reviewText:
For those interested in this game, here are some details that are useful to know.
You are a bipedal tank:
--- Your torso moves separate from legs, and some Mechs have Jump Jets, which allow short flight depending on the number of JJ's equipped.

This is a team game:
--- Stay with the pack, especially when you first start. Don't be the only Mech the enemy sees.

One Life to Live:
In standard Quick Play" game you drop in one Mech
recommended:
you will have to wait until that game is finished before you can play that Mech again. In Faction Play (Clan Warfare) you get to drop with 4 Mechs.

This is a "slow" paced shooter:
--- Movement and turn speeds are based on the Mech you are in
hoursPlayed:
not the speed you set your mouse to.

Variation:
---The speed difference alone between the fastest and slowest Mech is over 100kph
voteText: leading to huge variations in play style. Aside from this

votesHelpful: Ballistics/PPCs
votesTotal: Long Range Missiles (LRMs)

and Short Range Missiles (SRMs) all have different methods to success.

Location based damage:
---  If you "spray and pray"

make sure to turn your torso to spread damage.

Heat management is very important:

reviewText:
Always press R
Turn off arm lock and throttle decay when you learn how to walk.
Press X to stop.
Use arrows and right control to assign weapon groups.
«CLAN» doesn't mean «unit of players» in this game, it's lore stuff, google for «Battletech clans» (you will also find out why 90% of players have Kerensky in their nicknames).
Ammo can explode. Except Gauss ammo. Other equipment doesn't explode. Except Gauss rifle.
You can switch ECM modes with J button.
Pegular PPC doesn't deal any damage in range below 90 meters.
You will get banned for mentioning Hitler. 40 years old men playing this game don't get jokes.
Hold alt while entering 3rd peson mode to keep minimap active.
And don't forget to add smurfy mechlab and Sarna to your bookmarks.

Now you can robot.

reviewText:
Edit:
There seem to be a lot of people who are eager to downvote reviews for no reason.
I'm up for criticism, so if you find my review to be not helpful, let me know why.

The Thing:
Since it's release I've been coming back to this game and it will very likely remain one of my all time favorites
Don't let my relatively low play time on Steam fool you. I've been playing this game for a long time before it was on Steam. [hipster]And obviously before it was cool.[/hipster]

The thing I probably like most about it is it's complexity. It is indeed a rather complex game and it requires time to learn and overcome. If you prefer a more casual approach to a game similar (similar, not the same!) to this, I'd recommend Robocraft.
(EDIT: I do not recommend Robocraft anymore!)
But this here is Robocraft for grown-ups, for people with fully developed breasts and beards.
I'm serious. You will have to invest time into this game for it to be good. And, if you do, it's going to be really good, that much I can tell you.

What to expect:
Very tactical and very team-oriented games of 12 versus 12 giant robots from the future, armed to the teeth.

Mostly extremely customizable mech-loadouts (depending on faction).
Any mech plays differently, some of them fundamentally differently. Even a single mech can play very differently, if you just change the weapons.
Do you like to let rockets rain down on your enemies from 1000 meters away? Or do you want to do sustained damage with lasers over medium distances? Maybe you like to just go in and brawl face to face with short range missiles. Maybe you feel like a supporter and want to help your mates by providing visuals on enemies for your team to lock on.

The four weight classes (light, medium, heavy, assault) are very distinct from one another.
Lights, for instance, are able to easily outmaneuver the rather cumbersome assault mechs. But lights also have very little armor and, of course, not as much firepower as the bigger ones.
Medium mechs feel like a good allround-weight class, probably best to start with.
Heavies to me are, well, heavier mediums. That's not meant to sound derogatory. After all, heavies are heavier than mediums, because they have more room for armor and weapons. They're probably as good of a weight class to start out with as mediums.

Within the game itself there's both a casual approach, as well as a more competetive player base.
You can drop (your mech gets deployed by a dropship) in games alone with other loners, who might play well as a team or mess up completely, because they're bad at communicating. These drops are referred to as PUG-drops (Pick Up Group). Or you can form a group of up to 12 players and drop with them.
There's faction play, where units (basically the name for the guys with tags in front of their names, in other games usually called 'clans') come together to fight for star systems. They can control star systems and have to defend them against other units, or they will lose control over them.
There's also a lot of people role playing, who enjoy lore-based... stuff. I mean, lore-based things, you get the idea. Duels between two mechs for instance, with important things like, I don't know, honor and ♥♥♥♥. Read the books.

The devs are cool and nice and react and interact and everything. They stream on Twitch on a regular basis where you can watch them work on new content and watch them just generally be in touch with their player base.

The devs also reward players for playing. There's been customer appreciation reward programs. Within these you'd receive rewards varying from C-Bill-rewards (C-Bills are the ingame currency you earn by playing) just for playing the game. Plus, if you've decided to put money into the game and buy MC (the ingame currency bought for $$$) or one of their mech packs, you usually get a whole bunch of other things (including MECHS!) for free.

This game has one of the most mature player bases I know. People usually are more respectful and more helpful. After all, there's a high likelihood of them having fully developed breasts and beards.
You can easily drop into a game at any time, ask for new friends and what you get is people who want to marry you. There's also a looking for group function in the main menu. This way you can easily group up with strangers from all over the world. It's like OKcupid, but with giant stomping robots, war and explosions. What more could you wish for?
There are a few things that shouldn't go unmentioned, though:
In the beginning, meaning for your first 25 matches, you will receive very high C-Bill rewards. Same goes for completing the tutorial, which you should play in any case. You'll have a few million C-Bills after completing those first matches and the tutorial. After this, however, progress will be much slower.
You have to be aware that sometimes earning C-Bills feels like grinding. Other times it's a lot of fun, because it just happens while playing. After all, there's a certain satisfaction to melting through your enemies' armor and soldering off their arms to cripple their firepower. I mean it. This is something I haven't experienced in any other game so far.

It is after your 25 first matches and after the completion of the tutorial when you should start looking for which mech you want to buy first. For this you'll have to read into the meta a little, at least that's what I'd recommend. There are some helpful videos on the Tubes of You, too.
Search for mechs that are good, avoid mechs that really are bad (not many, but they do exist at the moment).
And if at first you don't like the mech you purchased, don't worry. It might just take some time to get used to it and figure out the way it's played best. This really does take some time with any mech, especially if you're just starting out. So take your time, don't get frustrated too easily.
If after a while you still don't like your first mech, try different builds on it. If you still don't like it, try a mech of another weight class.

You will have to use trial mechs for your first games. These mechs are being interchanged every now and then, so people can try out different ones.
There are 4 mechs free to use in every weight class. 2 of each belong to one of the two factions: The Inner Sphere or the invading Clans.

The game is not pay to win.
Yes, certain mechs are only available for MC. But they are not superior. Some (few!) of them happen to be within higher tiers of the current meta, but they are surrounded and outnumbered by mechs for C-Bills. Others are only available for real $$$ over a period of time, before getting released for the purchase with C-Bills.
Some of the things you can buy for MC include premium time and cosmetic items, such as paint jobs for your mech or cockpit items.
By the way, there are lots of events that let you earn cosmetic items, mech bays or even mechs, simply by participating.

You will need free mech bays in order to park new mechs.
In the beginning you have a few free mech bays. Once they are full, you obviously need new ones. Mech bays can only be bought for MC OR have to be earned by participating in events. If you really, really don't want to invest any money whatsoever in this game, you can do so. But then you should make sure to participate in most of the events. Otherwise you won't have enough free bays to park your mechs at some point.
tl;dr
Wow. This was a long review.
Unfortunately there is no way for me make this short. It is a complex game that deserves a long review. I recommend you read the whole thing.
Ultimately I recommend you play the game.

reviewText:
Being a mechwarrior since 1995 and MWO player since beta, with over 500hrs actual playtime on the battlefields plus around 400hrs more in the mechlab and over 500€ spent in mech packs and MC, I guess I can proudly call myself a mechwarrior veteran.

Even this game has nothing much left to do with the former serie except the lore itself and its technichal gameset, I can still say that MWO is the best free-to-play game on the market, next to Planetside 2 and War Thunder.
Overall it wins mostly because of its community. Really, the community is massive. You dont get that often in the F2P era...

Pros:
+ hundreds of different mechs
+ all highly customizable
+ complex loadout editor/mechlab
+ multiple classes/roles to play
+ events with free stuff every week
+ big legit, active and nice community
+ both competitive and lore friendly
+ leagues
+ a lot of different factions to fight for
+ 4 gamemmodes
+ decent amount of maps
+ runs smooth and stable
+ thousands of units to play with
+ voice chat
+ frequent updates (yes they work on it 24/7!)
+ tiers

Cons:
- tiers
- time and money consuming (as all F2P titles)
- steep learning curve
- unforgiving gameplay
- sometimes" frustrating
- minor bugs
- no AI (yet!)
- still no coop (but announced for 2016)
- some mechs can only bought with real money
(they are not better or something - NO PAY TO WIN HERE!)
- too few maps imo
- THE META!

Pro Tips:
- look at the map constantly
- find allies

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying I am still playing MWO, off and on, and will continue playing it because it does enough things right to be a worthwhile game.  If you don't care about the background skip to the pros and cons!
Keep in mind when reading MWO Steam reviews that there is a huge community schism regarding MWO.  Many old players (sometimes called 'Islanders') are justifyably frustrated by PGI's handling of the game.  Others (the 'white-knights') believe that the game is finally in a good place and is getting better, and that PGI is therefore forgiven for past transgressions.  Most probably fall somewhere in-between.  I would like to imagine I fall somewhere into the third camp.

Now for the bad news.  As many things as MechWarrior Online does right, there are still so many things wrong with it I cannot in good conscience recommend it to new players.

I will skip the diatribe about PGI's terrible history with community relations (I was a Legendary Founder which means I paid way too much money during alpha for a product that fell short of almost all of its design goals) and focus on the pros and cons of the game as it stands now.  Other reviews adequately cover the game's rocky history.

What I like-Very graphically appealing
-Sound is immersive
-Combat feels visceral and intense.  Inflicting and recieving damage involves a lot of sparks, explosions and camera shake
-Battlemechs have never felt stompier!
-Matches are generally fast and tight
-Weapons feel thematic (Lasers travel instantaneously and 'burn' for an extended duration, missiles are fired in swarms, ballistics throw sparks on impact and cause the victim's cockpit to jerk)
-Is fairly simple to learn and play without lacking strategic depth
-Teamwork is paramount and rewarded through play
-The community can be great
-A number of people have correctly pointed out that new players get a number of c-bill injections to help them outfit their first mech or two.  It's a nice touch, as long as new players are careful about what they spend this cash on

What I don't-The grind is obscene.  There are people who will tell you otherwise.  They play a lot more than you and have the skills, equipment and chassis to rack up those c-bills.  As a new player, you won't have this luxury, so expect an uphill battle to afford even one properly equipped chassis with double heat sinks, endo-steel structure, an engine that doesn't suck and a loadout that won't overheat after one alpha this isn't entirely true anymore, new players will likely be able to afford their first chassis relatively quickly but will suffer from a rapid dropoff of income once their rookie bonus runs out
-Related to the above, PGI prices content like mechs higher than any other F2P game I've ever played.  Hearthstone and League of Legends both require far less time and money to 'max out' an account on, and many complain about the grind in those games
-The metagame is somewhat rigid and PGI hasn't done a great job of balancing it
-There is a serious lack of variety in terms of maps and modes - while it is not as bad as it used to be pretty much there are only two things to do, competitive community warfare matches (meh) and random queue brawls (this is almost all of what you'll be doing)
-Grind
-New players aren't given any freebies, they have to play with garbage trial mechs that use stock configurations from the tabletop game until they can afford to invest in one of their own It has been brought to my attention this is no longer the case.  The trial mechs are far better designed than they used to be, I might even pilot a few tonight!
-While the bonus cash for new accounts is nice, the falloff afterwards can be pretty staggering.  Especially since you still need to skill 3 variants of a mech in order to unlock the elite skills
-The community can suck
-Did I mention the grind?

ConclusionI usually don't review games on steam, but I felt compelled to in this case.  MWO is very close to being the great game it always had the potential to be, but PGI needs to seriously reconsider their pricing model as well as the pacing of in-game rewards if they don't want to drive away most of their new Steam players.

As a prospective player, my recommendation would be that you play the game and find out for yourself.  It costs you nothing but the time it takes to download and play it, so unless you're an impulsive spender it can't really hurt to see if it appeals to you.  There isn't really anything else like it on the market.

Edit: for those who don't understand why I gave this game a negative review despite its merits, there is no option between 'recommend' or 'not recommend'.  For the time being my opinion leans towards the latter.

reviewText:
How can I sum up something so great as Mechwarrior Online into a short, readable review that won't sink too deep in analysing the techical aspects of the game?

Let's start by explaning what this game is all about...
Mechwarrior Online is set in the Battletech universe (1984), where different clans fight from planets and resources. You play 12 vs. 12 matches in various game modes and maps. Fighting, winning, and getting more money according to your combat performance has a great role in the game, but tinkering and customizing your 'Mechs is also a HUGE part of MWO (Mechwarrior Online).

'Mechs
So what are Mechwarriors then? Mechwarriors are the brave pilots of these huge lumbering mechanical tanks that have evolved from the basic battletank design into more efficient walking weapon platforms, 'Mechs.

'Mechs are divided into different categories according to their chassis weight: Light Mechs (35 tons), Medium Mechs (55 tons), Heavy Mechs (75 tons) and Assault Mechs (100 tons).

Lights are commonly used as scouts and intel 'Mechs, but they're also very efficient at taking down bigger assault mechs due to their great mobility. A pack of fast moving Light Mechs can easily swarm a bigger, slower 'Mech punching holes into the armors, tearing down weapons and limbs, eventually destroying it. And that can happen very fast if you're stranded too far from your team members.

Medium and Heavy Mechs are bit bigger, slower, carry more armaments and armor and can take up more beating than Light Mechs.

Assault Mechs are the biggest, slowest heavy hitters that you can see on the battlefield. A good Assault pilot will wreck everything coming it's way - but do not think that more weapons always means more success in combat. There are so many factors that you have to think during combat.

'Mech Loadouts
Every new 'Mech you buy comes with a stock loadout. Every 'Mech has 3-7 variants, which means the chassis of the 'Mech is pretty much the same, but the weapon hardpoints are different. One chassis might be more suitable for missile focused loadouts and other might have only hardpoints for energy weapons. On top of that, every chassis has Quirks, that give bonuses for movement, torso rotation speed, laser range, missile cooldowns etc. As I'm writing this review (Jan, 2016) there's been some rumours about the Quirks system going away somewhere in future, but I can't verify it at the moment. Personally I've always like the Quirk system, as it makes even the crappiest" 'Mechs still good when compared to the best of the best Clan 'Mechs.

The great thing in MWO is that you aren't limited into certain builds on every 'Mech. Once you select a 'Mech and open the loadout screen
date: you can fine tune pretty much everything from it and these all have advantages/disadvantages on battlefield. For example engines: you are free to tear down that small engine and replace it with a bigger
recommended: more faster engine. That'll make your 'Mech jog around faster
hoursPlayed: but bigger engine always means more weight too. More engine weight means less free tonnages available for weapon systems and other equipment. You can replace the normal STD-engines with lighter XL-engines. XL-engine weights less
voteText: but takes more space - and every 'Mech has a certain amount of free slots for equipment. On top of that the XL engine takes up space from both sides of torso too (Normal STD engine only uses center torso)
helpfulPercent: so if someone punches a hole into your side torso
votesHelpful: the engine is destroyed immediately. Destroyed engine means
votesTotal: blood
votesFunny: tears and game over.\n\nTo combat the tonnage limit of every 'Mech
commentsCount: you can modify the chassis by replacing the stock structures with more lighter Endosteel structure. This will free up some more tonnages for armaments

reviewText:
I have played a lot of Mechwarrior Online. To qualify that: I was one of the first 500 invited into the closed beta in 2012. I have also played community warfare (CW) with some of the best players in the game since that game mode was added over a year ago.

In 2011 I bought a 60 (Canadian) dollar founders pack for this game, because I feel that is a sane and reasonable limit to spend for a quality videogame product. And, despite the thumbs down on this review, at the time I was completely happy with my purchase. That 60 dollar founders pack came with an exclusive mech, 30 days of premium time, and 20 000 MC (the paid for currency of this game).

Today to buy the same collection of things in mechwarrior will cost you over 100 American dollars, and brings up the real issue I have with this game: The fun you will have is a byproduct of a gaming experience that has been designed from the ground up to take from you.

If you decide to play this game, you will face an extremely punishing grind. Mastering" a mech involves grinding out three tiers of skills with xp
date: which unlocks various bonuses that are straight upgrades. If you want that 7.5% faster run speed (huge) you will need to basic out all the elite skills on 3 mechs of the same chassis
recommended: essentially slightly different versions of the same mech. This is assuming that you have ground out enough cash to purchase the 3 mechs
hoursPlayed: and outfit them with good weapons
voteText: and upgrade them properly. It goes without saying that all of this takes a significant amount of time.\n\nThe classic rebuttal to this is the argument that this is a free to play game
helpfulPercent: and people are free to pay to bypass the grind. That fails to denude the fact that this game will either take a lot of your time
votesHelpful: or a lot of your money
votesTotal: or sometimes both (you can't buy those mastery skills but you can buy premium to help you grind faster). The carrot of mech stomping laser blasting fun lies at the top of a steep greasy hill
votesFunny: and the people on that hill will be firing at you the whole time you're climbing up.\n\nThis is the price you are expected to pay as a new player
commentsCount:
and it is why I cannot recommend this game to any of my friends or you.

reviewText:
As a new player, I think MWO is great. And as a new player I notice that this game gets a lot of hate for the product it used to be, rather than what it is.

As it stands, the game is generally very stable. I've been disconnected twice at the time of writing this and once was because of an earthquake at their server locations. It's a deep, tactical shooter with a lot of customization available. If you value positioning, constant map reassessment, tactics, and precision over snap accuracy then you should try MWO.

The F2P model is reasonable enough, and the game is not P2W. Within the first couple dozen games, anyone can afford a top tier mech layout. I don't know if MWO is going to continue with the frequent events they've been doing, but with them the grind is much less noticable with things like mech credits (paid currency), c-bills (in game currency), and premium time all being given out for free. I'd actually say the rate at which you get new stuff is about right with these events, so it may be too slow without them.

There is a little bit of an extra grind to get to the top which is with modules. Modules require global XP to learn the skills to use them and the modules cost a lot of c-bills (like as much as a new mech without being outfitted). Because of the ELO system in the game, Pilot Skill Rating (PSR), you won't really being playing against people with this gear in quick play. You will, however, be playing against these people in Community Warfare (CW).

CW is a fun mode that's a nice alternative to quickplay as the objectives are no longer symmetrical. It's meant to act as the global scale war that fits in with the lore of MechWarrior. It's not fully fleshed out yet though, and the main benefit for participating is ranking up with the various factions which do have some unique rewards. But the feeling of making a true impact isn't there yet. It's also not completely balanced between the factions.

Customer service has been good so far. I had an account issue that they resolved quickly, even with the holiday hours.

Bottom line: MWO is fun to play, offers a good freemium model, and the company seems to have changed their mentality in running this game for the better.

reviewText:
I'm a veteran player who has played since Closed Beta, spent a ridiculous sum of cash on this game, and logged over 4000 matches. I'll keep the review brief for those looking to get in.

Do I recommend this game? Absolutely. But a warning:

* If you're a diehard Battletech fan looking for a very deep experience such as Mechwarrior 2: Mercenaries or Mechwarrior 4: Mercenaries, you will not find it here.
* If you're a diehard Battletech fan looking for a deathmatch shooter with Mechs and customization options that you recognize? You will find that in Mechwarrior Online.

To everyone else? Give it a shot! The game is not without it's flaws, but the core gameplay is solid and a ton of fun.

reviewText:
There's little more for me to say when so many other reviews have aptly described the issues with this game, so I'll be blunt:

Try it if you really, really want to. There's no loss involved. But expect to be punished unless you're a veteran coming back or you've already spent money on the game.

Since other users have already thoroughly warned you about PGI's track record (and if you haven't seen that yet, you should glance through a few negative reviews, because they're valid,) I'll focus instead on warning you on what you, as a new player, should expect to see starting out.

The community is insular. They'll go on for hours and hours about how they want to be inviting and friendly, but their behavior and conduct don't reflect this. Teamplay is important, so pugs are referred to disparagingly by even the most polite of players. Most people still playing are still playing because they have intimate ties to the Battletech or Mechwarrior licenses; the game preys on their nostalgia and they in turn feed the machine and defend it from disparaging remarks. If you play other video games, expect to hear players lamenting about the call of duty" crowd or other such stupid garbage - further distancing themselves from the general community of online PC gamers at large.

The grind is deceptively monumental: you get a massive boost in cbills (ingame currency) via your first 25 matches and by completing the tutorial
date: which is generally enough to purchase (though not properly outfit) a single inner sphere mech. If you want to be on even remotely even footing with anyone else
recommended: you will need to do this three times: purchase three variants of a single mech
hoursPlayed: outfit those three variants so they're viable enough to play (stock builds are enormous garbage
voteText: ) and then play them until you rack up enough experience points to grind out all their "basic skills
helpfulPercent: which are flat percentage increases to your mech's performance (reduced heat generation, increased acceleration and deceleration, the works.) This will allow you access to a chassis' elite skills
votesHelpful:
which are even more powerful advantages afforded to you for greater XP cost (including increased top speed.) Unlocking all four on a variant will literally double all bonuses conferred from basic skills. Yes, you read that right. Grinding obscene amounts of experience into a mech makes it infinitely superior to the same variant, same build, piloted by a new player, regardless of player skill.

After your cadet bonuses are gone, your average income per match as a new player may run anywhere from 50,000 cbills (on a loss) to 300,000 cbills (on a well-played win. You will not see this much money as a new player, as the game's mechanics are relatively complicated, poorly explained, and map design is extremely unforgiving to inexperienced players.) You can probably expect about 100k to 150k per match if you're new. Mech prices vary wildly depending on tonnage, stock loadout, and technology (a clan heavy omnimech with a gauss rifle is going to be much more expensive than an inner sphere light mech with medium lasers and machine guns.) You can expect a decent IS heavy to run you about 7-8 million cbills, then outfitting it with decent weapons, upgraded systems (endo-steel and double heat sinks are generally a must) and a good engine may cost you as much as 7 million more. You can expect a decent clan mech (the stormcrow and timber wolf, both clan mechs, are still bar-none the best vehicles in the game) to run you anywhere from 10 million to 14 million cbills, but luckily there's less to upgrade. Sure hope you know what actually performs well, though, because if you ♥♥♥♥ up and build something ♥♥♥♥♥♥, you'll be selling it back for a fraction of what it cost you.

Weapon balance is comical. There exist entire weapons systems in the game that are completely useless, including machineguns and flamers. No one will tell you this, because A) PGI doesn't understand their own game and balances around a meta they know nothing about, B) the game is loaded with whales who believe themselves to be experts on the game's balance who will tout that you can pilot anything and perform well, as long as you know what you're doing (they don't.) and C) knowledge is steeply guarded by anyone who actually knows how to play the game. Comp" teams are fiercely protective of their strategies and aren't about to share tips and tricks with every Tom
votesFunny: and Harry fresh off of steam. There was a line from the old Battletech cartoon that the players think is a hilarious meme: "Information is ammunition." Well it's true
commentsCount:
and ammunition is both in shortage and at a premium.

Suffice it to say that lasers are almost universally better than any other weapon.

Map design and the existence of 12v12 matches also have a massive impact on weapon balance

reviewText:
I have to say this game is fantastic.

First off, I don't think it's really pay to win nearly as bad as most free to play games.  I see alot of complaints about this and I don't agree. Here are my reasons:

-You start out with 4 trial mechs from each weight class (trial as in they're set loadouts, you can't customize them, that's it). So in other words, you start out with 16 mechs to try out. That's plenty for me to start with personally.

-Secondly, you can purchase and customize mechs with c-bills you earn from matches.  It's not too bad really, Ten 8 minute matches got me a good mech that I was able to deck out and start getting more kills with during matches.

-You really could not spend a dime and get a fulfilled mechwarrior experience from this game. I know I did for the first few weeks without spending anything. You can earn everything you need pretty quickly to get a handful of decent to good mechs going, and the game starts you out with some c-bills and some premium time. I only spent money because I started really getting into the game and decided I wanted to get some premium time going and to purchase a champion mech pack at some point. Plus, I honestly felt like the developers earned my money because the gameplay is that good.

OK, let's talk about the heart of the game.  How is the actual gameplay you say?  Well, as a pretty big Battletech fan and someone who played Mechcommander and Mechwarrior 3 & 4... IT'S EFFING FANTASTIC.  God, this is the best part of the game for sure.  I love the gameplay, the visuals effects, the sound effects, the tactics and potential for teamwork, everything.  The battles are how I would imaging actual Mech Combat. The autocannons roar, lasers tear, missiles swarm.  It's so good, I love it.  Even if you're not into battletech, I think most people can appreciate the realistic feel of the mechs, and the roles of the weightclasses: assault mechs brawling, heavy mechs dishing it out, and medium and light mechs supporting. It's beautiful.  I thought Piranha Games nailed mech combat.  Also, customization is awesome and relatively balanced as far as I can tell so far. I will give a fair warning that you have to use a little patience and thought when starting out.  This isn't CoD, you don't charge in and kill.  You have to stick with your team, use cover and try to use hit and run tactics.  Also, try not to drive an Assault mech first thing, you need to work up to that to utilize it properly.  If you're not a Battletech fan, I definitely recommend this game.  If you're a Battletech fan, you have to play this game!!

Alright, so I'll telly you what I think the downsides are.  The quickplay matches are a little repetitive. Not as bad as some people are saying, in my opinion the gameplay more than makes up for it.  That said, there are about 8 or so maps currently, and 3 game modes (assault, conquest, and team deathmatch). It could use a little spicing up for sure. Games typically last 5 to 15 minutes.  However - this is only the quickplay version of the game.
The main feature of the game takes place in the form of faction play, which I'm only beginning to get into and understand.  This gameplay takes place in the form of territory conquest in via assault and defence of planets.  This form of gameplay definitely has some more meat to it.  For instance one game mode takes place in the form of defending a base with friendly defense turrets and gates at the front (highly reminiscent of mechcommander i thought) which was awesome.  This is pretty cool, but my problem with faction play so far is it seems more than a little elitist (tons of premades and clans steamrolling PUGs) and not only that but it seems very difficult to break into. Like, it feels like in order to get serious about faction play, I have to prove I'm good enough to join some group that meets every Sunday, etc. Don't like that, a little too reminiscent of WoW or some other mmo for me.  This part of the game is probably a little more pay to win, or, invest a ton of time and reading online forums to win.  I don't like that too much.  The game doesn't explain the faction play very well at all, and the interface is kind of a mess and overloading the player with options.  You have to look it all up online to learn anything.

Anyways, despite a few things I don't care for, I think this game is great.  I'd give it a solid 9/10 to anyone interested in picking this game up.

(Edit: I haven't played this since sometime in May in 2014.)
I was one of the original 120$ Legendary Founders back in 2012. I played this daily for 2 years, clocking in a ridiculously large amount of time and Mech collection. I watched whole clans come and go as a community spiked up over the hype then died off when the game didn't deliver. It spiral downwards since it was created. We used to talk about it coming to Steam back then, and now, only out of desperation to save this doomed product, has it finally come. This is now the THIRD release for this game. The second one was falsely touted as the first by its own creators despite already having been out for a year... and now it's releasing again on Steam. They're trying to save what I used to call a sinking ship. I'd now call it a sunken ship. Btw, the Steam version still requires you to make a MWO account... defeating any point of having been put on Steam to begin with. This port tells me that the game is finally dying, which it should have done LONG ago.

But hey, since they want to port their crappy game over to Steam, I guess I'll port my review too. This is for you PGI. I still haven't forgotten the times you wiped my CBILLS bank for not liking one of my Mech builds and unnecessarily suspending me off the official forums. As I said back then, you can't censor Metacritic. That applies to Steam as well.

MechWarrior Online, August 18, 2014, from my Metacritic.
PGI is a horrible developer; one of the worst I've seen. They go back on every promise. They miss every deadline. They make fake pipedream promises that'll never come. They censor or ignore their own community. They totally wreck things that were already working fine beforehand. They put in garbage no one wanted like ECM, ghost heat, 3PV, and UI 2.0. These things only hurt the game, not help. But any attempt to tell them this is met with a ban hammer, assuming you get read at all. MechWarrior Online as a whole has only gotten worse since closed beta, not better. Despite being a huge fan of the MechWarrior franchise and old games, I'm not one of the many fanboys that are going to stick up for this crap of a game or developer.

reviewText:
Going to leave a quick review here. Personally I think MWO is a great game. I have spent, and will continue to spend, many hours playing it. I've been a player for over 2 years now. It takes a little bit of getting used to it because of the learning curve, but if you want a first person, big, stompy 'mech battle with different types of weapons, then you should try out this game.

You can drop in quick play for a 12v12 match or go into community warefare with longer matches and more 'mechs. Teamwork is a top priority. Take time to outfit your 'mechs with the right equipment for your playstyle as you go, and unlock skills with your experience points, to improve as a pilot.

Pros:
-Big stompy 'mechs
-Good graphics and sound
-Dedicated playerbase from before the Steam launch, but even more players with it
-Free to play and not pay to win

Cons:
-Steep learning curve (I stongly recommend completing the tutorial)
-Technical loadouts for 'mechs can be time consuming to research or build, including the grind to get enough in-game money to purchase equipment and unlock skills (though you don't have to go too hardcore)

Overall I say if you're unsure give it a try as it is free, and see if you like it yourself, because everyone is different. The community will give advice if you ask for it.

So see you on the battlegrounds! o7

reviewText:
MechWarrior Online is a game of thirds. 1 third is the actual game, i.e. using giant stomping mechs to shoot lasers, cannons and missiles at other mechs. The next third is build said mechs, the mech lab and coming up with builds is one of the best parts of the game. It isn't like most other games, you can make terrible mechs if you don't know what you are doing, but if you know your strengths you can make amazing mechs. The final third of the game is the people, I didn't enjoy MWO initially because I was playing on my own. I connected to the Comstar NA team speak channel and just met people who also play MWO and had a great time. I also lurked and eventually contributed to the forums at http://www.mechspecs.com and I enjoyed the game even more.

You can drop some real money in the game to buy mechs, and I recommend you do to support the game, but you don't have to because there is no Pay To Win" aspect of the game.

I've spent more time playing MWO than any game I have ever owned and I still keep coming back for more. Highly recommended."

reviewText:
I've played MWO since closed Beta, over 3 years, and I love it. After playing for all this time, I can easily say that MWO has had better staying power than nearly any other computer game I've ever played. I also, for the most part, like the MWO community. I've met some great friends and have a lot of fun playing with them. Although, you don't have to join a group to have fun. I've had hundreds of great games playing solo.

The ability to customize your mech to fit your chosen game style is great. Scout, brawler, sniper, missile boat, leader or follower. Fast mechs, slow mechs, big mechs or small mechs. Lasers, canons, missiles, or support roles like NARC, ECM, and tag. The game has some real depth to it, and the developers continually work to make it better. My experience with the support team has been good (and I really have had to work with them on some connection issues).

It's not like most shooters, where your life span is measured in seconds. In games like Halo and COD, I always disliked that the average life span seemed to be 10 seconds or less. In MWO you can live for several minutes while taking fire and get into some insane brawls with opposing mechs. Minor mistakes can be overcome (provided your mistake isn't walking smack into the middle of the opposing team) and you can really make a difference to your side's success even after half your mech is blown off.

Having said that, the game does have a learning curve. There can be real depth to the gameplay. Teamwork is very key. You have to watch your position relative to your team, your enemy, and the map itself. Some locations on the maps are better than others, and you'll have to discover them. You have to pay attention to your heat, your mechs armor and internal structure, your weapon status, and to be a good player you also have to pay close attention to your opponents status and aim with precision at where they are weakest; all the while maneuvering as best you can to absorb incoming fire while delivering your own.

The tutorial is pretty good and a must for new players. Several of the existing player groups will also welcome new players and help you learn. I know mine will. If you can, get into one of the teamspeak rooms and ask around, or look at the gaming fourms in the faction groups. Most players are helpful in answering honest questions.

I would recommend premium time at a minimum if you're serious about playing. The 50% boost to Cbills and expierence really add a great deal over time and let you customize your mechs in a relatively short time. I would also recommend you find what kind of mech you like and then give a Hero Mech a try. The Hero Mechs give Cbill and experience bonuses that stack with the premium time. Make money with a Hero Mech and you can purchase and kit out your garage nicely without having to pay a dime more. I have way over a hundred mechs, and most of them were purchased for free, with Cbills earned in the game (or even given away by the developers during special weekend events!).

Of course, some mechs are better than others, and there's always going to be meta" mechs and builds that are at the top
date: but the developers really have done a pretty good job of balancing the mechs. The game is definitely NOT pay to win. The Hero Mechs and Premium time ease the grind

reviewText: A multi-layered cooperative tactical first person shooter. Your skill matters, but so do your choices regarding what weapons and equipment to put on your battlemech. Instead of being able to respawn, you have a durable giant stompy robot. Armor protects your internal structures (legs, arms, torsos, head) and components, and 'mechs are often able to stay in the fight with multiple destroyed sections. There are a variety of weapon systems, covering short & long range, and burst or steady damage -- with a cooldown & heat management system to keep you from firing all the weapons all the time. Battle awareness and communication play are crucial, as you work with 11 other players to encounter and destroy a roughly even opposing force of 12 rival pilots. There is a full spectrum of mech sizes (20 ton light 'mechs" to 100 ton "assault 'mechs") that slot into a variety of roles (scout

reviewText:
I joined closed beta in June 2012 and havent stopped playing since then. I have logged thousands of matches and have spent a few hundred bucks on the game.

That said, you'd think I could offer up a recommendation for this game, but I cant really do that. It's literally only the fact that it is a Battletech related game that has kept me involved and willing to deal with the multitude of issues MWO has.

The most prominent of these is the developer, PGI itself. Much of their more malicious and disengenuous history can be atrributed to the earlier years with IGP calling shots ($500 mech packs for just a golden skin spring to mind) but the absolute glacial progress MWO shows is the most grevious. Its been 3 years and MWO is still just an arena shooter, with next to no actual lore involved in regular gameplay beyond the mechs themselves.

Community Warfare attempts to simulate the actual struggle between the IS and Clan forces, but its shortcomings are vast. The game mode itself is extremely limited with extremely unrealistic (an illogical) goals in place in each round. It allows no seperation between solo players and united 12 man groups, something you'd be hard pressed to encounter in any decent online game.

Absolute miniscule, extremely necessary changes take weeks, even months to be implemented or corrected. PGI has a now legendary history of being completely incapable of small tweaks to balance. Instead, large and sweeping changes are made despite extremely vocal player feedback in test servers. The users who frequent the MWO forums often provide spreadsheets and their own data collection, with reasoned and well versed feedback as to how to make MWO balance better and fair, and it falls on deaf ears.

I dont want to include PGI's pricing scheme in this review, as Im sure it will be mentioned over and over. At the end of the day, I dont think the value even begins to approach what you get, especially when it seems like so little progress gets made. In no exaggerated terms, as someone who has played from the very beginning, MWO is different now after three years of progress: There are more mechs, more (but not many) maps, far worse graphics, more Cockpit novelty items, and a broken community warfare module. It's primary mode of play is still arena shooter, despite having three different ways of calling it (Assault, skirmish, conquest). There is no depth to any of these modes, and no attempt has been made to fix that after all these years.

Despite all of these shortcomings, I continue to play because Ive played Mechwarrior games since 1995. As soon as someone else is given the chance to make a Mechwarrior game, I will wholeheartedly jump ship, because I have a hard time imagining another company could do so little with so much time with the Mechwarrior license.

reviewText:
Mech warrior online is a thinking mans shooter based on the Battle Tech system.

You have to select what parts of your mech are armored the most.
You have to select what type of weapons to install on your hard points.
You have to setup good cooling, or you will not enjoy this game, anything above value 1.1.
For new users I would recommend nothing below value 1.3 cooling.


You have to decide which mech is right for you.

A light mech with the best speed, low armor, superior maneuverability, most often jump jets. Very little room for cooling.

A medium mech with balanced armor, slightly more fire power, good speed, and lesser to great maneuverability. Some times has jump jets, has a good balance for adding heat sinks and pretty mech any equipment you may need.

A heavy mech, the back bone of mech warrior arsenal, great armor, slower movement, and low to lesser maneuverability. Fewer heavy mechs have jump jets. You will have to decide what is more important. A higher alpha stike with higher heat spikes, or better sustained fire with very balanced heat.

An assault mech can have the most fire power, the highest armor, slowest speed, and poor to very poor maneuverability. Very rare to use jump jets in an assault. Heating a cooling on these mechs is completly custom and up to the user.

Roles

Light mechs often are the tie breaker of any match. If you take out the enemy light lance you have almost full control over the battlefield during the course of any match. Lights are the bane of assault mechs. Light mechs are the scouts and the ace in pocket for advanced users.

Medium mech are great for support. They can take a few more hits than the lights and are well balanced to fullfil almost any role long range or short, scouting, sniping, anti air. You name it there is a meduim mech that can do it, they just make poor tanks.

Heavy mechs are the real bread n butter of battle tech. Not too slowed down by a massive amount of armor and the can carry enough fire power to topple almost any mech in seconds 1v1. Heavy mechs also are some of the hottest mechs in the game, so beware of cooling issues.

The assault mech is more than a tank. If built right, an assault mech can wipe out an entire lance quickly, but their slower speed and poor maneuverability make them prime targets for enemy light mechs and lrms. Do not chase the squirrels in an assault mech it will always end badly for you. If you have a squirrel climbing up your leg, call out to your team for assistance, or you better pray a snap shot can take dispatch them quickly, otherwise your SOL.

Very immportant words,, STAY WITH YOUR TEAM or die alone.

Any first time player should stick with Inner Sphere medium or light mechs for the best playable experiance, they dont cost much but the equipment to add to them does cost a lot.
Plus the Inner Sphere light have the most customization and max speed of all mechs.
Then work your way into a medium, heavy, or better, or even Clan mechs. The bigger the mech the slower it is and the bigger target you are for the other team. Light and fast is what I enjoy the most.

I can not recommend Clan mechs for new players. The clan mech are so gimped on tonnage for custom equipment because you can not change your engine, and the heat build up is sky high. They do have better range and more custom hard points, but the heat build up is soo high, you can not balance max fire power with max cooling. The max cooling is never enough for a Clan mech. The Origin ii c mechs trade omni pods (custom hardpoints) for the ability to change engines. They actually work quite well and can be cooled very well.

Hope this post was helpful, and do remember to torso twist.

reviewText:
For those new to mechwarrior, allow me to provide an introduction.

These are not ultra fast, missile dodging anime style mecha.  These are big slow stompy deathbots that will get hit by hundreds of missiles, get annoyed and fire back.  Fast kills are rare, instant kills are extremely rare.

A battlemech is a 20-100 ton battle machine.  Each section of the mech has it's own independant health, and you can lose most of them without dying.  For example, if you are running a standard type engine you can lose both arms, one leg, your left torso and your right torso and still keep fighting.

You get to customize everything.  We're not talking putting skins on your guns, we're talking what guns do you want to carry where, how many rounds for each, how many heat sinks to keep the machine from getting to hot?  What size engine?  How much armor on your left leg, right leg, left arm, right arm, head, left torso, right torso, center torso, left tear torso, right rear torso, center rear torso?  - oh yeah, you get to paint everything too if you still care.

Teamwork is the deciding factor in matches, the nature of the machines and how they move and take damage means that even the most skilled player can't overcome a team that abandons them to the enemy.  Putting your team in a bad spot will lose the match even if you are better shots than they are.  This is chess with more layers of complexity.

Play intergalactic war.  There are 10 factions vying for control of the universe, pick one and start claiming entire planets in their name as you fight your way across the galaxy.

Now that you have the basics, here's the details on how this game has been.  I joined in closed beta and have been an active player the entire time, including all the massive meltdowns caused by actions of the publisher.  These incidents are incrediby public and easy to look up.  Yes, they earned a bad rep.
However, the game itself is quite fun.  It is not pay to win - the cash only mechs are not inherently better.  Different, but not better than the ones you can get for free.  If anything this game is only pay not to grind, which is fine.

Honest final recommendation?  If you are tired of fast action, actually want to see who is shooting you, and want to actually fight the other guy give this a shot.  If you like it, then put in a few bucks for a pack of mechs, skip a ton of grinding and enjoy yourself.  Also, join a team.  If you don't join a team, you will get constantly stomped in the community warfare mode.  Cannot stress this enough - no team, don't join CW.

reviewText:
I have played MW, MW2, MW3, MW4, its expansions (including MechTek) and the Mech Commander games.  MW4's multi-player PvP was awesome and all of the above were great games... MWO sadly is not.

I really wanted to like this game and gave it a solid try, however it is nothing but a PVP grind designed to tempt fans into forking over money so they can experience their favorite battlemechs.  The assets and design are fantastic and beautiful works of art.  There is so much potential to use them to make a proper Mechwarrior game.  Right now the assets are used to charge fans ~$10-30 a mech (or a very very long grind).  Why anyone would use their money to buy these and not better games on Steam is beyond me.

I love Battletech, but you PGI have turned it into an empty shell with only pretty graphics and no substance.  We have TWO options: PUGs or CW with forced 12v12: turning every game into a pop-tart shooting contest – where is the fun in that?  Shame on all of you (except your artists, they did a phenomenal job).

Hopefully Harebrained Schemes can redeem Battletech with their new project.

reviewText:
'Mech Warrior Online is an incredible shooter that, while not as 'simulation' heavy as the older titles in the series, still ends up coming out feeling like the only decent 'Mech Simulator on the market for the last 10 years. Forget that Hawken junk.

'Mech Warrior Online is set in the battletech universe and as such brings 30 years worth of history and lore with it, though admittedly most of is left on the table and instead you're given a solid, action packed shooter that focuses on what matters: The 'Mechs. And it pulls the combat off excellently. No absured spotting mechanic that plagues these kind of games, no stupid dice rolls and 24% deviance on impact, no sloping and facing that unrealistically bounces shots (Thoug this skill is replaces with your own skills at spreading damage) and of course, no Russian Bias.

BALANCE, as with most shooters is a hard thing to talk about. It's constantly in flux and tryhards always use the current meta builds that weild the most damage in a single strike and nothing else. However saying that, balance is in the best place it's ever been for a long long time. Sure there are still some usless weapons (Flame throwerers) but now it's more about what works on your 'Mech rather than how many of weapon X you can squeeze on. I have never once found a death in MWO to be annoying or 'cheap' in MWO. Something I don't think any other game can claim.

'Mechs themselves are also generally well balanced however there are 'Mechs that are simply better than others in certain weight catagories. They usually have tradeoffs, and many of the Worse" Inner Sphere 'Mechs have "Quirks" to make them more appealing

reviewText:
As a veteran player, a long time Mechwarrior fan, one of the first 600 players to sign up in 2011, and a closed beta tester I will say that this game is a disappointment.

The in-game new user experience is still dire after 3 years of the game being active. As of this year a new tutorial system has finally been implemented which helps players with movement, shooting, and controls but there still no in-game tutorial on how to navigate the MechLab (where you spend a good deal of time and build/customize 'Mechs). You're at the whims of the community on this one and will need to spend time reading guides and researching player suggested builds, which may be outdated or include biases. Since the MechLab is where you spend money (in-game and real), there's a good chance as a new player that you may spend money on the wrong thing and waste your time and money.

The overall gameplay once you get past the customization is shallow. In closed beta it was quickly found that the most optimal strategy was to ball up as a team and have everyone target one enemy 'Mech at a time as this would kill them quicker. This creates a snowball where once one team suffers one or two losses it's very hard to bounce back. This is the extent of strategy and tactics years later. It becomes quite repetitive.

Even though there are several game modes they all just devolve into team deathmatch, and some people even get real mad if you decide to play to the game mode objectives instead of just fighting.

Community Warfare, which sounds like it would be the main draw to the game, is just an afterthought. It's a bland Attack/Defend gamemode that, like the other modes, devolves into a deathmatch. Objectives are usually ignored. It has such a low population that it's tough to find matches at certain hours, and the matchmaking system has pretty much been stripped out and geared towards 'hardcore' players, which means if you decide to play some matches you'll be going up against veterans with years of experience and hundreds if not thousands of dollars worth of kit.

Visually the game used to look better. There was better damage modeling, the animation was better, and much of that deteriorated or was actively removed from the game in patches for some unknown reason. Some of it I'm sure was for performance reasons, but some of the changes over the years were baffling.

Overall, it's a disappointing game when you compare it to what it used to be and what it could have been.  I wouldn't recommend it to anyone, especially with so many other great games on Steam.

reviewText:
Introduction
I started this game 100% fresh to MechWarrior and BattleTech in general and am loving every minute of it. I don't feel as though it's pay to win, I'm no stranger to tactical shooters so maybe that helps.

After my first 25 Cadet games I had ~20 mill C-bills which seemed to be enough to get either a few IS mechs or a single clan mech and completely kit them out with a custom loadout. Which may not seem like alot, considering the vast variety of mech choices there are, but for the most part it's a solid starting point.

Free to Play model
I will argue that c-bill gain without premium time after those 25 cadet games can be very slow, but just like any similar game to this (World of Tanks, War Thunder, etc) it's just a grind, and for the most part the mechs are fairly well balanced at the moment. Some mechs are argueably just flat out worse than others, but if you learn the game mechanics and play properly any mech can work in the right pilots hands. So far I've spent very little money on this game and I have played it for a solid 2-4 hours minimum per day since I downloaded it and it's still a blast. I personally do not consider this game to be pay2win by any means.

Community
So far I have had very little problems with the community, the occasional salty teammate in chat, but what game doesn't have that. Not alot of people use the in game VOIP which is relatively disappointing considering the game revolves aren't alot of focus firing and communication, but it hasn't seemed to dictate the overall results of my matches (though the matches go much smoother when communication is present). There is tons of useful information for new and verteran players alike on the forums, pretty much anything I've wanted to learn about the game has been readily available via a simple google search.

Gameplay Mechanics
Being new to MechWarrior the gameplay mechanics at first were a little overwhelming but even the most average of gamers can readily grasp how to play the game and even more advanced mechanics like shielding and such. The introduction tutorial isn't anything incredible but it does give a fairly solid overview of the basics of the game such as targetting components, firegroups, and mech movement. For a little fun shoot the captain a few times after you finish the intial tutorial and are at the MechWarrior Academy.

Overall Verdit
I would 100% recommend this game to anyone who enjoys shooters in general, especially tactical team based shooters such as Arma or most Tom Clancy games. Team play is pretty key to success, very rarely does a lone wolf accomplish much in a match of MechWarrior, but even when your team doesn't communicate via chat or VOIP as long as you pay attention and try to focus targets down with your teammates the game doesn't feel like a complete landslide.

As for a number rating for those who enjoy those silly things, I would say somewhere around 8/10, definitely a game you can get very involved in and play every single day for extended sessions, or even the type of game you can just hop on for a couple matches every once in a while.

reviewText:
As a member of this community for nearly 3 years, I can confidently say that this game is worth your time.  It has had its up's and down's, even dissolved the original publisher (IGP).  But thats all in the past, lets talk about what the game is now.

-- MWO Smurfy Mechlab is your best friend! -- I highly recommend using this site to build mechs before you spend your hard earned c-bills.

The Good -
Lots of stompy mechs (300+)
Amazing Customization
Good core gameplay
Good beginner tutorial
The audio is pretty good.
Graphically it is pretty good, however the pilot model should updated at some point.
It is not a pay to win game, the pay features are to earn c-bills faster, the paid hero mechs aren't any better than the standard mechs, aside from earning 30% more c-bills.As long as you take your time in this game and dont just rush everything, you will do fine.

The Bad -
Mechbays are not easy to aquire for new players.  You get them from Community Warfare, events, or buy them.  However if you are enjoying the game, mechbays ARE worth the cost.
Community Warfare - It is in beta and it IS being worked on.  If you want to try Community Warfare as a solo player, or in a small casual group, it can be quite frustrating. Especially when going against organized teams.
Some of the free content is behind Community Warfare.  Example : Rank 2 of any faction gets you a mechbay.
No tutorial for the mechlab / customizing mechs.  And no way to test the loadout before your purchase.
Some information can be difficult to find.There is a lot of information to absorb in this game, and it can be overwhelming to some.  I am NOT adding balance to this list, because balance will always be changing.

MechWarrior Online has been going through some massive changes in the last year, after the removal of IGP.  Rebalancing will always be an issue, nothing will ever be perfect, this is the nature of an ever changing game.  They have been adding more and more content and attempting to make Community Warfare something that we can all enjoy.  just take the game slowly, it is a bit of a grind to get heavier mechs, but it will be worth it if you are patient.

Also if you have issues piloting your mech, drive it like a tank, its the same concept.

reviewText:
I've been playing MWO for around three years now. During that period it would be fair to say that the game has seen some ups and downs. However, over the last year or so, the game has got noticably better and it seems this trend is likely to continue.

The things are like about it are
*The combat is extremely deep, and tactical. The ability to specifically target different components to destroy or disable a mech is absolutely brilliantly done
*The building of mechs. You can totally customise every single mech to your playstyle and liking
*Balance. This game was horribly unbalanced between Clan Mechs and IS for a long time, but its better than it has ever been before currently
*Strategy and teamwork. This game rewards intelligence and teamwork over quick reflexes and lone wolfing.

The things I think could use some work are:
*Maps. I'd like to see more maps
*Community Warfare. Currently is too complicated and takes too long to find a game for casuals
*The graphics. Some parts of the game look great, some like dire. Needs more polish overall.
*There are still some terrible bugs that need fixing (like the stairs on Viridian bog)

But overall, the game is great fun, and probably my most consistantly played game of the last few years. The learning curve is steep, but I urge anyone with an interest in big stompy mechs exploding to give it a go.

Reactor....online.....systems.....online.....weapons..... online...... All systems nominal! See you on the battlefield, pilots!

reviewText:
Mechwarrior Online came with great promises and expectations in 2012, hoping to revive the abandoned genre of Battletech, which was one of the most influential genres back in the 90's. There hasn't been a real Mechwarrior PC game since year 2000, so when the MW:O was announced, hype was real and genuine. The developers of Mechwarrior Online, PGI, stated that MW:O is going to be a credible representation of the rich Battletech universe, with tactical combat, simulator experience of piloting a battlemech, including a large, community driven territory expansion and character development ecosystem, combined with real-time lore timeline progression. PGI called their game “thinking man's shooter”, due to how deep the battlemech customization, information warfare and combat roles are compared to any other arena shooters in the market.

They weren't entirely wrong, but MWO left a lot of things to be desired. Game has been available for 3 years, however many of the promised features are not in the game, will never be implemented, or are bare bone functional.

MWO offers  two game modes, available to any player. First mode, called “Quick Play”, is an arena game team deathmatch mode, where a matchmaker puts you on a random map of 13, with random people within your skill pool. There is nothing particularly worth mentioning, it is a Team Deathmatch of 12 players per team with no respawns. A quick, straightforward game mode, with high ingame currency and experience gain ratio. It is a recommended game mode for new players, until they grasp the basics of the game, then maybe join a clan and select their faction.
Second game mode is called “Faction Play”, previously known as Community Warfare. This is an advanced game mode, meant for intermediate players. You can play it as a novice, but you will be severely handicapped by doing that. FP/CW is a team deathmatch with objectives, where a team has to defend or destroy a mission objectives on the map to win the match. It is a slightly deeper in regards to tactics and drop preparation, since you can take up to 4 battlemechs in a match, however it is more time consuming and less currency friendly than Quick Play. This is meant to be the main game mode, but is currently in BETA 2, which is a PGI term for not complete. It should receive a  significant updates in the future, but is severely lacking currently.


Mechwarrior Online is a game that is really unique in this genre. It is the only mech combat simulator on the market, and the feeling of piloting a giant combat machine is really outstanding. This is the thing PGI got right. Unfortunately not many other things are on the same level. Once you make through very basic new player experience, you will have a limited amount of really good experience exploring new maps, battlemechs and different strategies, but once the dust settles, MWO is only a mediocre team deathmatch arena shooter with mechs, played on a seriously flawed maps, lacking the promised combat roles and information warfare. Severely lackluster game modes, combined with slow content release cycle and non-evolving balance due negligence of developers leaves little hope for the future of the game.

reviewText:
TLDR: MWO is a solid Mech combat game that suffers from an Apathetic, minimum viable product developers. It doesn't have the depth of many previous Mechwarrior/Battletech titles but can deliver a decent mech simulator experience with up-to-date graphics for those wanting.

It's hard to find a game as polarizing as MWO. Some love it, some hate it, but both sides have their points.

The game is far from new, at the time of this review its a little over 2 years old and just hitting steam now. It launched in 2013 to middling reviews, many can agree the core gameplay is solid. But on launch it only had two gamemodes, and in the two years since they claim to have added 3 more. Though one is Skirmish (Deathmatch) which added nothing new gameplay wise, and Invasion/Invasion Counter Attack (Same mode mirrored).

A vast majority of games will come down to destroying the enemy team, and to do so you have a very wide selection of mechs and loadouts. The meta of which has been evolving over the life of the game. As a Legendary Founder who has played on and off since beta I've seen the rise and fall of OP Alpha-strikes, LRMgeddon, Poptarting, etc. Currently the game revolves around mid-short range brawls, generally playing peakaboo at the line of skirmish until one side finds an edge and pushes through to vitctory. Games tend to play out a little one sided.

At the core of many arguments is the pricing model of MWO. At launch they offered tiered packs with exclusive mech variants to raise support for the game. While many accepted it as a good way to kickstart the games development, few suspected it would carry on as a common occurance. In 26 months there have been 5 more drives for money including Resistance I and II, and Clan invasion 1, 2, and 3. Not counting pre-order exclusivity to new Mechs for cash only. These typically offer a range of mechs from Light all the way up to Assault in increasingly expensive packs. A common criticism is the option to buy mechs 'a la carte' being much more expensive without offering many of the benefits of the pack. Making heavier mechs arbitrarily cost more as you will either have to pay the fee or suck it up and buy the rest of the lighter mechs bundled together.

Another criticism is the exclusive variants of mechs marketed as heroes" for cash only. While they are generally considered on par if not worse than ones available for in-game currency. Many find it distastful to lock potentially gameplay and balance effecting loadouts behind a paywall. In recent months they've began running tournaments which make it possible to earn their premium currency and time without spending money. But you'll be grinding for a long time to catch up on all the mechs they've released since.

MWO is not a pay to win game
date: but its definitely pay to skip the grind. It can be unfriendly to new players with a steep learning curve (Tutorial has helped somewhat)
hoursPlayed: and combination of unfriendly game mechanics. To master a mech you will need to own three variants of it
voteText: which means you will need to do your research if you don't want to waste your initial cadet bonus C-bills on a mech that you'll abandon down the road. It will also take a fair amount of games in each chassis to reach your maximum potential. Even just maxing out your favorite mech of each weight class will be a large undertaking without shelling out money for a mech with Cbill or Exp boosts and premium time. While not mandatory

votesHelpful: they are typically slow to react to the players or occasional controversy such as the backlash surrounding the infamous $500 golden mechs. Their actions

votesFunny: and those that are upset with the direction the game has taken and that it doesn't stay true to previous incarnations of the series. At least within the vocal minority

reviewText:
After logging in about 120 hours in a little under 2 weeks, I think I can safely say I am addicted to this game.

Being a long-time fan of BattleTech and MechWarior games in the past, I was very excited when I found out about this game a few years back. I tried it then, but it failed to catch my interest. I think this was mostly due to the lack of classic mechs from those earlier games, mechs like the: Marauder, Archer, Crusader, Phoenix Hawk, Locust, Wasp, Stinger, Rifleman, and WarHammer.

Here we are a few years later and I decide to give it another chance when I see it become available on Steam. The game play is fun and the graphics are really good. There are strategic and tactical elements to the game. There are advancements for both the pilot and the mechs. Between the large variety of chassis and the numerous variations of each chassis, plus the ability to customize your builds and looks, there are a huge number of options available.

The one major thing that this game has done to capture my interest this time around is to include classic mechs from the early days of BattleTech. The Locust and Marauder are already in the game. The WarHammer, Rifleman and Archer are all on the release schedule with confirmed delivery dates. I still hope to see other classics like the Phoenix Hawk, Crusader, Wasp and Stinger eventually, but at least they now have some of the most important classic mechs available in the game.

There is a lot to grind in this game, but that is a good thing. It means you will have plenty of work to keep you motivated for the long haul. You have the option to grind any mech you want in whatever order you want. Nothing is time-gated or level-gated. If you want to pilot an Assault mech from the start you have that option without having to work your way through Light, Medium and Heavy mechs first. The boosters and bonuses you receive during your first 25 missions are more than enough to help any new player get into whatever mech they are interested in. The company also seems to do a lot of promotions offering free in-game currency and gear. I come from War Thunder, where it took me over a year of playing to unlock top tier aircraft and max out aircrews in just one of five countries. The grind in this game seems like nothing compared to that. At least with MWO you have access to everything right from the beginning.

MWO is a free to play game, but like with other such games, they do need a source of revenue. They earn this by selling early access to new content, cosmetic options, subscription time, etc. None of that is mandatory. The early access to new content is for things like new mechs, which everybody gets access to eventually anyways. The cosmetic options are nice to have, but are completely optional, and they let you earn some options during events. The subscription options are actually very beneficial if you are at all bothered by The Grind"

reviewText:
This is a great game (if you want something different than any other FPS right now)

(1000 hours on this game pre-steam release)

MWO is a strange thing for sure. Will you like it? Well it really depends on what you expect from a FPS.
In here, you will not run like a headless chicken (except if you drive Locusts), you will not instantly kill your opponent with a lucky (or skilled) headshot, you will not respawn, you will not magically heal the damages you took during the fight.
You will take care of your team mates, you will run for cover under heavy missiles fire, you will sacrifice part of your Mech just to shield your engine while charging, and you will unleash the power of 20 tons of weapons (or more) against giant walking tanks.


Pros:
- Mech building: before you fight, you have to build your Mech. You choose its weapons, its engine, how much armor it has for each part, how much ammunitions, electronics... The Mechlab is a place where you are gonna spend a lot of time, as it determines a  lot of what you will be able to do in a game, but you'll spend Good time on it.
- Simulation feelings: you are in a huge machine of death, but not a fast Japanese Meka. You're heavy, slow, and the controls feel that way. You have to plan your movements because you can't turn back in the blink of an eye if enemies show up. Then again, you are just driving some kind of a giant tank with arms and legs, so it's not that hard to master.
- Unique combat style: in MWO, you can shoot with lots of weapons, on the same Mech, all at once... The only thing restraining you from non stop fire is the heat your weapons generate when fired. You have to manage this heat so you don't shutdown from overheating (which means standing still while your Mech cools off - a bad thing). You also have one life per drop, and no healing. Your Mech will lose some parts during a game, and learning how to spread damages as the fight goes on is a key component of being good at MWO.
- Beautifull visuals: the Mechs are amazing, all of them. Of course, you will love some and hate some, but the redesign are all incredible. Why re"design? Because next point:
- A 30 years old universe: yup it's an old license
hoursPlayed: long stories for every factions and clans.\n- Continuous development: there is a full team of developers on this game and you can see it. 2 updates per month since  3 years is pretty awesome

reviewText:
Some background:  I'm a backer of this game, huge fan of Battletech and long time mechwarrior fan.  This game could have been so much more than it is and to make matters worse, the devs have largely lost the trust of the community.  So much so that very very few people were willing to fund their followup game(known as transverse).

But lets get to the positives:

-The art design of the mechs is pretty nice.  Alex Iglesias nails the concept art.
-Its the only mechwarrior you're going to get that isn't ancient in game industry terms.
-Lots of mechs and variants to choose from and even more to customize.
-Good controls for the most part despite the defaults being goofy.  Check the options menu.
-Community Warfare features are starting to turn into a fairly appealing mode.
-The clan equipment sound design is top notch.  I wish the IS stuff sounded as nice.


And then the negatives:
-The weapon balance is awful and so many little jury rigged fixes have been placed on the system to fix" the problem.  PGI's gameplay design team is horrid at math and has been since beta.
-The game is growing more and more poorly optimized and it stutters on systems that used to run it silky smooth with nothing to show for it.  NVidia cards can have serious problems despite the made for nvidia intro vid advert.
-The player base has largely been chased off by false promises and bad ideas so there aren't a lot of people playing the community warfare.
-The game is buggy enough to be frustrating.
-The community mildly toxic but not the worst.
-Clan tech is implemented as though its 1:1 with IS tech and you'll be matched against it as such.
-All these assets and no mechwarrior single player campaign...
-The mechs are horridly out of proportion.  This makes the speed of the mechs feel extra sluggish since you're closer to 20 meters up rather than 12.  Additionally
date: some mechs are punished a lot more by their size.  The Centurion
hoursPlayed: is heavy/assault sized despite being half the weight of the Atlas.  Mechs should be in the 8-12 meter range not 6-20 meters.  That range is insane.\n\nHopefully you enjoy the game.  I grow quickly frustrated with the choices the design team makes.  Give the game a shot though
