reviewText:
Full disclosure, I'm a founder that's been playing since closed beta.

Even if you ignore all the controversey including PGI selling a bill of goods and then pulling a bait & switch, most of which is detailed in this article http://www.gamefront.com/mechwarrior-online-forum-ragesplosion/

-addition of real money consumeables(buying power)
-addition of 3rd Person View allowing players to peek over ridges
-addition of ghost heat limiting viable builds that are already limited by a chassis weight class, number of critical slots, number of hardpoints and their locations to discourage laser/PPC boating due totheir pinpoint accuracy. Resulting in players being cored within seconds of a match. This resulted in lasers and PPC's being suboptimal as they were never buffed after the devs limited how many could be viably equipped relegating them to supplementary weapons because of high heat output, delay between shots on standard lasers or reduced range on pulse lasers.

it doesn't change that the game itself isn't for casual Battletech fans. Especially with mech pack pre-orders in the hundreds of dollars that are withheld as timed exclusives until an arbitrary date after they are released. 'Whales' are willing to pay which is why the pricing structure hasn't changed since the beta.

Virtually everything in the game besides non-hero mechs carry a premium real money price in the form of MC(MechCredits), including literally paint, none of which can be unlocked over time via the in-game currency you accumulate through normal play(c-bills).

One of the biggest problems is the mechbay gating system. Each mech you own artbitrarily requires an available corresponding mechbay. If you have 10 mechbays and 10 mechs, you cannot unlock an additional mech until you either sell at a loss that you've already spent time leveling up, or you purchase an additional mechbay which can also only be purchased with MC. Effectively, you will always be spending money on the game. It fails as an F2P title because you cannot unlock using time as a currency by simply grinding out enough in-game currency through nomral play.

TL:DR

Bottomline, I love Mechwarrior, I've been a fan since the 90's. Even in MWO I love tweaking the mechs, the combat is fun even with the flaws and I like being able setup various weapon groups to control which weapons fire independently of others. It's been proposed in the past that they offer a VIP system where once you've spent a combined minimum total on the game, you would unlock VIP status that would remove the Mechbay system and give you a permanent XP/C-bill bonus and maybe even a permanent 10-15% discount on premium items that would stack with sales promotions, if not also unlock the all the paints. I would gladly spend another $50 or $60 on the game if it granted those benefits. Sadly, however, I cannot recommend the game in its current incarnation. Hopefully we will eventually get a proper Mechwarrior 5.

reviewText:
tl;dr it's fun to play, and it's a good team game
protip if your just starting: give every weight class a shot, they play so fundamentally different

I played this a bit in beta when it was still just lance vs lance (squad v squad) battles, not that great, so I figured I'd let it run and run and if it was still around in a few years strong I'd give it a shot. Now that they've made their release on steam I figured it'd be a good time to jump in finally.

I haven't had this much fun in awhile. I've been digging in and I love the gameplay of this game. I hear bad things about the development overtime, bad decisions that have been made. The interface is lackluster. There's terrible community implimentation. You can't even view a 'recent played with' list to find new friends.

All that being said, this game has depth and it's fun.
voteText: 82 of 144 people (57%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I thought it might be some pay-to-win nightmare wearing the skin of a legend, but thankfully it isn't. Paying for *anything*, or not paying for anything, won't make any difference to your capacity to win (or lose) at this game.

You don't even need to buy things with the in-game C-Bills you accumulate for simple match participation, as a rotation of community-designed mechs of all classes is available for free play anytime!

You can even win the normally paid-for currency in events; I've been playing this for one week, and in this time an event has been launched which will last for 10 days where you can win all kinds of unique or normally paid-for stuff.

Well done Piranha, well done.

Now if you can only integrate the Steam market so people could trade bits of kit, mechs, camo's, etc. this might be the only game I'd ever play.

reviewText:
So many mechs!

My background:  I haven't played tabletop, nor a huge Battletech fan.  I have played previous titles.  I don't normally play Shooters.  That said, here is an honest review...

PROS:
*Maps look great (graphics tend to the more real" feel)
*Good tutorial (Mechwarrior Academy)
*Can run around solo on the multiplayer maps in Trainings Grounds
*Almost unlimited configuations (once you can afford to buy mechs)
*Earning in-game currency is easy at first
*Mechs look amazing and there are plenty
*Lots of weapons to choose from
*Map voting
*VOIP
*Slower
date:
more time to think than a Shooter
*Simulation feel of being in the cockpit of a giant mech (has both 1st and 3rd Person available views)
*Community Warfare shows initial signs of being a cornerstone of the Great Houses/Clans conflict
*Matchmaker seems to generally do ok pairing players together
*Excellent sound effects for weapons
*3 Quick Play game modes plus Faction Play

CONS:
*Navigating the UI can be a challenge.
*Steep learning curve (previous titles in the franchise were just as difficult)
*Only trial mechs to start out with
*No tutorial on how to build a decent mech
*Game mechanics seem complicated
*No respawn (although limited in Faction Play)
*No matchmaking in Faction Play
*Game modes seem similar
*Minimal destrucible environment

reviewText:
I have to admit I rage quit this game before it came to Steam, it was over LRMs.
I even complained about LRMs in Steam forums.
But I thought I would give it another shot. But before I did I research the game more and developed a better idea on how to play.
Once I got back into my old account I was given a crap ton of C-Bills and some achievements so that was a good start.
I owned 3 Hunchbacks because I like Hunchback and I decided to trick one out with a build I found online.
I developed a long term plan and have been sticking with it.
I die alot but I got all my Hunchbacks to elite and I am making my way to Master, that was the plan.
I have yet to get any in game currency and don't own any special mechs.
I have to say the game is better this time around.
I die alot, I get blasted by LRMs, I am certainly not THEB33F but I also kick some ♥♥♥ from time to time and have fun.

If you are looking to play for a weekend and have all the stuff then this isnt the game for you. if you get frustrated in games you can't lone wolf to get all the kills then this isnt the game for you. You have to take the good with the bad.
Don't take MWO to seriously, have a plan on what you want to accomplish, do your research on how to play and you will find a great lobby shooter that stays exciting.

reviewText:
Giant Mechs shooting eachother and plenty of cover to make your 20 ton Locust effective at hit-and-run sweeps against a 100 ton Atlas.

One match I was deployed in a Locust (smallest mech) and I was up against an Atlas (one of the largest mechs).  We found ourselves facing off as the last two alive.  Effective use of cover and a lot of running happened.  In the end, I took the Atlas down.

The learning curve can be steep but keep in mind it's free to play.  The mechs which require real money to buy aren't any better than other mechs but simply offer unique loadouts and paint schemes.  Additionally, all the pre-order mechs that you can purchase will eventually be available for the free in-game currency.  The camo specs, and paint colors that you have to purchase currency for can typically be picked up during the frequent weekend-based events by participating.  In short, this is a fun game.

Get teamspeak and play with friends.
voteText: 42 of 72 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have played every Mechwarrior game since MW2 and this is the best yet. Obviously the graphics are a huge step up, but Faction Warfare also makes the universe really come alive, especially now that there is a parallel Scouting mode. The Quick Play game modes are also very interesting.

Even though this is a free-to-play game, there isn't really a pay-to-win component, and the mech customization is on par with what you would expect from previous MW games. You can really get into details and have a lot of fun with it. And there is a huge range of mechs to choose from which keeps things interesting.

There is still work to do: 1) Faction Warfare needs an endgame, i.e. if Clans capture Terra they should win. 2) Add even more modes to Faction Warfare 3) Fix queues in Faction Warfare, the waiting is too long, 4) If a planet is completely captured then a new planet should open up for the attackers, 5) More in-game lore, 6) Better documentation for new players, 7) More mech customization options, especially more weapon types.

Those are just my suggestions but on the whole I really, really like this game!

reviewText:
Definitely not without flaw, but still a very fun game to play with friends and teammates.

The community overall is one of the best I have ever experienced from any prior game. Much more mature players than an average shooter. There are the occasional bad eggs, but for the most part those people are not embraced by the community as a whole.

Lots of units to choose from with varying skill levels or focuses. There are various recruitment threads on www.reddit.com/r/OutreachHPG as well as the hiring hall and recruitment forums on mwomercs.com

PGI has been doing a lot better lately making positive changes and working with the community to make the game better. It is difficult the please everybody and they have made quite a few bad balancing decisions in the past, but it seems like they are starting to get more in line with what needs to be done.

Some of the new maps have been focusing more on being pretty and large instead of functional and balanced. The fact that they redid the maps in the first place was a step in the right direction, but I feel like at the time they could have gathered more info from the community as to what needed to be done to make the maps better. They listened to the part where people wanted destructable trees and stuff, but then took it a step further and put so much of it in that it obscures vision. Also the fog needs to GO. Poor visibility does not make things enjoyable. We'll see if the next map the do fixes some of those issues.

The 3rd party competitive scene is solid, and is only getting better as the community grows. PGI has been paying attention to 3rd party leagues and have been supporting them with prizes and coverage. They even had a team made up of their developers in the most recent season of MRBC!

Come play with us!
There is a handy player made starter guide here:
https://www.reddit.com/r/OutreachHPG/comments/3w6ll1/welcome_to_mechwarrior_online_resources_and_faq/

reviewText:
I've played this game off and on since 2012, starting with the Founder's beta.

We'll start with the good things: the core gameplay, is solid and actually works fairly well.  The weapon effects are nice and some of the artwork is very good.    The game has very good sound design and effects.

Now, for the bad: everything else.

It is an arena shooter with long queue times, lousy matchmaking, bad netcode, a terrible community, and terrible balance decisions.  It is extremely grindy, the cash shop packs are insanely overpriced, and development on the game has been virtually non-existent for three years now.   Oh, and the game is extremely buggy.  And I can provide examples.

Let's begin with the queue times.  My average wait to get a solo match in the 'public' arena game queue is usually about three minutes.  My average wait to get a group game (groups have an entirely different queue) in my last play session was over five minutes per match.  The average wait to get a community warfare match during peak hours is typically about fifteen minutes.  Sometimes, after waiting for fifteen minutes, you don't even get a real match, but instead you're forced to grind out turrets for minimal reward.

Let's continue with the matchmaking system, which recently ditched ELO in favor of a 'skill tier' system that is actually just a grind.  If you win a match, your skill rating will improve.  If you lose a match, but displayed more activity than a moldy potato, your skill rating will improve.  The game literally rates player skill based on the number of matches someone has played.

The netcode is bad.  You can play the game and see for yourself, if you don't believe me.  However, suffice it to say that it is entirely normal in this game for shots to simply fail to register on the target at all, or for other weird things to happen, such as taking fire from the front and noticing that the damage registered on your back.

---

The game is badly balanced, because the designers of the game do not understand their own game.  With every other game update, certain mechs and/or weapon systems will go from being completely worthless to utterly overpowered, and there is absolutely no rhyme or reason to how, when, or why this will happen.  Actually, I take that back; I do know why balance changes happen.  When the lead game designer actually deigns to wade in and play his own game, he is typically embarrassed on account of being awful and not understanding what's going on.  But rest assured, that he will nerf the hell out of whatever killed him, because clearly that must be overpowered.  For instance, look up Goons Heart Paul" on Youtube and then consider that the mech knockdown mechanic was COMPLETELY REMOVED FROM THE GAME FOREVER in the patch immediately after that video was recorded.

Oh
date: and there are also two different levels of technology in the game.  Inner Sphere (IS) technology
recommended: and the more advanced Clan technology.  Clan mechs are faster
hoursPlayed: more durable

that's because they're better!

---

When I say the game is grindy

which is ultimately necessary to be on even footing with veteran players.

---

Development on this game has been dead pretty much since release.  I don't think I need to go into fiascoes such as Transverse (when the developers decided to abandon development of MWO in order to try to kickstart a Star Citizen ripoff) or the $500.00 gold mechs (Google it)

reviewText:
I recommend this game if you're a fan of MechWarrior or if you're looking for something unique amongst the F2P catalogue.

MechWarrior Online is definately a game worth trying simply because it is free. But be warned: the game is very grindy and difficult. Matches will seem unfair to someone new. This game is slow paced, which is different from other shooters.

This game is also very niche. Even if the game was perfect, most will not like it because it's only fun for certain people.

The main issue this game faces is the grindy nature of the game. You will spend a lot of time playing to get the end game stuff, which is acceptable. However, you have to specialize in a mech (buying three varients of the same mech) in order to get high-level masteries." If you make the wrong choice

reviewText:
I've played MWO for a bit over a year now, and it's the only game I've consistently come back to in that time. I really loved MW2 experience and seeing the mech lab for the first time and customizing my mechs really brought those feelings back. Then dropping into a match and unleashing destruction upon the enemy is extremely satisfying and cathartic. Good play is often rewarded and you can really see your tactics help. There are rolls from both sides, but there are the games that both teams had something great going for them and it gets down to one or two mechs left dueling it out. Those are such great moments that really keep your on the edge of your seat, especially while spectating after having dropped earlier in the match.

The faction play is fun, but still has room to grow. There will be a 3rd phase update soon that will hopefully add a lot to the game mode. The faction play is a bit difficult and higher skill level than the normal solo queue or group queue. I highly recommend new players tough it out in those queues before attempting the face-rolling potential of faction warfare.

This game definitely has my support and I'll still be playing it for years in the future, I think. This is one of those games that I'll constantly come back to. That list of those games is short, but there was definitely a FPS Mech shaped hole in that lineup that this game fills.

reviewText:
Borderline ok game brought down by a bad monetization scheme. 4/10


Cons: Game paywalls you early on to buy mechbays. Other issues are poor balance and quality of maps. Good teamplay is vital to winning but commander interface is poorly implemented. Game has a beta level of quality with slow developement and a plethora of long lasting bugs. Some maps are more finished than others. Official support is nearly nonexistant. Grind is tough on normal players. Hard to tell game has been out for over 3 years. Game can be very expensive if you choose to buy into it.

Pros: Good concept art. Good graphics at times. Mechs and weapon effects look nice. Easy to understand controls. Fun and established lore. Lots of seasonal content. Fills stompy robot niche. Short matches.

reviewText:
Overall Rating: 8.5 / 10

DISCLAIMER: Please do not be fooled by my amount of time played on Steam. I have been playing this game since Beta 2012, so I assure you I have many, many hours logged on this game. More hours logged then all other games I own combined for that matter!

Review:

This is an excellent game with great potential and a bright future ahead! I recommend this game for anyone looking for more tactical gameplay in their FPS gaming.

Last year, the devs introduced Community Warfar, a gamemode targeted at hardcore players with an entire star map and several factions to fight for. If you decide to give this game a shot, I recommend shying away from this gamemode for the first while until you get a grasp of the main concepts of combat roles and loadouts, and decide this is a game you want to continue with. If you make it to ComWar, you will enjoy increased rewards, frequent events, and the final end-all Battle for Tukayyid Tournament to end each season of ComWar. ComWar is currently in Beta II, with Beta III just around the corner. In Beta III, players will be able to choose from several unique Career paths, vote on planets to attack, pool C-bills for tactical bonuses & ordinance (TACTICAL NUKE CONFIRMED), and perform either full out planetary Assault or planetary Scouting missions to collect intel for additional bonuses.

The devs are continuously pumping out new content in the form of Battlemechs, Camo, (coming soon) Decals and Maps. They are also dedicated to perfecting player balance as much as possible, so one can expect one or two updates to gameplay mechanics every month, on top of new content updates.

MechWarrior Online got off to a rough start in 2012. Whether you talk to the haters or the lovers, everyone can admit this fact. This was largely due to the now defunct company Infinite Games Publishing (IGP) and its control over the project. The good news is that since its departure, progress on this game has been swift and positive. The game's 'mech concepts are lauded as one of its strongest points, with much of the beautiful 'mech designs now slated for use in the upcoming turn-strategy game Battletech (if you don't know about this game, also worth a look! www.battletechgame.com).

The game's UI has been improved frequently, but new players will still have some difficulty navigating some tabs. Notably, new players may struggle with customizing loadouts. My best recommendation for this is to visit the game's forums (mwomercs.com/forums/) and get advice from the playerbase, most of whom are very helpful.

The game's Tutorial zone has been revamped recently! All new players should visit this zone first, because this is not a game that you can simply skip the tutorial unless you are a returning player (the tutorial even has in-game rewards for completing challenges). As a veteran player, I still use this zone to practice with new 'mechs.

Some may get turned off buy the game's MC currency (money purchasable currency) that allows players to skip a lot of the grind and get the good stuff. While this game may seem Pay-To-Win, this is certainly not the case, as virtually all chassis, weapons, equipment and upgrades are purchasable with C-bills (gameplay generated/earned currency). The only things unobtainable without MC are vanity items & a select group of 'Hero' mechs that come with unique camo patterns and weapon hardpoints (which are arguably no better or worse in performance when compared to their standard counterpart). Also purchaseable with MC-only are designated 'Champion' 'mechs, but do not be fooled! These mechs are simply optimized versions of standard C-bill purchasable mechs, they do not differ at all in performance potential!

In summary, this is a great tactical shooter with very unique gameplay concepts. As such, the learning curve can be rather steep for some, and there are still a few rough spots that require development. The future of this game is bright, however, with constant updates and some really exciting new content lined up for spring. In the words of the game's devs, they are far from finished" with this game!"

reviewText:
Its quite simply the best stompy robot game out there, and its the first game of the Franchise for years, that isn't homebrew, if you like Battletech, Mechwarrior, or  just shooting stuff with Lasers piloting a big ♥♥♥♥♥ robot, then you should try this game.

Its not a fast paced game, unless you play a light, but that doesn't mean it takes little skill, you have to be aware of your surroundings, and work as a team, Rambo's that think individual skill will win all before them, are going to be the scrub that fails, as TTK is high when your focus fired on, and there is a high learning curve, unless you are an exceptional gamer, you are not going to master this game in a week, or even a month, for many players, but people that genuinely desire a challenge, should take to this game.

Now the negative first for old time Battletech,Mechwarrior fans, last paragraph more general.

Its the least like the franchise that has been produced, though it looks visually great, there are only mechs no support troops of aircraft, P.G.I decided that they couldn't produce a match maker that has uneven numbers in teams, so clan tech will not be recognised as anything like as powerful as it is in Lore, athema for clan fans, myself I never liked the OP bestest mechs that brought totalbalance fail, so I'm fine with it.

Customisation is also a balance issue, though hundreds disagree. None of the load outs will look anything like the Canon mech's which is pretty sad, if you are a real hard core fan of the old lore. Very few close to Canon builds  work in comparrison to what you can  built with the custom system, its sad to see Warhammers, and Marauders, handing in their AC5's SRM's and of couse PPC's, for laser and more lasers.  or warhammers with twin AC20's where the Machine guns went.

This is I'm afraid from my point of view the big negative, even ignoring the lore and the canon builds, the game has lots of weapon systems but  various  hit detection issues and the use of HSR has made many weapons nonviable and turned the game into a lasers with everything meta, because they are hitscan and can have the beam corrected, as opposed to point of impact damage which can be ducked more easily,  and at times miss because  hit dection is out, so a PPC is a rare sight on Mechwarrior online, and that says a lot, because if there was an Iconic weapon in  the lore it  is the Partical Projection Canon, but sadly  the Laser Aces it in every way.

reviewText:
As a long time Battletech / Mechwarrior fan I've been one of the suckers who bought the super expensive Legendary founder package and Phoenix package. I've played MWO since closed beta, stopped playing some time ago. On the PLUS side I have to admit the game looks nice and is mostly fun to play.

On the other hand the game and its developers have also disappointed severely, never really delivering on the promises. Development is slow and new release sometimes introduced more bugs than it solved. Wild changes in mechanics or effectivenes of individual weapons happened every few months, rendering previously successfull mechs useless. It felt that devs never really listened to the community. The contents (mech packs, camo paints) are incredibly expensive. Progression is non-existent, there is not much to aspire to. It is just a brutal grind to earn XP for one mech, then for another variant of the same chassis, and for the next one......... or grind to earn credits to buy the next chassis.

And let's not forget MWLL - the free Mechwarrior-like game that was at least as good as MWO and had to be killed to make room for MWO.

reviewText:
Its a good game. Feels like a slowed down version of Armored core with a harder lock on system.

That said, this game feels more achin to chess then to Armored Core. You will die from the pawns as a queen, knight, rook whatever, if you are in the wrong spot. Through trial and error or success you'll learn where risky places are and where safe ones are and how to pander to bad situations or simply to know when you've been outclassed. You WILL be outclassed, some people are simply better. Good news is, its not about how quickly you can sight cross hairs on someones head from 100 meters (although you if you get good at that in this game you will wreck) its about awareness and team cohesion.

The mechs DO look amazing, all the hype about the models is real. They look amazing.

THe maps are.... interesting. They range from super long range, to super short range, but there is no way to say whether as a short range mech, you get the map you want. I feel that not all the maps have somewhere where every play style shines. I look to TF2 for map design, and feel they did very well. There are tight corners, little nooks, long corridors, hoppable outcrops and cover smattering everywhere; all things, that each seperate class looks for to allow them an advantage. Not quite so in this. Pretty much it plays similarly to real life. Life occasionally hands you lemons and you need to deal with it.

THe rewards system i would like to see buffed, but as it is, being a heavy brawly mech is the best way to get C-bills *in game currency*

It is NOT pay to win. Eventually, everything that you can pay for with $$$ you can also pay for with C-bills. *with some exceptions* eg. hero mechs. (which don't break the game, just another variant of existing mechs)

I recommend this game. Its a solid title that will scratch the mech-customization-fps itch some people may have. Its not the best, but as far as mech games on a PC goes,  its brilliant.

reviewText:
MWO has come a long way from where it was when I started playing it in January of 2015. PGI has made great strides at improving MWO.

Now how is the game itself now? Pretty darn good. The game is easier to get into than say World of Tanks or WarThunder as everyone has access to to pretty much everything from the start. With the playingfield far more level you also do not get oneshotted as easily making MWO far more forgiving to the new player.

When trying to learn MWO do the tutorial, do the optional parts of the tutorial not just for the bonus Cbills but also to get a better idea of how mechs handle. Learn how each weapon system handles, look up some guides, and if you are in doubt, suck up the high price tag of clan mechs and get one with your cadet bonus. Trust me it is worth it, use it to learn how heat works, how to torso twist, get yourself a Hunchback, Stormcrow or Timberwolf and go to town.

Seriously go grab a Stormcrow it is one of the most forgiving medium mechs in the game. If you want to get an Inner Sphere mech? Hunchback, any of them, but, best would be the one with the AC/10 which is the Hunchback HBK-4H. The Hunchback and Stormcrow are very, very forgiving and flexible mechs. Also everyone wants to pilot a heavy mech as well, so a medium mech will help with queue times.

Another advantage of grabbing a clan mech first is that when building your mech you have far less things that you can do wrong, like under-engining your mech and making you an easy target. Get to also know what the various upgrades do for your mechs, get to know how much ammo you use.

Reading guides on the meta is a good idea, it will give you an idea of what you will be fighting, it will also give you an idea of the weaknesses of each weapon system is and strengths. You do not, and I stress this, and should not blindly follow the meta, learn why the meta is the way it is so you can tune your mechs to capitalize on how the game works.

Most of all, find what you enjoy to run in your mechs and run it. Also don't forget to find some friends, look up the faction team speak servers and do group queue drops. Trust me, working with friends or just communicating in general will do more for your match score, cbills, and exp gains than any metamech build.

Before getting into Faction play, otherwise known as Community Warfare you should get a good grasp of how your mechs work and get four of them that add up to 240 tons. Make certain they are all basiced.

MechWarrior's, I look foward to meeting you as friend and foe on the battlefield.

reviewText:
A word from a Legendary founder who crowd-funded the start of this, and a veteran of Closed/Open beta.
This game has a steep learning curve, but does not restrict you to underperforming mechs like War Thunder does with its tier system.
The grind is as expected of a F2P title, plus there is no glimmer of P2W, most complains about P2W come from players who just end up running into freshly relesed mech piloted by veterans.
A word on the mech packs, they first sell them as preorders(mostly), after release they are locked only to the people who preordered them, after some time they can be bought for MC(like golden eagles in WT, or RP in LoL), then some time after that they are released for c-bills( your ingame monopoly money). So there is no mech chassis that is permanently locked behind a paywall.
Play the game for yourself and form your own opinion on it.
Good luck mechwarriors.

reviewText:
I have been playing MechWarrior Online since closed beta (summer 2012) and have to say that this is one of the most gratifying and addictive games... once you climb the learning curve. The gameplay is unique in that you can customize your 'Mechs with a very wide variety of weapons. There are no re-spawns in 2 of the 3 game modes, which forces you to play smart rather than run and gun, like most FPS games. It can be frustrating to die in the first few minutes of a game (solo and group queue matches are a maximum 15 minutes, but usually average about 10 minutes, while Community Warfare matches typically last 20-30 mins).

If you are an FPS gamer, you will appreciate the higher level of tactical play and it rewards good aim and movement. In fact, the component/hitbox design of the 'Mechs really rewards players who have precision aiming. Headshots (cockpit kills) are extremely difficult, but highly satisfying in this game... more so than any other FPS I have played.

There are 4 weight classes of'Mechs, ranging from Light through to Assault, and offer you different roles to play within a team and changes your playstyle. Some people specialize in one or 2 roles/weight classes because it suits their playstyle and others are flex players who like variety.

Team Damage: Yes, it is a real thing and it is annoying as hell to be on the receiving end from trolls (which are few and far between, I might add). Thankfully, you can monitor your team damage at the end of round info screen. Do keep your firing lanes clear and apologize to your teammates if you accidentally shoot them in the back (where there is MUCH less armour and can destroy weapons or even kill them in one full volley of your weapons if placed in one spot). If you are tabbed out of the game and click back in with your mouse, you will fire your weapons, so please alt-tab back into the game instead.

Interface: The out of game user interface in the game has changed a lot over the past couple of years and it still isn't perfect, but it MUCH better than older ones. The lack of customizable UI is understandable, due to the sheer volume of parts that make up the info needed and it still can't all fit on one screen. This is a game that is very complex when played to its fullest potential, yet offers instant action once you become familiar with the ideal builds for each 'Mech. Expect to spend a lot of time initially tinkering with Mechs and unlocking skills and items (modules that enhance your weapons, movement or ability to gather info). The in-game interface is pretty cool and has recently introducted additional info within the cockpit (you can also play in 3rd person view, but it highly affects your aiming for precision shots and people can see you are in 3PV because a drone flies above your Mech... you may get a bit flamed for it, as it can also be a visual cheat due to terrain design).

Team-Play/Communications: As with any team-based game, you are highly recommended to find a unit and utilize voice comms, but you can play strictly in the solo queue to build your experience, level up your 'Mechs (skill trees take about 30-40 matches to complete for one Mech chassis), or experiment with different weapon loadouts and heat management. Voice comms are available in game, but not used by everyone. You can mute annoying players quite easily. Clans, House Units or Merc Units (aka guilds) are constantly looking for players and have their tag displayed in game next to their name. If you start to see players with a given tag and like your cohesion (and win rate!) with them, I advise you find out their voice comms info and play with them in a group. Just request to join them in chat or add them as a friend and use the in-game messaging feature.

Heat?: Ah yes, heat management... this is a layer of complexity that requires you to really be aware of your heat production caused by weapon use and movement. Learning to squeeze out the most of your Mech takes a lot of time and understanding, but there are some great community resources out there. You eventually can do it by feel, but there are visual and audio cues to help. Overheating causes damage to your internals and you can even blow yourself up by riding in the red too long. In those last ditch attempts to squeeze off a final kill, you can choose to override your auto shutdown when past 100%, but do so wisely! Suiciding due to overheat can still reward the kill to a player shooting at you.

Community: there are always toxic players or trolls, but you will find an overall very nurturing community. The game is no doubt a niche game, but has a very, very loyal following with some very big whales who love the BattleTech universe. There is no other multiplayer game on the market quite like this one and it induces a lot of passion within the MWO forums and MWO sub-reddits.

eSports: There is a budding attempt to turn MWO into an eSport with a $100K prize pool world tournament starting in Q1 2016. Those in the competitive-minded community hope that enough new players with great skills enter MWO to spawn new teams or revive some old ones that have felt that the competitive scene is stale. Most competitive play is accomplished via community-run leagues (MRBC, RHoD, and a few 8/12/16 team invitationals). The publisher did host one official beta tournament, which brought out a lot of new names to the competitive scene and we hope that will be the case in the near future with the influx of new players from Steam.

Pay Model: The game is F2P and used to be very limited in this regard, but has opened up widely since Community Warfare started. Initially you begin with 4 Mech Bays. You had to buy additional ones in the past, but now you can earn them through in-game rewards and special events. There are some Hero and Champion Mechs that are only purchasable with real money (MC), but they are not mandatory to buy. They do offer enhanced XP or C-Bill (in-game currency) bonuses, so it can be a good way to farm cash to buy additional 'Mechs. As with most F2P games, you will end up paying more for this game than a retail box model should you get into it... and there is nothing wrong with that at all! Mech Packs are pricey, but it is more of a pay to early access feature rather than a Pay 2 Play/Win model. There are only a few Hero Mechs that you may want to buy should you wish to get into competitive play. Wait for paid items to go on sale at 50% off to get the best value, which happens often.

Matchmaking: There are 5 skill tiers and that is how the base matchmaker tries to pair up players. Sometimes you will be matched with players a tier higher or lower, but the idea is that both sides are matched as evenly as possible. There are also weight and chassis limits per side, so as to maintain some degree of balance of teams. The past saw some issues with queue times due to lower populations, which has been less of an issue since Steam release. However, the Community Warfare (CW) mode still suffers from a lack of popluation due to lack of real incentives to play that game mode vs time per match. We hope that an increased CW population will reduce the wait times and increases the potential of this game mode. More on CW below.

End Game: Community Warfare is the persistent universe game mode and is not based on any matchmaking at all, but a specific weight tolerance of the 4 Mechs you can bring to each match. Yes, this is the only game mode where you have respawns, but you still need to use each Mech wisely, as matches are more prolonged with different phases to the fight. There is a defense and an offense mode to each map and new game modes are going to be introduced to increase playability of CW during off-peak times. Here is where you can unlock in-game rewards and also earn MC, the real money currency that can unlock more Mech Bays (character slots, per say), cosmetic items, or even Champion or Hero Mechs, if you grind it out.

reviewText:
Its quite clunky, especially the graphics/physics, but overall i enjoy this game,
and even decided that its worth spending money on it.

The damage/weapon-system is interesting and the battletech universe in which MWO plays is rich in lore and there are over 100 novels since the 80s. The balancing was not good the last years since its release as far as i uncovered (there are 2 sides Clan and Inner Sphere which battle each other with different levels of technology), but there was a recent patch in December which seemed to turn everything to the better. I started late December so i cant tell the difference. :)

The game is not overcrowded in CW and its not adviseable to join those as a random because you will get stomped 9 out of 10 matches by highly organised and trained units, but its easy to get into solo battles and pew pew away.
If you want to do more team oriented stuff like CW or the soon to be introduced 4vs4, join a unit.

There is a skill-matchmaking in place, which has 5 levels.
You start with 5, and you can be matched with ppl that are 2 levels up or down.
This just grants you to make the first steps in peace, after like 70 hours you come to level 3 and can be matched against the best.

If you want to play in the long run, you need at least premium time if you want to get new mechs regularly,
but unlike WoT you can buy any mech you want immediately and level it.

Its not so easy to get to know the game, since the factions mechs have differences with Omnipod and Quirksystems and the weapons are very different, but if you just use google and read the MWO guide for beginners and the comics, you should be fine to start.

If you like vehicle combat, just give it a try.

reviewText: I played this way back in the beta, but didn't have much time to dive in and learn everything. When it came to steam I decided to give another try and actually dive in and learn the game. reviewText:
This is great example of a game that should have been a classic, but instead is merely mediocre.

The graphics and sound are decent, and it is a good foundation on which a great game could have been built, but wasn't. Essentially the game is just an arena combat game using mechs  - there is a Community Warfare mode which seems very unpopular, but really the game is just deathmatch.

Having played on and off since the original Beta, I can't help but feel that if the developers had put a little more effort into fleshing the game out with a bit more depth and variety it could have been so much more. Essentially the game we have now is little more than the core functionality upon which a game world could have been constructed. Calling it an MMO in its current form is pretty funny really, as there's only the skimpiest of metagames or player interaction.

This would be fine for a simple FTP game, but as the inheritor of one of Sci-Fi's finest (if cheesiest) franchises, and bearing in mind the frankly incredible amounts of real money demanded for Mechs, it's just not enough. In addition the rich lore and background of the Battletech universe has been largely ignored or contradicted when large parts of it could have been exploited much more cleverly.

In my view the IP should never have been given to these developers (or indeed their even shadier former publishers) and I'm afraid it seems that they just weren't up to the job of turning out a solid game that's worth the money that so many have already spent on it.

reviewText:
TL DR = try it, it is loads of fun and not payment required to experience 99% of what it has to offer.  Giant mechs battling eachother with lasers, cannons, and missiles.  Nothing like Hawken or any other mech game out there, it stands in a class of its own as far as I'm concerned.  If you liked the older Mechwarrior games then certainly give this a try.

___

Have been here since the closed beta of this game back in 2012,.  Been playing fairly consistently ever since but I'm not a 7 days a week guy.

Aside from Dark Souls games this is my favourite game.  Giant stomping mechs blowing up eachother.  This game is not perfect, but no game is (except Dark Souls :D).  But it is in my opinion an excellent game.

Most important thing would be the game play, it is great.  12 vs 12 teams of giant mechs throwing missiles and lasers at eachother.  Not much else needs to be said.

It can be tough to learn but once you get the hang of it it is very satisfying.  To help with that they have made it so brand new players won't get matched against the elites, with a tiered system.

New players get a whack of bonus money in their first bunch of matches, and also some more for completing the tutorial.  And even more through achievements and stuff so you can get started pretty quick.  There are a variety of trial mechs avaialble at first, so here is a tip, play them all, see which ones you like best before you spend your hard earned new player money, cause if you choose one that you end up not liking, the return for selling it is minimal.  Also do the tutorial, and read some of the player made guides out there.

I would say that the community as a whole is very welcoming, in every game you have jerks and trolls but for the most part people are happy to help out or answer questions or let you play with them etc etc.

Lots of different mechs to try out and you can customize them all however you want.

Pricing can be a little high on the real-$$ items if you want them, but PGI does frequent sales so here's a tip, do like I do and wait for things to go on sale before you buy.  Also if you want MC (the currency bought with real $$) they usually have a sale on that a couple times a year so keep an eye open for it.  Personally I enjoyed this game for almost 2 years before I spent anything, and didn't suffer since all the mechs and stuff are all available for free.  Mostly the $$ stuff is cosmetic, or to boost your earnings (premium time) to lessen the grind, which by the way is not bad anyways.  Also they have events all the time where you can get some stuff (paint jobs, colours, etc, even mechs) just by plaing and earning points over a weekend.

No pay to win at all.  There are mechs that are only available for MC (purchased for real $$), with special paintjobs, but none of them are really any better than their non-$$ counterparts.  In fact in many cases they are pretty average or even sub-par, haha.  But, you do get some new interesting loadout options on them, and a 30% cbill bonus (cbills are the free currency used to buy mechs and weapons etc).  Champion mechs are also available for MC, but they are not special chassis (IE, you can get the same ones for free), but they just come with a nice build and an XP bonus.

Community Warfare, the big galactic conquest game mode can be fun, but right now is pretty stale and in need of a revamp (which I believe is coming).  Also, it is not welcoming for new players.. it is designed for the large units of experienced players, so while you may have some good matches, a lot of the time you will get mercilessly passed around for 30 minutes.

Overall this game is a lot of fun if you like the slower pace of giant robots brawling it out.  It has issues for sure but the devs seem to be on a pretty good path now (in the past it was not so much, but since the developers bought out their publisher things have improved greatly.)

Highly recommend at least to give it a shot.  I generally hate free to play games but this is a diamond in the rough I think.

reviewText:
Please note that despite my listed hours played, I've actually been playing since the closed beta.

Pros:
*Huge* catalogue of 'mechs to choose from
Great loadout customization
Some good looking maps
Constant stream of weekend events, and tournaments
Visceral and engaging 'mech combat
Very active development team
Faction Play/Community Warfare
All competitive/meta grade 'Mechs are avaliable for free-player currency.
Mech art design is really quite gorgeous

Neutral:
Sound design is functional
Devs *can* have a problem listening to the community
Unlocking 'Mechbays pretty much requires paying money, or playing every weekend event
Highish investment price, about on equal footing with World of Tanks
Frequent sales on cosmetics and paid 'mechs
'Unique' XP unlock system
Steep learning curve, but an okay tutorial

Cons:
Jarring disconnect between 'old' and 'new' map design philosophies and qualities.
Some 'Mech textures can be downright ugly
Only five gamemodes and 18 maps
Cumbersome frontend UI
Small team can lead to slow fixes, and glacial development speed on some features.
Nickel and diming
Poor optimization leads to a poor performance to fidelity ratio
Some bizzare 'balancing' options come down the pipeline, sometimes.

Conclusion:

It's a great arena shooter, with decent customization depth, but not much to do beyond fighting. Graphics and sound are good. Updates come frequently. The real-money stuff is way too expensive, but anything worth half a damn goes F2P within a couple months anyway. Anything else becomes avaliable for MC, which you can earn for free. The devs can be rather ignorant to the realities of the game's meta, but it kind of, a little bit, maybe seems they're starting to listen to the community, but they could *really* work on that. It's probably worth a download, and some free-play, but keep your wallet closed unless you find you're enjoying yourself.

reviewText:
Closed Beta player, so I have been there from the beginning in 2012. The game has substantially evolved since that time period, from 5 'Mechs and a single map with 8 vs 8 and one game mode (Assault), to 3 Quick Play modes, 2 Faction Play modes, 12 Quick Play maps, 7 Faction Play maps, over 60 'Mech chassis (totalling 300 variants), 12 v 12, and a host of other improvements.
But this review isn't about a chronological list of stuff that happened, you wanna know how the game plays, right?

The new Player Experience is still a little rough. Once you've gone through the MechWarrior Academy (a welcome recent addition), there's no real tutorials on proper teamplay with other players, as well as any information on customizing your own BattleMech. However, the pace that PGI has been going at of late, this stuff may all come soon.
Once you've actually learned basic and advanced tactics, it is a proper BattleMech simulator; your 'Mech has a limited pivoting torso, you have loads of weapons on your 'Mech that can make you overheat if you're not careful, and of course, speed is still life. Assault 'Mechs, the biggest of them all, do indeed struggle with much smaller 'Mechs (such as almost all Light 'Mechs, and the Cicada and Ice Ferret), because of the much slower pace of the lumbering giant compared to the relative agility of the gnats surrounding it. This sort of inherent balance, coupled with different scouting mechanics that feel closer to World of Tanks than previous MechWarrior games (a good thing) already makes this feel more balanced and visceral than those earlier MechWarrior games.
Maps can and do restrict tactics in places, and many  of these maps can also change up the gameplay or make it stale. They're not quite as pretty or realistic as some of today's AAA titles, but I think they're very much sufficient for what they're trying to do, especially for trying to realize BattleTech's universe.
All this and I forgot about the pricing model. 'Mechs are EXPENSIVE when paid for with real money. If you want to build a collection, you will have to fork over a little money for MechWarrior Credits [MC] and buy some bays, and if you're not patient enough to accrue C-Bills (keep in mind that your first 25 matches, you get a major bonus to get you your first couple 'Mechs sooner), you can buy 'Mechs with MC, too. Fortunately, PGI runs sales and events rather regularly, so you may be gifted with some scraps of MC or some free 'Mech Bays, and rarely, even a new 'Mech! Keep an eye on their website for more information!
Give Piranha Games some patience, the greatest has yet to come. They are overhauling Faction Play a bit, and someone's pet project is proper Single Player/Cooperative.

TD;DR: This isn't your father's MechWarrior. It comes with its ups and downs but it is very much worth a play. Just be mindful of your wallet, 'Mechs are not cheap.

reviewText:
MWO is a free to play game based on the Mech Warrior series which is based on BattleTech. The mech combat is good, possibly some of the best in the series' history. I've played the TT and franchise for over 20 years and can safely say that at its core, MWO is true to the premise of piloting a big battlemech.

There is an extremely steep learning curve for new players that is not helped by lack of good documentation explaining some of the more important mechanics. The community is really good at filling in the blanks though and most are more than willing to help new players get acclimated.

The artwork is gorgeous and if you are able to play on higher settings the game really shines. Although a bit dated now, you can see that the artwork is top notch.

It's a very fun game, especially being free and I would reccomend it to anyone looking for a new game. This isn't your typical shooter though, it tends to move at a much slower pace when it comes to combat and it is heavily team oriented. Those that try to take down the enemy team solo ala CoD will find nothing but frustrating losses.

That's not to say it is without issues. The gameplay itself is repetitive and most modes equate to stomp forward and kill them all. There are additions in the pipeline to include new modes that should break up the monotony but if you're the type of gamer than enjoys a lot of diversity in modes such as CtF, KoH, etc. this may not be your cup of tea.

The pathfinding is frustrating, especially when you're stomping along in a 100 ton assault mech and are brought to a complete stop due to a rock" no higher than your mech's ankle.

The mech customization is amazing with literally thousands of mech and weapon combinations. It's one of the few F2P games out there that does a very good job of walking that line without getting into P2W territory.    The developers are very responsive and interactive with their community via Twitter which is exceptionally rare in this industry.

Overall I would give it 3 out of 5 stars (which could easily jump depending on what the company does with the recently released Phase 3 of Community Warfare). It's a free game and within a few hours of playing as a free player you can easily accumulate enough cbills (the free currency) to buy and outfit 2-3 mechs.

reviewText:
MWO is unique in the world of modern games, the F2P model is solid (though I find the prices a little high, you are not forced to buy anything to be competitive).  It's definitely more of a sim than a shooter, heat management and trigger discipline net you more kills than charging in with guns blazing.

A couple things you should know before you drop in:
1. Stay with the team - A solo 'Mech gets scrapped in short order, always.
2. Press 'R' befpre you start shooting at something - Your target lock is shared with all other players on the team, by letting us know what you're shooting, you might get some assistance befor you get scrapped.
3. Trigger Discipline (this is NOT CoD with robots) - As you fire weapons, your 'Mech begins to heat up, keeping an eye on your heat gauge and knowing how much heat your weapons generate per shot is vital to your success.  If you overheat, your 'Mech shuts down until heat levels are within spec again, leaving you an immobile target in the middle of a battlefield.
4. Jump into VoIP!  - MWO is a game that heavily emphasises teamwork, grab a headset and coordinate.  Even if you don't have a strategy, you can call out targets that are too far away to target lock, and you can call for help if you get ambushed.  The difference between winners and losers is coordination.
5. Read up! - MWO has some great guides available to help the new MechWarrior in understanding his place on the battlefield, read some of them (Google is your friend) to get a leg up on the competition.

reviewText:
I've played MWO for 3 years almost nightly.

It had huge potential and fell short.
BUT
Even having fallen short, its is still the best Mechwarrior game available.  (Its potential was out of this world)
What make me say that?  Gameplay.  Customization of your Mechs. Progression. Teamwork means winning or losing, not how much you paid for your Mech.  To become a great team player and mechwarrior there is a bunch you need to know.  Which brings me to my next point.

There's a learning curve.  You'll get your butt kicked for about a month straight until you learn the weapons and the mechs.
But if you stick with it then you'll start getting kills which is where the fun begins.
JOIN A GROUP TO PLAY WITH.  The game is infinitely better when played on voice comms on TS with friends.
Groups will accellerate your learning too as you will be taugh as you play and chat with veterans.

The future of MWO is friendly... now that its done spinning its wheels in the mud.  I'm eager to see what they do with the new Community Warfare, Faction Warfare, and balancing.

On the subject of joining groups.. Why not take a look at our group.  I've not found a reason to drop with anyone else for three years and counting,  The Skye Rangers have a bit for everone in every timezome.  Casual, Competitive, EU, NA?  --->   www.Skye-Rangers.Net

See you on the Battlefield

reviewText:
As a new player I kind of have to wonder where all the bad reviews are coming from. I almost didn't give this game a shot because of them, but when I eventually did there were plenty of powerful mechs to play for free and I didn't do bad at all. You get a nice fat bonus for your first matches and you'll be able to buy one powerful fully up-to-scratch best-level mech for yourself. I reccomend choosing carefully. The grind gets real bad after a while (to the point where a second full-power mech is paid DLC), but at least the game itself is fair. You can always use the free mechs if you don't care about the metagame and just want to walk a hulking mech to shoot people. Plus the unleveled versions of mechs are kinda affordable, and they aren't too much worse than top-level mechs.

The core game is more strategical than most shooters. Because it takes a while to kill someone and you can't easily reposition, the tactics behind your attacks are invaluable. There is strength in groups, because in this game there's no cheap one-shot kills. If someone shoots there will be plenty of time to react for the opponent, because you won't kill anyone with just one shot and going back behind cover takes getting that robot up to speed again. If the guy you shot has 5 friends you'll be shot back way harder. So attacking goes in groups, that way the odds won't be stacked against you. More people is more joy, because if you brought 8 friends along the enemy will have a lot worse of a time. Then of course there's flanking and attack routes to keep in mind, maybe sending 4 guys to flank can be an advantage etc., you get the gist. Shame there's a lot of pubnoobs who don't care for strategy.

The meta-game is building your mech, which is another collection of strategic decisions I won't go too much into depth on. The basic idea is that you can't have it all, you'll have to choose your strengths and weaknesses. The grind is more important. Basically free players can have 1 mech up to full power, if you want to max level another mech you'll have to buy space and get the mech you want 3 times over. Grinding up the money and premium currency for a second fully powered mech takes so incredibly long I'd actually say it's not possible. For all intents and purposes you get 1 max-level mech, you'll have to pay real money for more or settle for not-max-level-mechs. That sounds really bad, but keep in mind that not-max-level-mechs are pretty decent and usable.

reviewText: MWO is for you If your looking for a game with individual skill (shooting, torso twisting), battlefield tactics (teamwork is OP) and customization (mech weapon loadout, camo, cockpit).  Don't be discouraged in the beginning (you will die) this is a game that takes effort to play well.  Communication and teamwork are important factors in achieving victory - and necessary for Faction Play.  There are Challenges/Events that give rewards (c-bills, MC, mechbays and even mechs) that really helps with the grind.  They also have sales often so taking advantage of them helps too.  Teamwork brings an whole other dimension to the game and many units have their own teamspeak server.  Joining a unit (the Apocalypse Lancers) was for me a major factor in making the game still enjoyabe to play.  Many veteran players are more than willing to help new players get the most fun out of their stompy robots.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER : THIS GAME HAS A MASSIVE LEARNING CURVE, BE PREPARED TO FEEL THE SUCK FOR A FEW HOURS OF PLAY UNTIL YOU GET THE HANG OF IT.
I HAVE BEEN PLAYING SINCE CLOSED BETA AND AM STILL PRETTY TRASH.


Having put hundreds of hours into this game before its steam release, and with a large number of mechs in my stable without spending a single dime despite having a premium mech and cosmetic items earned entirely from in-game Events (Which happen quite often actually, or did before steam release, we'll see!) I have to say that I enjoy this game far too much, The thing is, even if you buy things you are getting NO ADVANTAGE. This game's ONLY deciding factors are player skill, luck (Just like anything else luck is a factor) and utilizing the built in communications to coordinate with your team.


TIPS FOR NEW PLAYERS :
1. Turn off the ♥♥♥♥ing 3rd person, there's alittle camera drone behind and above your mech with a flashing red light EVERYONE CAN SEE when you're in 3rd Person, and its actually detrimental to your ability to aim.
2. Controller support is wonky, and you DO NOT want to use a controller anyway, M&K is going to serve you much better, tracking targets smoothly and quickly is ESSENTIAL in this game.
3.Never go out alone, you will die faster than you can say What's going on?!"
4. Save every C-Bill you earn until you can afford an IS assault or Clan Heavy
date: then save a few million more to outfit it as best as you can.\n5. USE OUT OF GAME UTILITIES LIKE SMURFY'S MECHLAB AND METAMECHS. YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED.\n6. The community has developed a Utility called "Fire Control" it has a weapon toggle feature for things like machineguns and TAG Laser designators
recommended: It is not against the game's rules and has other features as well like fire sequencing multiple fire groups instead of MWO's chainfiring mechanic
hoursPlayed: I only use it for very specific builds that are heavy on constant fire weapons like MGs/Missile boats with a TAG
voteText: but it can be used for other things as well.\n\n7/10 This game has its problems
helpfulPercent: and will continue to have problems
votesHelpful: but It's had a great year this past year and with it's deadweight publisher IGP gone since like two years ago IIRC PGI has been making massive strides to regain community trust and has produced an enjoyable if frustrating stompy mech shooty game. Its not battletech
votesTotal: but then again mechwarrior has never been battletech
votesFunny:
its just set in the same universe!

Server Disconnections are semi-common for me its kind of annoying but has been getting better lately.

reviewText:
Pros:

- free to play
- easy to learn
- not pay 2 win when it comes to playing casually
- not hacked to death, unlike most other free shooters
- unique, niche simulator, with fast-paced and, at the same time, deeply tactical gameplay
- instant access to 16 Trial Mechs (4 different mechs per each of the 4 different mech classes) without having to pay or grind anything. The only downside to these mechs is that you can't customise them, they're all pre-built
- new players get massively inflated rewards for their first 25 matches
- plenty of diversity in terms of various mech classes, mech types, mech builds (weapons, modules, etc)
- team-based game which rewards you for sticking together and helping each other
- some maps are huge with varied terrain and plenty of cover, which promotes tactics like flanking
- lazorz
- lazorzz
- lazorzzz

Cons:

- very little gameplay variety: instanced PvP matchmaking across 3 very similar game modes on 18 maps, of which you will usually only play the same few, because people vote for the same ones most of the time
- no PvE, no Open World, no real M M O gameplay - unless you count instanced matches for control of planets on a global map
- some maps are somewhat linear and so small that you will engage the enemy within 30 seconds after a round starts, and the round will then devolve into head-on barrages with minimum tactical elements
- key elements of combined arms from previous Mechwarrior games (and mods) are missing, like being able to pilot Elementals, drive non-mech vehicles, fly aircraft, etc
- after your inflated income for the first 25 matches dries up, the game becomes a massive grind for enough in-game currency and XP to fully upgrade and tailor your mech
- if you buy a mech and then decide you don't like it and want another one instead, you might as well make a new account
- you will have to play hundreds of hours to get properly upgraded mechs to be competitive in Community Warfare, unless you want to buy your way to pimped mechs, which cost dozens (if not more) dollars per unit
- some consumables are low-skill and incredibly cheesy, like air strikes and artillery strikes

Verdict:

9/11 ign

reviewText:
I had played this game before it was on Steam. It kinda makes me happy to see that it has been released on Steam.

MW:O had an iffy launch, the publisher made a ton of f-ups and gave many people a sour taste in their mouths. But since the developers cut themselves away from the publisher, the game becomes better and better. I enjoyed MW3, MW4 and M4: Mercs. And this game feels like a good MP adaption. Destroying enemy's with PPC and lasers is just as fun as it was then. Hell the impact the weapons gave in this game are even better.

There is 1 thing I kinda dislike, the consumables like airstrikes. IMO they should just be deleted from the game. But overall this game is a ton of fun.

PS: Many people (mostly trolls) are crying about Hero mechs, claiming that its P2W. The truth is though, most of them are crap. Another thing is, they are pre-assembled loadouts which you can make yourself for free (and often better since most of them are crap). The only thing different from Hero mechs and free mechs is the paint job.

reviewText:
If you enjoy shooting big robots then this is the game for you. I've played just over 3000 matches and still enjoy blasting mechs.

It's f2p done well, you can earn almost every thing in game using the in game currency and there are events most weekends that reward you with ingame currency, cosmetic items and sometimes premium currency and mechs.

The game does have some issues however, some of these are the lack of game modes (currently only three) and balance has been an issue in the past but is getting better.

Overall I'd reccomend this game, it's fun and free so why not try it out?

reviewText: Hello there fellow forum users! I just want to say what a great game this is, truely! You see, in the books and in TT games Clans are superior killing machines that can easily stand toe to toe with 1:2 odds, but here at PGI we like to do things...a little differently. You see, ever since IS players got us to change to game entirely and make CW wars nothing more than a stompfest on Claners we've seen huge ratings spikes and much more people like our game now. More people play IS anyways because when new players see the IS territories and see that they're almost 10x larger than the clans, they blindly join the IS, and thats just how we like it. With nerfed to hell clan mechs and everyone joining IS. Thank you ~PGI because ♥♥♥♥ the clans

reviewText:
The game has flaws. It lacks variety in game modes, some maps aren't balanced well enough, some weapons don't work as supposed to like LBX, team work is difficult without proper ingame commands except for chat, Faction wars are pointless at the moment but, damn, this game gives a proper MechWarrior feel.
It appreciates team work and tactical movement around the map, flanking and other stuff, it gives you epic moments when staying on top of a close and tough round with a new mech and loadout.
Do you need to pay to be able win? Nah, only learning and thinking brings victory. All mechs are available for ingame currency sooner or later except for Heroes and Champions, which are not a must.
Do you need to follow the Laser Meta? Not at all, any variety of weapons can work out if you utilize them properly.
There is a ton of various loadouts you can come up with for most of the mechs.

Stay away from Trials as soon as possible, but they sure helps to take a look at various Mechs.

The game gets updated often enough and it's a lot better than it was in 2013 and still getting better.
It's great to play this game in a split with Megamek to help visualize the last one. :)

240 hours since Steam release and still enjoying it.

reviewText: Been playing this game for years before it came to steam. It's easily in the best state it's ever been in. If you want to try your hand at a solid mech simulator, pick this up. It's entirely possible to play and do well without spending a dime, all it takes is practice practice practice.\nNothing that can be bought with money is any more competetive than what can be bought with in-game currency, it just might net you a little more reward at the end of your matches.\nThat said if the game catches your attention the way it has so many others and you find yourself a true fan, it can be hard not to spend the money to get those shiney mechs with special paint and increased match rewards.

reviewText:
You now all that ******* grinding and invisbily tank/ship crap from Armored Warfare, World Of Tanks, and World Of Warships?   Well none of that crap.

ALL non premium mechs are available for in game currency to ALL players, premium mechs are balanced ot where they only carry different load outs and aren't really pay to win or carry troll guns/armor due to the customization in the game

No mandatory premium since you don't pay for ammo replenishment or repairs every match

Your first 25 games and achievements make a lot of bonus XP/GXP/C-Bills(money) allowing you to buy any two mechs you want just about OR  one mech and a hell of a lot of equipment for it

The 'end game content' offers easy to get free mech bays (garage slots) so you don't need to spend a bunch of money on them.

Also the things you can spend money on in bundles and such are MUCH better in this game than in competitors, A month of premium time and 3 chassis (with all the equipment involved) for 17-45$ or so,  compared to the 50$ for one ship and a bunch of gold for experience converting while you grind the ship or tank till you're miserable and bored playing the same vehicle over and over and over.   Meanwhile I take my mech out with a different weapos and equipment load out every other match.

reviewText:
Mechwarriors has changed a lot in the last few years. In 2013 I liked it but it was such a grind. Now two years later, it is so much easier to get money. On top of the in game money sales they have on mechs, it is pretty easy to get the mechs I want to play. No longer restricted to the Spider and Jenner, I tried out some of the heavy mechs. So much variety! Each mech does feel different. More so with Inner Sphere mechs.

There are some paid mechs that do have an advantage but it is kind of minimal. Some of them will have ECM or more hard points. But most of them are actually worse than the base models. You could play this game and not spend a cent and be completely fine. There are plenty of events to give you in game gold and premium time.

Die hard mechwarriors fans from previous games? I dunno. I hear a lot of those guys complain. This use to be..." I liked the older games to but was never huge into them like these guys. I love MWO - it really is a good game. Don't let the old MW players make you think otherwise. It's free after all
date: you don't have much to lose to try out the game. Plenty of trail mechs to take for a spin!"

reviewText:
+ Satisfying Combat
++ In Depth Customization of Mechs makes your mech made just for you
+ Awesome Community
+Money does not make you better in combat... might make your mechs look coolio tho.
+Nice graphics

-This game might seem abit grindy to some.
-Customiztion may be overwhelming at first.


Combat in this game really satisfying, you can really tell you did a number on your opponent... when you completley blow off his mechs arms or send him running with a silly limp :D. The nice visual effects really add to that as well.

Its more of a shooter that involves more strategy, teamwork and knowledge of your mech and, with experience, the weaknesses of your enemies mechs to succeed.
Tho, having skills like a stready trigger finger and good situational awareness will also get you far... plus it keeps you from being deadz.

The main thing thats really got me hooked on this game is the in depth customisation of mechs in this game. I've spent hours endlessly customizing and testing them on the battlefeild just to find that sweet spot, only to have my taste of weaponry shift again and again depending on me wanting more pew pew or dakka dakka. Or whether i want to be a In Your Face" role or a support role. To simply put it
recommended: the customization does look quite intimidating to beginners and new players may be lost at first with all the numbers and different components.\nBut the high amount of detail you can go to customizing your mech
hoursPlayed: right down to the armor in each limb and type of Missle
voteText: Cannon
helpfulPercent: Laser
votesHelpful: Sensors
votesTotal: Engines
votesFunny: makes each mech tailor made to your intended play style.\n\nGlad to say
commentsCount: this game is far from a pay to win kind of game but does allow you to use real money to get what you want right away if your not willing to grind for it. But gives no real edge in combat in the end of the day.\nHowever
column16:
the game showers new players with loads of in game money when they start out. Which leads me to the biggest advice i can give to new players.Try the trail mechs first before spending all that c-bill moola.

The game affectively gives new players the choice of any mech in the beginning due to the extra c-bills players get in their first few matches (first 25). So get a good idea of what matches your play style first THEN buy your dream mech.

Last few words : Stick together and TEAMWORK is king."

reviewText:
I read a number of positive & negative reviews before writing my outstandingly positive review of MechWarrior Online!

The anger I saw from the community of 3+ years ago and from the founding members about some of the problems with changes the developer made are just nonexistent in the game today.  I also feel the community back then was mostly just upset about changes that weren’t fair at the time but have been fixed from the game I play today.  So, don't let any of those reviews deter you from trying this fantastic game.

MechWarrior Online is free, worth a bit of your time to try out, and if you enjoy playing it grab a few Mechs to support the continued development of the game, and if not, you paid nothing!

The game I found is very competitive, fun, and nothing short of amazing.

PS: Use the “Dakka” Dire Wolf mech seen on the “Metamechs” mech building website; it has been my favorite so far!  Anyway, no more time to write, there are enemy mechs that need a good Dakka!

Enjoy, Have Fun!

reviewText:
This is a game that deserves more credit.
Here are the pros, and the cons.
PROS;
A legendary game comes back to life!
Animation is wonderful.
gameplay is extensive and enjoyable.
queue time is VERY short.
all the mechs are available at the start (But you cant modify or save them)
money is obtainable,
free to play!
NOT a pay to win,
the players all people who played the original. So their older and smarter! Ive never seen a steam user ACTUALLY STRATEGIZE!
and doy, its mechwarrior. You cant go wrong with a classic like that.

Cons
If you quit in a middle of a game you can either resume the game or wait.
experience is needed
training is dull and boring.
no form a booster just flying.

EXTRAS;
i have played the original mech fighter, and it revolutionized the shooter industry for being one of the first games to be 3D. You can see their progress with time! It is extremely fun to fire missiles and lazers at my enemies.
I recommend it!

reviewText:
Long time MechWarrior fan, and I have to admit this game feels very much like, if not better than, the previous MechWarrior titles from way back when.  Teamwork and knowing the particular strengths / weaknesses of the Battlemech you take out will drastically affect how well your matches will go.

My only cons with the game is that there's no single player or at least some kind of co-op vs AI mode.  Also not having any game mode population sizes outside 12v12 can be annoying....I'm much more of a 4v4 or 8v8 match playstyle as the smaller numbers allow for more individual player skill to shine rather than deathballing in a 12 man match.

Despite the cons I mentioned if you like tactical 1st person shooters then you should give this a go.

reviewText:
Despite its questionable pricing model, MechWarrior Online is just way too much fun to play.
It's relatively complex when it comes to customization, but the game is tons of fun. My opinion is somewhat biased (or not biased at all, as it would push me to scrutinize the game harder) because I have been a long-time fan of the BattleTech/MechWarrior franchise and series. I've played the MechWarrior games since the first, and always enjoyed them.
All that said, I found myself pleasantly surprised with MWO. I feel like they have done the franchise justice quite well, and, although I had concern that the Clans weren't getting a lot of love, we have gotten quite a hefty hand of Clanners recently, along with IIC 'Mechs, and more Clanners incoming even.
If I have anything to complain about, it's that the 'Mechs don't totally feel like 'Mechs at times. They control a little too... Smoothly? I guess? Smooth is good, but something about it feels 'too' fluid, if you know what I mean. Also, when a 'Mech is destroyed, it feels like there's no real weight behind its descent... But these are minor, minor complaints. I adore this game, and if you want a fun technical shooter with a strong focus on teamwork and patience, start playing. You don't lose much if you don't like it, really, the game is free.

reviewText:
Faithful recreation of the tabletop game? Probably not....but as close as you can get in a massive multiplayer arena?

Absolutely.  Granted PGI does everything they can to entice you to spend real money, but MWO is a great time if you get off work and just want to climb into the cockpit of a 80 ton robot with giant cannons and laser beams. Oh, and missiles, did I mention drone boats?

Yes, I didddddddd.

Weapons systems are a bit off from the tabletop (ESP. EW, ie ECM / Beagle / NARC)  due to playerwhine, but ultimately it's all here, save a Long Tom (I suspect that's not long in the coming). Perks truly make each varient of the mech chassis unique and weapons oriented, so you can load up that Mauler with PPC's and the correct varient will SHINE.

Best played with a team. Lance. Company, whatever you can get - but if you go PuG you're likely to get a bit...disappointed as the team skill ration isn't very high. However, there are a BUNCH of high quality Merc Corporations you can join to get the full feel and training if you so choose.
