reviewText:
This game used to be a disappointment to me, and in a few ways it still is. The development cycle seems to be dragging at a snails pace, and the community has a shaky history. However If I were to compare it to other free to play games on Steam it comes out on top of a lot of them with really solid gameplay and customization, good graphics and sound, and on top of that probably the best in the big stompy mech genre for now.

The greatest amount of naysaying you will hear is going to be from the old NBT Hardcore Vets. The real Battletech badasses of a bygone age. This game is not even close to a carbon copy of the good old days of Mechwarrior 4 Mercs some of the most well organized league play I have ever seen. I was very young when I watched my brother's Dad play on Clan Smoke Jaguar, The Jade Falcons, and even The Blazing Aces (of which I was a member of sometime until the MWO went through a period of great stagnation.)

All in all, if you play these games for fun, you are going to have fun.

If you play the game wanting to get back in to league play the exact same way you did back in NBT, you are gonna have a bad time.

reviewText:
Overall this game feels like it lives up to the MechWarrior standard we all know and love. I read reports of it feeling incredibly Pay2Win in the early stages. This discouraged me quite a bit until I decided to play just recently. And I have to say, they have fixed this massive issue from my experience so far.

This game sets you in the seat of any one of dozens of building-sized mechs (with variations for every appetite of carnage) as it pits you against one another in a thought-provoking strategy. Run&Gunners will not like this game, outright, to be successful you need to utilize what you can with your team and weigh strategies. A single mech can turn the tide of battle depending on the game type and the strategy employed.

PROS:
-High on the thought-provoking based gameplay. (Moves/actions/assaults require tactics)
-Built-in Voice to assist with this
-The mech choices feel endless and nearly every style of approach" can be found in at least one mech
-Weapon balance is very sold
date:
something you expect from a MW game
-Builds for any mech can keep even veteran tinkerers happy
-Maps have variety (even if people only choose a few maps)
-The game feels organic and very immersive as you are set in the cockpit of a 30-100 ton war machine
-The smallest mechs have strategies to employ against the largest
recommended:
and vice versa. Not one mech can truly reign as "king of mechs"

CONS:
-New players will feel overwhelmed with the amount of options and how to actually build/load a mech
-The tutorial is nice but not as extensive as the game itself
-There is no "try before you buy" unless your mech of choice happens to be in the weekly(?) trial mech line-up
-EXP gain and Credits gain after your first few battles feels molasses in January slow
-Game requirements may be high for some older PC's

Overall the gameplay is as solid as titanium with a few flaws in regard to resource income. Good visuals
hoursPlayed: good gameplay
voteText:
and the community is actually quite friendly for a team-based competitive game. Let's just say I'd rather meet with MWO folk than LoL/DOTA2 folk any day of the week.

Solid 9.5/10
Promote whoever did the improvements for this game."

reviewText:
Mechwarrior Online, This is a Free to Play PVP TDM shooter game with you driving huge mecha in combat.

Store sells cosmetics, Mecha with and without xp/credit buffs, xp buffs, credit buffs, xp conversion.

If you die in a TDM match, there is no respawn.
Winning the matches give you the most xp and credits.  Winning a match requires teamwork, communications, good aiming while moving skills, tactics, good mech builds, using cover and speed, and luck to be on the winning side.


Pros:
Free to play.
4 mech weight classes.
Great graphics, sound, gameplay.
Mecha building.
Trial mechs that rotate weekly.
Faction gameplay, The Clans vs the Inner Sphere, one clan or house vs another.
Community gameplay.
Has Steam achievements.
Tutorial mode.
Good instructions.
Joystick support.
Mech and Pilot module unlocks.
60 plus Great mecha models with variants.

reviewText:
MWO is an FPS simulation (and yes, I saw that walking simulator tag...sigh) where you drive 35-100 ton death machines around and blow things up.  If this sounds awesome welcome to BATTLETECH, a universe where war is decided by these giant mechs.  Each mech has a ton of customization with the different weapon groups.  Lasers, balistics and missiles.  The game can be daunting for someone new, but it does come with tutorial missions and practice missions to help get new players up to speed.  Of course, you could also jump straight into the action and that's fine as well.

Graphics are good.  It runs off the cryengine which while dated can still put out some good images at the highest settings.  Of course, it's also scaled pretty well, so if you experience performance issues feel free to turn down some settings.  The only gripe I have with the graphics is low-light vision.  Sometimes it gets hard to see enemy mechs, especially on night maps.  There are two vision modes designed to help with that.  Thermal (triggered by pressing H) allows you to see the heat signatures of enemy mechs.  Hot objects glow bright white in this view, but be careful not to use it on the Terra Therma map or you'll go blind.  It can also sometimes be hard to drive with this mode especially in cities as buildings don't show up too well.  The other vision mode is night vison (Triggered by pressing n) which is the same green-screen that you would expect.  It works well most of the time and provides good contrast but it has problems with smoke.

Controls are pretty simple but you have to get used to thinking of your mech as a tank.  Comming from World of Tanks and a longtime battletech fan, it wasn't hard for me to get used to this but some people really struggle not being able to strafe side to side.  You have to turn your legs first!  I've tried it with a controller as well and it takes some configuring but you can set it up no problem.

Gameplay is awesome.  It's an FPS but mechs have lots of health so you can take a few hits and trade with enemies.  Position and line of sight is also really important, as is TARGETING.  There is a radar screen but only the mechs you and your team target will show up on the map.  There is a lot of info warfare demonstrated in this game and I love it.  There are target painting lasers, beacon rockets that can light up enemy mechs for the world to see, ECM and counter ECM, active probes.  I could go on all day.  There are a lot of really skilled players out there that have written and videoed great guides, or just, had fun!  The game is fairly balanced for the most part but it is very heavy on teamwork and focus fire.  Individual 1v1s are rare, and sometimes they aren't always in your favor as different mechs have different roles, some mechs are superb duelists while some mechs are more long-range fire support.  If a duelist gets in close to a fire support mech that fire support mech is probably dead, that's why this game relys so much on teamplay.

Mechwarrior, and battletech, has a lot of fans.  If you love battletech, you'll love this game.  However, I have some tips and warnings for newbies.

A tip: Don't get intimidated!  Battletech has a rich lore and a vast customization system.  Look up metamechs (its a website :P) mess around in smurfy's mechlab, above all else, keep an open mind. This can be a slow game, but it can also be very fast, it all depends on the flow of the match you're in.  Don't listen to people crying about P2W, for the most part, the game is pretty balanced on that front.  It's more, 'pay for convenience' and PGI has a habit of releasing mechs in stages, first stage is like a preorder, then it's available for premium currency, then it's available for C-Bills (The standard currency)

A warning: You need a lot of patience to play this game.  The cadet missions and training missions give out some C bills, but mechs can cost upwards of 9million Cbills when fully decked out.  It will take you some time to get up to speed, but it's worth the wait, as once you have your own mech you can do whatever you want with it.  Fight in community warfare!  Master your mechs!  And have fun!

reviewText:
If you've ever played a mechwarrior game, the combat mechanics will be pretty familiar to you.

All players are offered a variety of trial mechs which change frequently. The trial mechs are very competitive and often 'hero' variants are available as well. If you wish to modify your mech you'll have to buy one with c-bills or real money, which is easily done after playing your first handful of matches.

Premium content includes mech patterns (skins), colors, war horns, dashboard bling and experience/c-bill boosts.

The built in VOIP is excellent and allows for even random quick match groups to be extremely well organized. Graphics are excellent, audio is excellent, no input lag to speak of.

The user interface can be a little overwhelming at first, but after some experience you'll find that the flexibility that comes with having a ton of options can be extremely rewarding.

10/10

reviewText:
8.5/10                         ...Would turn 12 enemy Mechs to burning heaps of scrap again.

I have included two video's of me playing in one of the heaviest and one of the lightest Mechs in the game. Nothing gets the adrenaline pumping like perma-death Arena Combat!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pPjvpjtpgb0&list=PL-3BCK8E48cbVI-R2eOAUBVvPxc_yuAPb&index=1

Pro's

- Great Gameplay
- Extremely satisfying combat
- Easy to pick up controls and get strait into the fighing but extremely hard to Master a Mech and become an Ace pilot (Pick a Mech and carve out your own Piloting Style)
- Fantastic sense of developing your armoury and customizing Mechs to suit your Play style
- Great replayability and sense of earning/time invested for tangible rewards
- Regular Community wide tournaments and events which reward all players with real money purchasable items from the store (cosmetic colours and commos/Mech Bays/War horns/Cockpit Items/Free Mechs etc.|)
- Can play this game Free2Play, there is no Pay2Win except temporary pay walls when new Mechs are released
- Teamspeak address known as Comstar to find players to play with or clans to join mwo.syn-games.com or na1.mech-connect.net
- Doesnt need a high-spec machine to run. Those two videos were filmed on low settings on a low-med spec computer.
- Cadet bonus and tutorial give new players a good chunk of the in game currency allowing them to kit out any Mech of their choice to start earning some C-Bills


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x3vUh771X7Q&list=PL-3BCK8E48cZS_W9FcgSPgmSypuxMsGXD

Con's

- Dev's who often apear to have no understanding or experience playing the game
- Some really bad maps - Forest Colony, River City and Caustic Valley (ironically these maps used to be fine but the dev's tried to improve them)
- Quite a grind before you have any decent variety of Mech's
- Conquest and Assault both are lacking as game modes leaving skirmish as by far the more popular
- One of the most toxic gaming communities around although i personally enjoy this as it means you get raged at regularly by the feeble opposition you just slaughtered single handedly. However most of the abuse will come from critical members of your own team. This similarly is a source of entertainment for me. If you are dead and i am alive your criticism means nothing!
- Did i mention how bad the Devs can be?

If you want a game that you can play regularly on your own or with friends that includes big stompy robots blasting bits off each other then look no further. Combat that stays satisfying after the 1000th time you have walked over the vanquished corpses of your enemies and shot a 100 ton Mech that towers over you in the ♥♥♥ with all your weapons and watched him topple like a giant tree to come crashing down at your feet.

reviewText:
Ok a review for this game after i've hit 100+ hours in game. If you have ever dreamed of piloting a big giant robot this is the closest you are going to get until someone does a follow up to the Mechwarrior series of games.

1) Controls are simple enough though its recommended to play with a keyboard and mouse rather than a joystick setup as per in game cockpit pilots.

2) Players are refreshingly not toxic like CSGO which has the nastiest creatures around. Yeah once in a while you get a troll but that is exceedingly rare. Beware in PUG not many people speak at all which is a bit weird considering its a team based battle game

3) The in game purchases does reek a bit of a money grab at times with prices that is quite expensive for each pack (DLC) but if you are into the game I guess you will be throwing money at the developers anyway. This game is not Pay to WIn but more of a get items sooner with your cash .

4) Gameplay - I have had epic matches with some battles reminding me of the movies with great set piece battles like the Gladiator and 300. Lots of pincer movements and flanking executed though it is rare that a team is so coordinated.

Overall I would say download the game and enjoy the free to play options that is available. If you wanna get deeper , then purchase a Mastery pack for the Mech you like to play with. Good game!

reviewText:
I have a full time job, 2 kids, a wife, and other responsibilities... I still find the time to get in 11.5 hrs in 2 weeks.  I know that doesn't sound like a lot but for someone who plays maybe an hour a week on a good week...

It is also worth note that this game does have a learning curve, and tier 5 is full of derptastic derpdom and things like friendly fire, but on the whole I have seen it as having one of the least toxic, albeit at time salty as hell, communities I've been apart of in a while.  As a rough rule people are willing to teach and learn... though more use of the coms would be nice.

Great game, loads of potential, and hopefully will continue to move forward in a similar track.

I love this game, it is fantastic, and while the packs here are garbage, even on 20% sale, it is well worth starting and if you want to sink in some money often you end up going straight to the source.

reviewText:
Pros
- Beautifully designed Mechs by Alex Iglesias (the man is a god)
- Not a twitch shooter. Needs map awareness and thinking to play well.
- Kit out your mech
- Play as a team or lose.

Cons
- Developer has no clue about game mode mechanics
- Developer has no clue about map design
- Developer has no clue how to optimise a game engine (DX9 runs better than DX11 here)
- The game will never be finished. Developer is constantly fiddling around with it.
- Faction Play (Community Warfare) is a bust
- Conquest mode

Having played this for 2-3 years since before Steam release. I have to warn you that the learning curve is fairly steep. There are a lot of things to know about the game, and they will not come quickly.

Most of the guys who have stuck around are hardcore Battletech/Mechwarrior fans who just want to pilot their favourite mechs into battle and blow up other mechs.

The core gameplay loop is improving how fast you blow up the other guy with well placed shots. But the game modes are standard. Skirmish, Assault, Domination are all just Deathmatches with some twist or none. I personally hate Conquest mode because it simply doesn't work without respawn mechanics.

A lot of this review sounds negative, and that is intended. I would recommend this game, but ONLY if you like the few things it does right, and if you like beautiful mechs.

reviewText:
Its not bad.

If you're looking for a modern day Mech Warrior game, this is a pretty good fit.  The game play seems to blend the best part of MW3 and MW4 together, while at the same time eliminating some of the most annoying parts of each.  Gone are the laser bunnies that dominated MW3.  Gone are the crippling customization limitations that made MW4 bad.  While you don't have complete freedom, the game gives you enough to capture a good experience - if you're willing to grind for it.

The C-bill grind wall is pretty massive after the first 25 games.   You cant just jump in your mech of choice as in past games, you instead have to buy it and you'll farm for quite sometime just to gear out a good sized mech the way you want it.  This kind of sucks.  The games microtransation system is not required at all, but is also not very generous.  If you do want to support the game, be prepared to pay 20$ just for 1 medium sized mech.

All and all, if you're looking for some old fashion mech action, this game is good.  Just make sure to buy the mech you want in the beginning, otherwise it's going to be a long time until you get it.

reviewText:
MechWarrior, what can I say besides it’s been an iconic game coming from the battle tech universe and the world of table top, for us older gamers we remember the early MechWarrior game series and enjoyed the story line and game play.  Not to mention the in game movie content as you became deeply involved the more you played.

MechWarrior Online:

I started beta testing this game during the closed beta back in 2012 and still continue to play it since the release date of September 17, 2013.  There are a lot of things that I’m not happy about as MWO has evolved as do a lot of other people who play this game.  All I can say is don’t get your head stuck in the forums and the negativity see the game for what it is.  A constantly evolving and improving online experience as a MechWarrior pilot with the Inner sphere, Clans and Mercenaries.
Mech releases are flowing with the in game time line so as the time line progresses more tech and mechs become available.  There is a tier based ranking system that let players play with those at their skill level.  Very good to help new players get familiar with the game play and tactics.  Just remember if you are in a group with players at a higher Tier you will play at that level.

8/10
If community warfare was completed and not still in the beta phase I would probably give it a 9/10
I put this game down for 9months and picked it up again recently and was impressed to see the changes that had happened over that time being new maps, mechs and a graphic overhaul.
It’s free and also pay to play, grind your way for C-bills to buy mechs or throw down $100 for 25000 mech credits either way it’s a hell of a game and definitely worth a try.

V1L3

Clan Wolf International [CWI]
clan-wolf.info

See you in the next drop..
o7

reviewText:
I work full time, and play a lot of mechwarrior, so I don't have time for a big review, but here's the gist of it:

Come in with no expectations, and be very happy. It's pretty much like getting to play multiplayer mechwarrior of old. The effects are cool, the graphics are okay, the gameplay is slightly different but still about shooting lasers, autocannons, and missiles at enemies and blowing off their limbs.

However, I have never seen such visceral hate for the developer as I have in this game. Everyone who plays routinely poops all over PGI (the developers). I understand the REASON people are mad. The mechanics are so solid in this game, that it's just BEGGING for some cool stuff. Cooperative missions, single player campaign, more multiplayer modes, really cool base sieges and destructable buildings. Those would all be really, really great. And yes, the developer talks about how those are going to be in the game, and yes, they are not in the game yet. Should that equal anger and a vicious attitude to the development staff? I guess that's up to you to decide.

As for me... I still play for a few hours every day, so I can't complain. It's a good game, and it's a mechwarrior game. See you on the battlefield.

Let us take a mathematical process to determine if MWO is good.
MWO= Mech Warrior Online _ WOT= World of Tanks _ Tanks=T _ Mechs=M
WOT=good _  M>T
So that would mean |M-T| > 0
MWO= WOT-T+M
MWO>WOT>good
We can therefore safely say MWO=amazing

reviewText: Probably one of the most comprehensively balanced multiplayer games ive played. The matchmaking seems to be spot on and matches are consistently tactical and thrilling.  A huge variety of mech's backed up by an even larger variety of mods, addons, weapons.  You can tweak your mech's to your preferred playstyle and more importantly, take premium Mech's out for trial. The community is great, the surrounding ecosystem of forums, Smurphys Mechlab and wide variety of clan specific pages remind me a lot of the commiunity around EVE.\n\nOverall, one of the most consistently fun multiplayer experiences I have had. I dont even mind the grind for credits and skills simply because I get to drop into battles and mash other players in walking tanks bristling with lazers.

reviewText:
*Edited: This was before I began getting into the faction (ranked) gameplay. The mode is way more tactical with actual strategizing, that the community often engages in. However, the queues are extremely long, even longer than gameplay somtimes.
Here's the rest of the review:

I have mixed feelings about this game, but overall I feel it's a pretty fun, semi-tactical combat arena game in the Battlemech universe. I've been looking to play something like Mechwarrior but more recent, and this fits those old games with improved gameplay and graphics.

I haven't been huge into the Battlemech universe, so part of the game is overwhelming. There is a lot going on in this game; so many Mechs to choose from, weapons and builds to go with.

The community has been pretty solid thusfar. I've only had 1 game where a teammate purposely shot off my arms. I expected more, but everyone seems to either be going along with the gameplay or actively tactical and supportive.

The gameplay is very short and can miss a lot of the tactical aspect. The maps are diverse and offer some strategizing, but within the community, the strategy features aren't used often. The same can be said for any gameplay mode that isn't deathmatch; all objectives tend to be to elimate the other team.

Some purchase aspects are mainly skins, or things that can be grinded for. So it's not unfairly balanced to those who pay to win. The challenges add some objective and diversity to the gameplay, but I feel it is really lacking in tactical-based objective seeking gameplay.

This is a game that works well, plays great and has the community to support it. You get dig deep into the immense Battlemech universe, grind and build limitlessly, or just skirmish in a well developed combat game.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
First off: This isn't a twitch game. Being a good button-masher isn't going to make you a good player.

Second: This isn't Call of Duty. You can't carry your team's weight. Teamwork is necessary, so use that option to talk to your team.

Third: Big stompy robots with big weapons are awesome. This game takes it to a new level in the sheer variety of what you can do to make your big stompy robots YOURS. You have a mech with two ballistic hard points that has enough slots for a pair of AC 20s, go ahead and slap 'em on. Not to mention the game is balanced. Having a big mech isn't an automatic win.

Fourth: The game really is free to play. It isn't pay to win. You pay for things like different colors for your mech or some cockpit bling. Maybe you just really want that mech right now, so you can use actual money. There is not one thing you need to buy to be an actual, competitive player.

reviewText:
Love this game so far. Fair warning to new players though..... Within my first hour of playing and learning I was bombarded with name calling etc. by veteran clan players on my team about every other game for not knowing the maps, what my mech's role was, etc. It was pretty harsh.... and of all the time I have played online MP games this was probably the biggest bash-fest on new players in the game I have ever seen.... They are easy to ignore... Just keep playing on and learn!! I look at it this way.... if players take a loss in a random, match-making battle so personal.... They aren't worth the bits and bytes of text data they type when they cry about losing in a match with mixed noobs and vets...

Game is free to play as it says and lots and lots to do for free. Trial mechs of every class to learn on or decide which you like, you can buy your first mech or 2 and load it out, as well as add some perks and what not all from playing the game. No purchases really needed. If you want more advanced mechs and components....asthetics... yea it is a little pricey with real money.

All in all this one can be played without spending a dime and still have fun doing it. If you are obsessed with kill ratios, cool paint jobs, clans, and want to take this game from recreation level to my day is ruined because I lost again" fanatic....You will need to open your wallet up a little...

Graphics are pretty decent for what it's worth. Gameplay is great... A LOT of different mechs and configurations for them are almost limitless...and free. From what I have seen so far
date: there really isn't a balancing issue bc of this... Everyone uses all different mechs that are custom built to their style...and none really overpowered considering this is a team effort game.... The guy who goes out solo away from the group always dies.... No matter how good he is... A group of baddie mechs will tear a lone player apart."

Ummmm Yeah... This is Bill Lumbar reporting in for my first review of MWO.

I started playing MWO around 2 years ago.  I have always been a fan of the BT table top, grew up playing it as a child and young adult.  38 now, and through the years I have played many of the BT games on sega, super Nes, playstation, xbox and pc to name a few.  I used to head up to chicago to the BT center as a kid with my dad to get my fix.

Life took over and I found myself not playing BT games anymore, and for years.  I got that hunger again around two years ago and googled new BT games.  First hit I got was MWLL and I happened to have the old Cyris game so I was all set.  Jumped right in and I loved it... then bam!  MWLL got shut down/they stopped developing it.  I then read the rumors surrounding the why" and came across MWO and downloaded it and started playing it more then I would like to admit.  For a solid 6 months

reviewText: I've been playing this game since Beta. It has come a long way since then. It is a smaller development team than I would like for such a large title and cult following, but they are doing a fine job considering. And they've been doing MUCH better since they split from their Publishers (IGP).\n\nIf you love BattleTech and want to try out driving your own customized Big Stompy Robots against a Team of enemy players, then give this game a try! If you've never heard of BattleTech but you like the idea of Giant Robots that drive and fight similar to Tanks, give this game a try! They have been constantly tweaking their matchmaking system to give as fair as possible games to everyone. Of course, with any matchmaking system, the more players the better the matchmaking will be! Tell your friends to give this game a shot. It has a lot of re-playability and hundreds of different mechs to collect and customize.

reviewText:
Hello potential MechWarriors,

I am Khan CoffiNail Tseng a unit leader of the Clan Faction loyalist unit Clan Ghost Bear International. I have been on and off heavily active in MechWarrior since May 2010, a year before MWO was even announced playing in a MechWarrior mod for the game Crysis. I was a zealous fan of MWO from the start of announcements for MechWarrior Online using a daily puzzle of the Atlas concept artwork and twitter to stir a buzz felt around the net. I was so crazy in love with this game I ended being the 25th register forum member. I still play this game and am more a grey knight than a zealous fan for various reasons, but I am a die-hard Mechhead and love to see MechWarrior in the spotlight it had back in the 90s. The game has its flaws, but so does any game that is in development still, it may be out but it is a perpetually in development game. So the MWO you play today, will not be the same one in a year, as content is continuously coming out and being teased with.

It is a great game. It has very well done artwork, and the Mechs are extremely well done. Animation is great as most mechs feel weighty and others make you jump if you run in to them around a corner and you skid to a stop to try and get back around your corner. Scale could be considered a little off by some, but with the addition half a year ago with destructible light posts, knockdown trees, etc the scale seems fairly well for Machines only a dozen meters tall. The environments are beautiful and I still find myself getting lost in them at times.

Do you want a game that can be both twitch and slow, where good aim pays off to take down critical components, but someone who’s aim is mediocre can still do decent damage and have a great time doing it? MWO is a good FREE game to add to your library. If you want a game with a lot of weapons fire going off and an often chaotic battlefield or something to get a fill of stompy big robots this game is a great FREE addition to your library. You are someone who just loves to tinker with things until they are just right, shedding armour off this leg to add a bit more armour or heat sinks, crafting the perfect build and playstyle this would be a great FREE addition to your library. Honestly, it is free, so give it a try and do not take my word for it but experience the battlefield of 1980’s 31st Century Battlefield Technology.

This game has had its ups and downs much like any develop game and the fact their game has been in a large sense open to the public since November 1st 2011 and the very start of their development, now this means they have had a lot of scrutiny and under the microscope. They have been developing a nestablished universe with a fairly strong fanbase. These fans have not had a game since early 2002 in MechWarrior 4. Of course these loyal crowd, to which I am one love the core universe MechWarrior Online was place in, Battletech. It has a deep and rich backstory that is the effect of an alternate history starting in the 1980s.

PGI’s announcement of MechWarrior Online had a very exciting start. With a twitter feed giving daily in universe news written by the current developer of the tabletop, backstory universe Randall Bills. It had hints of the setting, a puzzle of concept art. The month of October 2011 was fairly amazing from a Mechwarrior fan’s point

This is getting to be a very balanced game. No longer do you have a arms race to the largest Mechs with the most advanced tech. Every mech in the right hands could be a very deadly opponent. Like in this universe the elite skilled were some of the deadliest pilots, who could operate their machines like and extension of themselves. A green and fresh pilot in a Atlas, should come down to a veteran in a light Mech Jenner.
The Customization of Mechs via the Mechlab. Giving you hours of lost time playing around to get your warmachine just the way you like it, with the weapons you like. The deeper meta of the mechlab is an art all in itself and is a core aspect to master in competitive scenes.

Role Warfare: Where your Assault Mechs going in force alone would mean nothing, but a well-coordinated team, mixed with different weight classes and loadouts could crush a more numerous opponents. Your Heavy Mechs were the support and the force going in with the assaults and crushing the opposition. Medium Mechs the backbone of the game, your go to for price and power. The light Mechs of your team were experts as going in behind enemy lines and at using Electronic Counter Measures (ECM) to shield your team from enemy sensors.

Intelligence Warfare: From the above lights, to other, heavier chassis with ECM and other electronics of the battlefield. Using your gear to assist in spotting for you Long Range Missiles allies in the rear or to jam the ECM of your foe.

Community Warfare: The creation of units in-game. Guilds, clans, communities. The larger picture of the glory that is a game set in the war torn Inner Sphere of the Battletech Universe. There is always war, and this give the community as deeper meta game to bring to the table.

Something always feels great about piloting 20-100 ton Bipedal Warmachine of destruction and smashing them around a forest or city. The rush you can have being the last pilot in a match, or as you take on a mech in a higher weight class, or even as that Assault crashing in to wreak havoc with your team.

Thanks for reading. I hope I have given a bit of sway for you to try MechWarrior Online, or at least to keep it on your scope to try soon. We see the same games in different forms, and MWO has a bit of a different take on the FPS. I hope to see you on the battlefield MechWarrior.

-Khan CoffiNail Tseng, Clan Ghost Bear International ghost-bear-command.com
voteText: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Hello mechwarriors, and potential mechwarriors.


I'am a long time player, original founder, and competitive team vet. I also played ALL the previous iterations of this franchise, going all the way back to the beginning. For what it's worth. I have played in well over 5000 drops, own 200+ mechs.

On to the game itself.

Oh I have spent money, but mostly, because I wanted to, I buy mech bays, and premium time mostly and up until recently every mech pack they sold. I took a small hiatus from purchasing packs until some game issues were resolved, I did not stop playing, not even a little, but I voted with my wallet for a while :).

The game is fun, it's fast paced, and it requires you to think about what you are doing at all times, stop for a minute to look around, and you might be dead. There is a unique variance in how you play based on the type of mech you bring in the game, light, medium, heavy, assault. You can play the game as a solo participant or as a group participant, here is the divide, teamwork is OP, and always will be in a game that boasts a 12v12 atmosphere.

Many people are reviewing this game, and many giove it negative reviews, mostly, because they are now, or at least were at some point, very passionate about this game, this is the common theme you will in reviews on steam for MWO, passion, it makes for a diverse and interesting commentary on how this game effects  the people who play it. Many people come and go, some say the best" players have gone on to other games

If you like mech combat simulation games definitely give it a try.

reviewText: I really enjoy MWO, and have been playing it since early 2015, and through updates the game has progressed nicely and I believe it will continue to grow. It is already a great game, and I believe it will keep getting better.  It has a massive learning curve, so it will take some time and many many matches to get decently good at the game. It is possible to play the game entirely free, but it will take some grinding to get enough to in-game currency to purchase more 'Mechs. There are frequent weekend challenges that give extra content for doing well in different game modes, and the devs. are hard at work building more game modes for release in spring of 2016.  As I said I really enjoy playing this game, and I hope PGI can continue building it into a great BattleTech universe game!

reviewText:
Alright, where do I start?

Also this review is written on 12/21/2015, so some information may change.

- F2P -
The game is a free-to-play game, so give it a shot. The grind in-game isn't as bad as it used to be. You can now gain in-game currency at a reasonable rate whether you do well or not. There is some content that's locked behind a paywall. There's some stuff you can purchase with the premium currency (MC) and some stuff you can purchase with cash directly from the mwomercs.com website.The premium currency stuff is mostly cosmetics. You can purchase mechs and stuff with the premium currency, but that's a waste. There are some premium only mechs with unique hardpoint configurations.Thankfully, PGI is rather generous, as there are ways to gather the premium currency in-game. As for the direct cash purchase items, they are typical pre-order mechs that'll eventually get released for
purchase via the in-game currency. Some of them have special stuff that's exclusive to the purchase, so if you're a sucker for some of those aesthetics, feel free to purchase?

- Gameplay -
As for the gameplay, its a more tactical shooter, with a simulation game feel. It significantly slower than most shooters in the market, so don't try to play it like those other games. You get to pilot some stompy robots and shoot some lasers, ballistics, missiles and stuff at each other. And you get to fully customize their loadouts and such. It's rather entertaining.
There are 4 weight classes of mechs you get to pick from. Lights: Played fast and twitchy. They typically have little armor and weaponry, but they get to run all over and wreck heavier mechs in various situations. If you have a twitch shooter background, playing lights may help you ease into the game. Mediums: Relatively nimble and armed. I recommend playing mediums if you have no clue where to start. They have enough tools to show you the range of what mechs can do. Heavys: Well armored and armed. Heavies are the bread and butter of the team, as they have the mobility and firepower to influence a match greatly. Most players play heavies for that purpose. Assaults: Heavily armored, and armed to the teeth. Playing a assault makes you a walking turret. You're supposed to tank damage and push for your team, as most players will follow you. If you get cold feet or are indecisive, don't play an assault. There's a ridiculous amount of awareness you need to play an assault well.

- Learning Curve -
The learning curve is steep. There are a ridiculous number of mechanics to keep note of. And a lot of them aren't explained at all in the game. I could type endlessly about it and probably not cover it all. But thankfully, there are various external informational outlets you can find to tell you about those. But for the most part, there's a lot to take in. So don't be intimidated by that fact. Just play and learn from your mistakes. Also, big tip: use the minimap and don't use 3rd-person view.

Give the game a shot, its a genre that's been overshadowed, and who doesn't like robots?

Also on a side note: PGI has done some shady stuff, so keep note of that if anything seems to be going south.

reviewText:
I have to recomend this game (sigh)
I have been playing it for about 3 years now. If I didnt recomend this game, I would feel bad for the last 3 years :P

Pro's

The mech's look amazing, and allot of the graphics are pritty good

PGI has really stepped up their game in map design, and allot of the new maps have depth.

The difference in playstyles of each mec can be vastly different, be it light, med, heavy, or assault.

Not all mechs are viable but allot of them are, so there isnt one or two mech's that are the best.
I
f you get onto a decent team, you will have alot of fun, dosnt matter if you want to do compeditive or just tool around in community warfare.

If you played WoT(World of Tanks) you will have a one up in this game being that they are very close in play style and form.

Cons:
The hitreg varies between the different weapons and is infuriating. Some times your damage numbers reflect exactly the work you put in, then other times it dosnt and then some time you get no hitreg and you dont even effect you target by shooting him/her...it. It is theorized that if you can have a ping of 120 consitantly you are in the sweet spot and your hitreg will be perfect, and that if you have a stable ping that dosnt vary allot, it will be even better.

The balancing of the game by PGI is real, they over balence them to try and make every weapon viable and nerf mechs just to make them less usefull, instead of realizing that they are only balancing the game into frustration.

The new player experience is very difficult. Most of us have been playing for several years, as such we have become really good at the game, figured out what mechs we are good at and are up on the current meta. new players arnt, and often get frustrated because the biggest and baddest mechs arnt nessessarly the best. once they figure that out, most of them have already sunk allot of cbills into bad mechs. Also the learning curve can be brutal and unforgiving, between knowing where to go on the map, to just maneuvering around in your mech.

Sticky walls that break your legs, and small rocks that keep your 100 ton mec from moving are just some of the frustrating things that can run you away from this game. It dosnt happen as often as it used to, but it still happens.

Finnaly the community, this community is the most loyal, and at the same time can be the most hateful. There have been and are allot to trolls, at the same time, a game can be won and lost by one person doing somthing really stupid. This is a team game, not a single player game, and is much more unforgiving than all other shooters. Your teamates rely on you not doing stupid things and staying with the team.

reviewText:
A totally solid Mechwarrior game.  While it does have issues such as a limited number of maps and game modes, it is clear that the developers want to expand the game greatly in terms of content and game experience.  There is already robust support for multiple playstyles.

The need to balance player experience with sellable content is obvious in a F2P game, and I feel the developers are making a fair and earnest effort to provide a great game for those on a budget while offering the big spender ways to part with their money without completely breaking the balance of the game.

All in all, the game art is beautiful and the game tries to adhere to Battletech lore insofar as is possible, so fans of armored combat" style shooters and Battletech fans alike should all be able to find something that keeps them coming back."

reviewText:
Edit: As people didnt seem to find my review all that useful (9 of 15 as of this edit), lets try to fix that.
Slower paced than hawken, much more unforgiving.  This is a thinking man's shooter; if you want to mindlessly kill things without any real skill involved, CoD is probably more up your ally.  Basically, you play a big ♥♥♥ stompy robot, loaded for bare and ready to ♥♥♥♥ up the nearest scrub to cross your path.  Think Gundam.

There are 4 mech weight classes in the game, Light, Medium, Heavy, and Assault.  There are many mechs of each weight class, just pick one that fits your playstyle.  Each weight class has a different purpose.

Lights act as nimble scouts/Assault killers/Fire support.  Lights are typically fast moving, highly mobile, low damage mechs.  GOTTA GO FAST!!!!

Mediums act as nimble fire support.  Mediums have a nice balance of weapons and speed to out manouver your enemies while still putting decent fire down range.

Heavies are your fairly hard to kill well armed mechs.  Heavies act as moderately mobile weapon platforms that you dont want to get in front of in a light.

Assaults are your heavily armored slow moving death machines that can kill you in a couple volleys, but get shreaded if a light gets behind them.

Pick a mech and and stick to your team like a sad lost puppy (especially if your buddies are bigger than you, give those ♥♥♥♥ers a hug).  If you're in a light/medium, use your heavy/assault buddies as human shields while plinking the enemies in their weak points (which vary).  Shoot anything that gets near your heavy/assault buddy  If you're in a heavy/assault, pick the nearest/most damaged enemy mech and pull all your triggers (plural ♥♥♥♥ing triggers).

When you shoot, your weapons ganerate heat (IT'S JUST LIKE REAL LIFE!).  Therefore you have to watch your heat generation and not just mindlessly fire your weapons into the abyss, you'll overheat.  Much like a computer when it overheats, you shut-the-♥♥♥♥ down, and damage your internal componets, leaving you vulnerable to enemy fire (as you cant dodge/shield the damage).  So, check yourself before you wreck yourself.  Lasers generate a lot of heat, but have infinite ammo.  Missiles generate moderate heat, but have limited ammo.  Ballistics generate low heat, but have very limited ammo.



Credentials:  I'm a veteran player (since beta) and I love this game from a PvP persepctive, it forces team cohesion and team play.  I almost always have a good time, even in defeat.  I have 1749 games on record (quick play games, not CW), given that ever match is about 10 minutes, that's 291 hours on record (just in match time, double/tripple that time if you count the time i've spent in the mechlab and CW).

This game used to take a bit of a beefy computer.  Optimization has improved tremendously in the past couple years.  I wasn't able to play much in beta or through initial release due to having a crappy PC, but i got a new computer about a year and a half ago and picked the game back up.  I was amazed by all the improvements made to the game in the time i was away, and I've been playing since.

The game has improved EXPONENTIALY since initial release, and it's only getting better since the Steam release.  Give it a shot, it just takes a few minutes and a little bandwith.

This game's community is phenominal, if you want to learn something, go check out some of the streamers or youtubers, especially NGNG (No Guts, No Galaxy).  If you have any questions about anything, multiple people will be happy to answer you in detail.  NGNG is the largest group of MWO content producers.  They're all good guys/gals that provide good content/informative content for the community.

NGNG YouTube:  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCfjiF6LH7fxeEoe8u6PONDA
NGNG Twitch:  http://www.twitch.tv/ngngtv/profile

Other Content Creators of interest (Check these dudes out if you're interested):

Everyone loves TheB33f
TheB33f YouTube:  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCmxv6LmrmYXZxX0mt-cNQiA
TheB33f Twitch:  http://www.twitch.tv/the_b33f/profile

Other Streamers with Quality content:
http://www.twitch.tv/angerbeard/profile
http://www.twitch.tv/thepanzermagier/profile
http://www.twitch.tv/watcherrat/profile
http://www.twitch.tv/escef/profile
http://www.twitch.tv/z0eff/profile

Any one of these content producers will happily help out new or returning players.  They often do charity streams and giveaways as good human beings.

If you want mech builds, check out: http://mwo.smurfy-net.de/ There is a ton of info there for building your mechs for success.

If lore is your fix, check out the wiki for everything battletech: http://www.sarna.net/wiki/Main_Page

Short explanation of some bad reviews:  Lots of the bad reviews come from unfulfilled promised of what the game was supposed to be.  The old publisher IGP (Infinite Game Publishing) was ruining what the devs PGI (Piranha Games Incorporated) was setting out to do.  This caused IGP to see the game as a flop and return the game rights to PGI.  Many of this game's founders and vereran players felt wronged by some of the actions forced upon PGI via IGP.  Since PGI broke away from IGP, the geme has been on an upward spiral in every respect.  IGP was a group of money grubbing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that wanted a flow of income from the game they had the rights to (to an extreme degree).  Many people are still butthurt over these things.

Intense Con:  Mechs are expencive with IRL money, keep in mind, this is a small developer making a very high quality game, and they have to eat too  (plus the Mechwarrior Community is a niche with many whales who will throw money at a develpower willing to make a game in the nearly dead franchise)

Potential Pros:  With the influx of new players from the Steam release, prices of things in game (IRL money) may become cheaper due to the larger player base.

PGI has hired many more people to work on the game (i caught this bit of info from on of the devs in a twitch stream chat)

The free to play model is actually not too bad, with 16 trial mechs each on rotation (that actually have good loadouts).  Back in beta, and early release, there were only 4 trial mechs with garbage ♥♥♥ loadouts.

You don't need to put any money into this game to have a good time, but hell, if you find that you're having lots of fun just with the trial mechs, toss $20 at the game, and get a mech or two.  If you enjoyed the game for many hours already, it's probably worth atleast a couple dollars.



TL;DR:  New players, give it a shot, it's free.  Old players, give it another shot, it WILL surprise you with all the improvements made since beta.

Edit:  I will happily answer any questions if it is not within my review, just leave a comment and i'll do my best to get back to you ASAP (assuming the question is something i can answer).

reviewText: First things first: I'm reviewing this game based on what it its now, not on what happened in the past or what it could have been.\nBe aware the devs made quite a few mistakes in the past and didn't hit all the goals they set when pitching the game for crowdfunding (which was to be expected, since the goals were quite exorbitant for such a small studio). They made mistakes in their communication with the playerbase. There is a vocal part of the (former) community which is very" disgruntled over these mistakes (and decisions they didn't like)
date: so take reviews with a grain of salt. When reading reviews or discussions be aware that there are some guys on a crusade to make this game fail. Furthermore many guys are wearing the thickest rose-tinted nostalgia glasses I have ever seen in any game series (regarding previous Mechwarrior games).\n\nI'm recommending this game. It isn't perfect
recommended: but it is better than many games on the F2P market. Take it for what it is: a tactical
hoursPlayed: slow paced

and the overall state of the game is better than ever.

probably best of any Mechwarrior title

- You can play this game without ever spending money (mechbays can be obtained in CW)

Mixed:

Cons:

Verdict:
Try it

reviewText: Mechwarrior Online is a worthy followup to its legendary predecessors, and the best large robot tactical action game on the market. It hits the rarely achieved sweet spot between first-person twitch gameplay and methodical strategy, combining extremely deep customization of beautifully brutal war machines with intense moment-to-moment combat. The pace of battle is somewhat less than the warp speed found in most first person shooters, allowing the player's tactical awareness and strategic creativity to come to the fore, in contrast to other games where raw reaction speed is king.\n\nThis more thoughtful pacing is consistent with the game's stylistic choices as well, which hew to a more traditionally western" aesthetic of plausible tank-like distopian death machines stomping across war torn cityscapes and dangerous alien worlds
date: in contrast to the glut of "Japanese" style lithe robots that dance across most videogames today.\n\nThe game's free-to-play economy has gone through various permutations before appearing here on steam
recommended: but has settled into a comfortable place
hoursPlayed: providing adequate resources to free players in normal play
voteText: along with increasingly generous special event prizes most weekends that prevent any "pay to win" problems. Additionally
helpfulPercent: they have reduced "XP" requirements to narrow the gap between old-hands and neophytes
votesHelpful: making this the best time for a new player to enter the arena since it's original closed beta launch. While the enormous variety of potential player customization makes balance devilishly tricky
votesTotal: the developers have consistently improved it over time
votesFunny: and managed to move it to a remarkably tight band that permits significant variety of viable playstyles.\n\nIn sum
commentsCount: I give this game my highest endorsement
column16: I have been playing it since closed beta and it is undoubtedly the strongest it has ever been."

reviewText: One of the best free-to-play games ever made. I've played since tabletop was the only way to get into a giant robot and obliterate other giant robots. Mechwarrior: Online has it all -- mech customization, epic battles, a huge star map upon which to battle and an active, dedicated community. The developer is top notch with excellent talent working for them and they've made something extraordinary. Many of us waited a very long time for this game and Mechwarrior: Online does not disappoint. The moment I was able to I bought the Legendary Founders pack and I've watched this game improve and grow since then into the glorious combat simulator the Battletech universe demands. Your game library is not complete without Mechwarrior: Online. This is a must play game.

reviewText: TLDR: This game is not newbie friendly, it's shallow and has pretty repeative gameplay, the Devs are as greedy as EA, Content comes out at a glacial pace and in small quantites for very high prices ( 4 mechs for 60+ USD) And it's only really fun to play in a player clan because if you go lone wolf and play random battles you'll get bored fast.\n\nSo, I've been a Mechwarrior fan since i was 5 playing Mechwarrior 2 Mercs on Windows 95 and i've played every Mechwarrior since and this game is probably my least favorite and  the most shallow It's hard to keep playing at a consistant pace. It kinda a bit in common with Battlefront and the developer is almost as greedy as EA. Great graphics with zero depth. it even has it's own version of EA style DLC  , you see, every time they add a new mechpack (at a glacial pace) they are first sold for real currency (for the price of a triple A game mind you 60+ USD) , then in game premium currency then you can finally buy it with regular credits after half a year.) this game is lucky it's the only Mechwarrior sim at the moment and they're squeezing us for every penny. Queue times are long for random battles and MM sometimes has a brainfart and gives one team a significant tonnage advantage. there also aren't many maps and the level of content you get for your money is very low. Playing random battles can be confusing for new players and can get stale fast , the tutorial only covers the very basics and the game has a steep learning curve so new players will not know how to make the best builds and will get outgunned by players running metabuilds. the only thing that keeps me playing is Community Warfare which is a competative mode where player clans join factions from the lore and fight against each other for planets and ultimately control of the Inner Sphere.  to sum this up i would not say this is a good game, with about 3 years of being online the amount this game developed is pretty pathetic especially when you see what kind of prices they charge for content. I'd only recommend this game if you're a diehard fan who can join a clan and i would urge you to seriously consider if you want to shell out the price of a triple A game for a couple of mechs.

reviewText:
Let's start simple. Try the game for yourself. I can only tell you that my experience with this game since 2012 has been good. That is my experience alone but you can make up your mind by trying it yourself.

Play the 25 matches for the in game currency to see if you truly like the game or not.

_______

Let's break this down into several components. Gameplay, UI, Graphics, Content, End Game.

Gameplay 8/10:
This game down to its core is a very fun game when you play it and learn it. Its an action shooter but it doesn't have the cartoon speed of some other FPS where you die after stubbing your toe on a bullet. No you can take a hit and if you are smart can survive for as long as you can. There's a sense of tactics in there somewhere. It's knowing when to attack, when to retreat, when to work with your team. You don't just run and gun and respawn.

That is just half the game to launch into a match though. The second half is to make and create your own mech builds. To be able to tinker and change a chassis to how you want to play and not some stock loadout. To own and change every mech that you can get. To collect and master all the mechs you want provided you get the mechbays you need.

It isn't perfect, balance could be better in regards to lesser used weapons. There could be more balance between the two major 'Factions' the Clans and the Inner Sphere.

Overall it feels like a fun game to play,

UI 7/10:
The first incarnation was terrible, the second incarnation horrific, and now we have this current '2.5' UI that has honestly been a success. There's a lot of clicking but in comparison to other games like say Armoured Warfare it isn't actually as bad as it use to be. A lot of information that needs to be presented to you is but there is room for improvement which will come.

What the game needs? UI Tooltips when you work in the Mechlab. UI for Mech Modules (Extra addons for mechs), and just quality of life improvements.

Overall the UI is not special but its not terrible.

Graphics 8/10:
Mechwarrior: Online is showing its age. It runs on a outdated engine that has high demands for less gains. We've seen the power and scale of CryEngine 3 as a FPS but it demands much more when you see 12 vs 12 Giant mechs that take up a lot more power to render. The graphics are however still quite amazing. The visuals of seeing your lasers, cannons, and missiles fire is amazing. You won't be disappointed by all the effects.

However you would want optimizations out of this game. It definitely needs to be optimized across the board.

Overall its a great visual overall but it isn't the type of visuals you would expect from some triple AAA title which you shouldn't anyways.

Content 8/10:
In my opinion the story is not rich but the lore behind it is. It leads into having a lot of room for content in the future. It already has hundreds of mechs to choose from which is the meat of the content. There's so much room for variety that it provides so much content already. Could it have more than just mechs? Yes.

I want to see more than just PvP Matches. It lacks in content that isn't just PvP.

Overall its still good but that leads into the last component.

End Game 5/10:
The end game is unfinished. Plain and Simple it is not done. It is an interesting Idea of a moving world but it just seems like a map and place to fight right now.

The future looks bright for it with new modes of play, the ability to use guild/faction/unit money to buy things with but its not there yet.
_________

Overall this game is 7.5/10 until more patches come out. I have some faith but it needs to be proven at this point.

reviewText:
Giant stompy robots. What more do you need?

Fair warning: the new player learning curve in this game is steep. Like 90 degree steep. Do yourself a favor and DO THE TUTORIALS. Run them until you're very familiar with how to handle yourself. You don't want to start a match off and get stuck running into a wall, getting you butt shott off, because you don't know to move your legs independantly from your torso.

Once you've mastered the basics then hop in and get ready to be shot up to pieces. You're probably going to lose right away - or at least get blasted pretty quick. Like I said, the learning curve is a wall. But if you can push through your initial deathfest and learn a few things in the process you might just have what it takes to start racking up the kills yourself.

This game is also F2P, and as far as free-to-play games go this one is pretty forgiving. The ONLY things you cannot purchase with game-grinded monies are additional mech bays (you start with 4), and Hero Mechs (honestly, nothing special. Just different varients of a chassis, none of which are amazing.) However, between monthly (or bi-monthly) events, contests, competitions and whatnot you can earn premium moneyz to buy those things, or earn them outright. So yeah. It's pretty forgiving.

That all said, I've spent over $200 on this free" game. FML."

reviewText:
INTRODUCTIONDon't get me wrong, I love mechs.  Even though the first mech combat game I played religiously was HAWKEN and FromSoftware's Armored Core series, I needed something more realistic.  That was when I stumbled upon MechWarrior Online.  Set in the BattleTech universe, MWO allows you to enter the BattleTech universe and fight in the Clan Invasion of the 31st Century.  It took me a while to learn the ropes, and now, I'm ready to post a review about it.

THE PROS:+Community Warfare, where you can pick one of the many factions of the Battletech universe, and fight against other factions.  This mode was the most enjoyable one for me, since it led to the most intense and team-driven battles at times.
+Excellent customization.  You can swap weapons, add heat sinks, and adjust armor on your mech, and it's only limited by the maximum weight of your mech (and your in-game credits which you earn from battles, of course!).
+The damage system.  If your mech takes too much damage to the arm, it might lose the arm, and the weapons attached to it.  If your mech's leg becomes too damaged, you move at a slower pace.  If you lose both legs, the torso or get hit in the cockpit, your mech is destroyed.  This, in my opinion, is much better than having a health bar, seeing how it makes it much more intense.

THE CONS:-It has a learning curve.  If you're looking for something to play casually, than this isn't really going to be your first choice.  You have to manage heat and ammunition in battle, as well as watching your damage, which can make the game difficult to learn.
-Getting new mechs takes a while.  Mechs cost millions of in-game credits, and you only earn 100 thousand or so per match, so it may take a while unless you're willing to pay real money, or sell off one of your mechs.  I wouldn't consider this a pay-to-win game though, because you can certainly get a mech by earning in-game currency, however, it may take some time before you can get a high-end one.

FINAL RATING: 3.5/5
If you're looking for a good mech combat game, this is worth a try.

reviewText:
So... I don't like FPS games in general. Hey - come to think of it, I barely like any games.
But, I like this one. I've played it for nearly two years, practically every day.
Two reasons:

1) You are part of a team.
Sometime your team is a blessing, sometime it's a curse. The game is unforgiving and does not keep tabs - make the wrong choice of 'mech or loadout, forget about where the team is and what they're doing, play in a match of random players doing all kinds of funny (bad) stuff - one misstake (yours or a team mate's) and you're out. Cry and moan every way you want about the outcome of the match or the performance of your team, but there's always something YOU could have done better  or better communicated with someone else about.
Every now and again you have nothing to do with the outcome of a match - learn to live with it!

2) It's Battletech(tm).
Yes - It lacks some of the elements seen in previous titles in the franchise. It also is better than previous titles at other things. The last year, I've seen improvements in development I never would have thought possible when I started playing. There's also a lot of great improvements in the roadmaps, which I hope will adress many of the current shortcomings.
I know many care about what have been and what will come. Me, I just play the hand I was dealt - Adopt, and have fun.

reviewText: Free 2 Play - but you have to pay with your soul. Easily the most addicting game I've played yet. Nothing quite puts a smile on my face like powering up your mech at the start of the round. If you like tactical shooting games that require some thinking this is the game for you. It's very similar in game play to WoT, however it's nothing like the horrible money pit that p2w game was. However, some rigs might have issues. I have a 3930k and a gtx 980 (all under water in a custom loop), and I have some serious problems with crashing. Reformatted to windows 7 (from windows 10) fixed some issues. Rolling back to the 390.00 drivers fixed some other issues. I still get the occasional crash and restart into black screen but it doesn't stop me from putting 14-16+ hours into the game every day.\n\nOverall, I would highly recommend the game, and if you would like some free premium time to get started please drop by my stream @ twitch.tv/phone_microwave - New players are always welcomed and questions are encouraged!

reviewText:
As a long time HAWKEN fan, I avoided this game as I constantly heard pay to win and outlandish mech pricing claims.

Having just started playing, one thing I can say is this is no Hawken and I was wrong to draw comparisons. This is much more of a simulation experience and not a FPS - in the style of something like Elite: Dangerous or World of Tanks. It has a slow, deliberate pace focusing on the strength of the unit and not the individual.

It's deep and complex but once you buy and outfit your first mech (which can be done straight away) you absolutely can compete with those who have been playing since the beta. A few novice light mechs can take down or disable any Behemoth, if they work together and target the right areas.

If you're a big badass robot fan like me who was really skeptical about about Mechwarrior Online, now's the time to give it a try. It's not perfect and the interface is pretty clunky but on the battlefield, where it counts, Mechwarrior Online is the game we all remember.

reviewText:
For a start, I am not a newcomer to MWO or the battletech universe. I know quite abit about lore, the mechwarrior series and battletech.
At first I wasnt much into MWO though. But I kept casually playing the game because I liked the mech combat.
I can tell you the game has improved much over time and PGI keeps going.

Overall what I like most about this game is the customization in the mechlab. You can spend hours thinking about possible builds and how they might work out in the game, then go for a test run just to be back in the mechlab after 1 game.
Many possiblitites to play the game and pretty much any mech is viable depending on your piloting skills.

If I should point out a negative it would be that balance is still shifting. Considering the amount of mechs and weapons though that shouldnt be too surprising and currently MWO is in its most balanced state. All weapons, with exception to flamers and maybe MG, have a role in the game. I think its up to  you to find out what mech and weapon you think might suit your style.

This game is far from perfect but it has a caring community and developers willing to listen to its community (which has led to some people even thinking they listen too much to us...). Great gameplay and options for most play styles and the design of the mechs kept me hooked onto to game, so I suggest that everyone can give this game a shot, its f2p afterall.

reviewText:
Download and play if:
-you played a MechWarrior game before
-you like strategic shooters
-you are a fan of simulation games
-you like driving a tank but can't relate because it doesn't have legs like you
-you are cool with losing a big portion of your time to reading strategies and thinking about this game
-you can work together with 11 other people for ten minutes at a time

We all know you have to grind" your way through f2p titles
date: but there isn't another game that makes you forget instantly that you are "grinding" anything.  Playing Quick Play over and over again to work out your masteries on a chosen 'Mech is just fun.  Your first 20 matches gives you an insane amount of money to buy just about any 'Mech you want
recommended: and depending on what class and chassis you pick
hoursPlayed: you can even get your three variants to achieve mastery.\n\nHere's how not "grindy" the grind is: I played my first 17 hours and bought three heavy 'Mech variants
voteText: and achieved mastery of them without getting bored at all.  In fact
helpfulPercent: every match that I start
votesHelpful: every time I click Quick Play
votesTotal: every time the oh-so-familiar 'Mech computer says "weapons online
votesFunny: sensors online
commentsCount: all systems nominal" I get goosebumps like I'm that kid I was back in 1995 when I first played MechWarrior 2
column16: or when I saved my lunch money instead of buying lunch in middle school so that I could buy MechWarrior 4 in 2000.\n\nThere is near limitless fun you can have just jumping in with Quick Play without ever giving PGI a dime.  Seriously there is not any reason someone who casually wants to shoot big robots in a walking tank would need to spend money.  But once you start finding yourself reading guides
column17: learning strategies
column18: working through your masteries on your first three 'Mechs
column19: something will change.  You'll probably buy a 'Mech bundle
column20: which somehow feels ok

reviewText:
This game is ridiculously fun. Giant robots blasting giant robots, not sure how that's bad? I would like to see some of the game modes refined, and the community warfare to have some more depth added, but this is a free game that lets you hop in a 100 ton battlemech and blast other battlemechs.

The mech designs are awesome, the maps are pretty good for the most part, there are very real differences between how the different weight classes of mechs play, but all can be effective. I just finished a game in a 50 ton medium mech (CENTURION) with top damage for the match and won a free mech. Also, the laser sounds are soooooooo good. WUB WUB WUB. PEW PEW PEW.

I usually play outside of steam (I started with the steam release, but the game works better outside of steam for some reason?) hence my low time played. I've got maybe 100 hrs at this point.

Super fun.

reviewText:
QUICK REVIEW:
If you're looking for a fast paced FPS mech shooter this isn't the game for you. STOP READING

If you enjoy teamwork and stratagy focused game with some simulation elements this is the game you been looking for! Cont. reading...

It's a great fun game once you grasp it! I've played it off and on for 3 years. It requires good communication, situational awareness, and methodical thinking.

ADVICE:
My advice use the tutorial and practice in the Mech Academy and the Mech Lab for the first few days. Look at the controls and button mappings. Try out different Trial Mechs BEFORE YOU BLOW YOUR CADET AND TRAINING BONUS! Think of your play style check out the guides on YouTube, in the forums, and here
http://mwomercs.com/game then buy and build your mech.

The game does have grind that is curved by spending money after all it is the F2P model. But if you follow the advice above the grind won't be so bad because you didn't jump the gun and buy the wrong mech before you found your play style.

PROS/CONS:
Pros:
-Solid gameplay
-Robots
-3D cockpits
-Customization
-Hard Working Dev Team
-Continually updated product
-Never ending updated mech roster coming to the game

Cons:
-Steep learning curve
-Not as new player friendly
-Lacks Campaign / Co-Op

INFORMATION YOU SHOULD KNOW:
Features to being worked on / added:
-Comunity Warfare phase 3
-Single / Co-Op Campaign
-Decal mech customization
-More balance passes (these won't ever stop)
-VR HTC Vibe and Oculus Rift support
-Map and model updates and makeovers (Ongoning process)
-Dynamic Weather in game

Things being considered TBD:
-CryEngine Update and DX12
-Collisions (Knockdowns / Physics)

reviewText:
TL;DR - It's not perfect, but it's my perfect.

First off, my credentials to write this review: I've been a fan of Battletech and Mech based games and shows in general since I first picked up MechAssault for the Xbox around 12 years ago and shortly thereafter fell in love with the MechCommander games for PC and have been a giant stompy robot lover since.  I've also purchased every top package for MechWarrior Online from Legendary Founders through the latest unseen mechs and have probably sunk about 300+ hours of play time into this title before the steam launch and have been playing since beta.

Ok, on to the review: MechWarrior Online has had it's rough points in the past and it's still not entiely perfect.  The graphics aren't mind blowing.  The in game music basically has to be supplied by you running an old mechwarrior OST in the background.  The camos and paints are overpriced.  The cockpit items are cheesy and borerline immersion breaking.  The UI is inherently flawed.  The gameplay can be repetitive on certain maps.  The default keys and some of the game options are questionable.  Some of the warhorns can be headache inducing.  And the power level difference from a new mech to a mastered" mech with modules and a custom build is a vast bottomless chasm.

However
date: it is fun.  The community is fantastic.  The in game chat is professional.  The devs do listen and are trying.  The redone maps are fantastic.  The selection of mechs is excellent.  The weapon and chassis balance is a lot better than it used to be.  The customisation is awesome.  The gameplay is tactical and skill based.  And finally the feeling you get from coring a mech with your last salvo while limping and with only one arm barely hanging on is unparalleled.  I have experienced some of my favourite gaming memories from this title and I don't regret a moment of it.\n\nI have no doubt there are both positive and negative points about this title that I've failed to mention
hoursPlayed: there's probably things I have never encountered having not played through the "new player" or f2p experience.  But I've had fun with it and if you're a fan of Battletech or of giant stompy robots in general then I'm sure you will too.\n\nOne more thing
voteText: if you're just getting into the game here are some basic tips:  Fight from the cockpit
helpfulPercent: unlock your arms
votesHelpful: torso twist when you're reloading
votesTotal: use double heat sinks
votesFunny: assign left click = left arm
commentsCount: right click = right arm
column16: side mouse buttons = torso weapons
column17: press R to lock target
column18: remap shift to full zoom
column19: set your FOV to 0.75
column20: concentrate fire
column21: stick with the team and watch your heat.\n\nWith that all said
column22: I hope you found this at least a little informative and it helps you out with deciding whether or not this is the game for you.\n\nGood luck
column23: Mechwarriors."

reviewText:
Mechwarrior Online has been a regularly played game of mine for 3 1/2 years now.  I enjoy it because the mech customization and uniqueness is very good and that translates into many different potential play-styles.

I continue to play because it is a game that still has the ability to give me an adrenaline rush and white-knuckle game-play occasionally on those close or come-from-behind matches.

It is a tactical shooter and rewards a good sense of awareness and the ability to work as a team.

Community Warfare is fun, although there isn't much of a lasting effect of winning or losing a Community Warfare match, but that system is being continuously worked on and there are some big changes being made that will improve the system.

I recommend this game if you prefer a more tactical, unit-based shooter where you generally must work together with others to be most effective.

reviewText: MechWarrior Online... Man, this game is the mech simulator where you can pilot the robot and use weapons wisely, because they're limited. Like HAWKEN, mechs are shown in 4 classes: Light, Medium, Heavy and Assault (HAWKEN has only 3 classes). However, unlike HAWKEN, the mechs have the height differences depending on classes. Trial mechs are usable, but you can't modify them (like in HAWKEN again). You can buy mechs and modify by replacing lasers, SRMs, LRMs and stuff. Also, unlike HAWKEN, you can upgrade your pilot skills beside mech skills. In Faction Play you can join the faction you want to. You can get along with your faction to attack or defend the planet from occupying factions. About mech cosmetics, it needs MC (MechWarrior Credits) which you can get by real money. The game is hard and challenging, the starters with no skills will get killed easily, but challenge excites you, right? ;) I will recommend this game for those who really want to pilot the real mechs. Only Reality! Only Hardcore! Only MechWarrior Online! =D

reviewText:
I've been a fan of the BattleTech Universe for over 20 years.  I've played many iterations and versions of the games.  I've enjoyed decided that this is the best I've played in a long time.

This game is a Free-to-Play game, with in-game purchases available.  However, it's perfectly playable without spending anything.  It puts you in the cockpit of a giant robot weighing anywhere from 20 to 100 tons.

The game does take a little bit to get used to.  I found I had to reprogram the default keys to match my playstyle better.  Once I did that, I found myself doing much better.  There is a plethora of guides and tutorials available as well as a large number of communities.

Give it a chance.  If you're into this genre, you won't be dissapointed.

reviewText:
I want to start off my being clear that I'm a returning founder who left the game initially because of problems with balance, meta, and PGI's inability to deliver.

I picked the game back up again about a month ago, figuring i'd get in, check out CW, and lose interest within a day or two.  And to be honest, i still feel like i could lose interest any time now.

For better or worse, this is not a direct port of TT.  To be hoenst TT had some mechanics in it that were just not suited to real time simulation.

PROS
The mech models are really good.  There are some technical issues with some models (hit boxes, scaling), but i think that on the whole, the mech models are in good shape.

We got the Unseen showing up.  While the mech modles are altered, they are still immediately recognizeable.

Most of the weapon and component implementations make sense when ported over from TT

Community is generally less toxic than most others (That said, this is a team-based game and people do ge frustrated when people ignore attempts to organize in match)

The number of mechs now available makes it less likey that during drops (at least in the lower 3 tiers) you will encounter  cookie-cutter meta teams.

CONS

Ballistic weapons aer still just a hair to accurate.  While rounds drop in flight, they don't really seem to deviate in any other way.

Some of the weapon conversions are just badly implemented:  A 5 second cool down on gauss rifles, then charge time before you can fire, which really adds up to a double-lencgth cooldown

Clan implementation was just baddly handled, and it still causes gameplay and balance problems

Gameplay/Mech balance issues can take some time resolve, and are sometimes knee-jerk reactions (Ask a veteran about tackling)

Community Warfare just isn't ready yet.


All in all, despite having some issues, the game does have promise, and is fun most of the time.  There are some changes coming up in the immediate future that address some of the outstanding issue and open up more content for Community Warfare.

So with all of that, for now, yes, I'd reccomend it, because you can get damn near everything out of the game without spending any money, though obviously people who spend the money get access to new chasis sooner.
