reviewText:
I know I haven't played too long, but I thought I would lend my first impressions after my first foray into Mechwarrior Online.  I think I can honestly say it has delivered so far on most of my expectations.  There's still quite a bit more for me to do as I haven't even ventured into the Faction campaign part of the game.

To start at the beginning, this game appears to actually be free to play.  I have yet to run into anything other than a few mech variants and some minor cosmetic stuff that requires real money to acquire.  The game is still completely playable without paying a cent however.

The sheer number of mechs to choose from is excellent.  And, I hear new ones are added regularly as well.  There are several variants of each mech, allowing you to choose one that suits your play style.  And if you can't find one that is quite perfect, then you have the option to purchase and then customize one.  The customization options are absolutely excellent giving anyone the ability to tweak and change their mech to their liking.  The only thing to realize is that there is a bit of a learning curve when it comes to the different mech variants and their different hard point configurations when mounting weapons.

Matches are typically fast paced and engaging.  The maps are detailed and quite well designed (well, most of them).  Each one contains a lot of neat features to provide cover or execute complex tactical maneuvers.  I've only been caught in a few matches where things seem to drag on and on, but thankfully each match has a time limit.

And I must say, this is so far, the first MMO I have played with a focus on PvP where the userbase isn't a bunch of angry teenagers foaming at the mouth whenever someone steps one foot out of place or not using some specific mech type or weapon type, etc.  I think I may have encountered maybe one, possibly two players that felt it necessary to add snarky parting remarks as they left the match after the team lost, but out of around 100 matches so far, and with exposure to hundreds of other players, I think 2 are tollerable.  At least in the quick matches, I have yet to feel the same vitriol as when I would PvP in games like WoW or Rift.

All in all I'm pretty excited by this game and look forward to the parts that I still have yet to play.  A big thumbs up from me!

EDIT:  So here I am about a month later and I still haven't participated in Community Warfare.  Quick matches are still quite a lot of fun as there are a lot of different mechs to try, not to mention all of the possible variations of each one to test.  Besides, I'm hearing that Community Warfare isn't very PUG friendly and many times skill really matters (it's not that I don't think I have the skill.... I doubt that others do in a PUG).  I suppose that would be my one complaint about the game so far is that Community Warfare isn't very friendly to solo players.  I know I'm inviting the wrath of the MWO veterans when I say that, but my only response to those individuals is that times are changing, the game is on Steam now where there is a large population of solo/casual players, and anything PGI could do to make the ENTIRE game available to those players would probably be in their best interests.  This, considering they came to Steam to increase the user base to begin with.

reviewText:
How i got to MWO? - SKIP it if you dont like personal introductory stories. Or else be my guest.
I was looking through my games while moving and then i remembered I had a MW 4 - Vengeance CD somewhere. Didnt find it though but then I had an idea. Lets look it up on the interwebs. I found out no MW4 Vengeance around anymore so I read somewhere there was a MW ONLINE and then researched and did a very scientific survey - nah, just kidding - no survey but i really got excited and tried it out - Failed so badly that i tried more and more and after a couple of months MWO was my thing. I am in a very eligible unit but lawschool means sooooo much playtime while exams.

Joined the battle February 2015.
My Steam playtime doesnt represent my actual play time.
I joined in on steam and do play on both the MWO Client and Steam Client.

Have seen some changes til then and mostly they have been well received.
*Mostly been playing quickplay and just got into community warfare - faction play lately so this review is quickplay originated.
AND I am not going to talk about pug play because i am a pug myself. My experience is heavily positive but sometimes i encounter people that cause me to lose my temper.
Because it has gone under changes various times i dont recall that much of em.

*The ones i remember are the mechlab changes which now provide a good overview at everything. positive.

*I definitely am a fan of the c-bill grinding but that only goes perfectly with premium time.
So long i have been investing in the hero and champion mechs meaning i spent money in this f2p concept. - kinda negative.
*I dont regret spending money on premium content but i figured it would be a little better if the game didnt have the mc thing going. This then would mean that without veterean founders the game might not even have made its release.
So thank you veteran founders. You da real mvps out there.

*if sales are going on - buy as much as possible especially if you get to win mc from events definitely spend em on mechbays. - definitely positive.
*Also getting into faction play and achieving higher ranks will get you the MC and free Mechbays necessary. dont say no to free stuff ;)
-BUT its very hard at the beginning even with the Cadet-bonus. At least that was my experience back in the day. - negative.
THEREFORE definitely get to know other players and play together. We are a newbie friendly community and we'll help.

-I am kinda upset that there arent any champions or hero mechs available for c-bills. There should have been just a couple heros/champs for c-bills at least. I am looking forward to every event and sale.
You need to invest some serious amount of time and therefore
it gets really addicting - you ll spend your day playing and playing and playing.

Remember to drink and eat and sleep enough.

reviewText:
Long before this game started on Steam, or was even talked about being a part of the Steam Community, I've played since Beta, back in 2010. For close two and half years, PGI struggled under the yoke of Infinite Game Publishing, And much to Russ Bullock and Company's credit, they have done a superb job. By first, buying themselves out from under IGP and going on their own. It's Piranha Games is a small company with little or no experience, and for most companies, that's a death's knell. Most would close their doors and fade off into the gaming world sunset, but PGI has prevailed.

MechWarrior has a long standing tradition of rich gameplay and diverse community. Small that it may be, but even the smallest game can be the biggest of giants. And MechWarrior is no exception. I can still recall playing NetMech and going head to head with people using a dial up internet system, where the computers were as big as coffee table books and games were played from a Floppy disc. Yes, it shows my age, but still I have played this game since that time and its many titles: MechWarrior 2, MechWarrior 2: Mercenaries, and MechWarrior 2: Ghost Bears Legacy; MechWarrior 3 and MechWarrior 3: Pirates Moon; MechWarrior 4: Vengeance, Black Knight and Mercenaries, and now a total, but competely new version of the Franchise- MechWarrior Online.

I have loved this game since I first played the Table top version, where I chose the BattleMaster to play with using nothing but dice and paper and paperboard cutouts to simulate warfare in the 31st Century. Too many times in the past with those that I mentioned above I wondered. . . when? When will I see those legends again: the Marauder, Archer, WarHammer, Rifleman, Stinger, Wasp, my BattleMaster, my Executioner [Gladiator]. When will they return? My faith in both Russ and PGI as well as patience has paid off.

The Legends are returning, first with Project Phoenix `Mech Package, consisting of: BattleMaster, Thunderbolt, Griffin, Wolverine, Locust, and Shadow Hawk have returned to the honored faithful, and soon, the other legends of the BattleTech World will make their debut. The Marauder released on Dec. 1, has become a steady favorite to the new players. The WarHammer will see its release on January 16th, and the Rifleman will soon follow it on Feb. 16, and the Archer is set for release some time in March [this is just a guess. Nothing is set as of my writing this review]/ But what a great time to join! Soon on Dec. 15th, Origins IIC package will see a full release of all four Clan Second-Line `Mechs: Highlander, Hunchback, Jenner and Orion `Mechs, will be getting the Clan Treatment. How can one not want to join?! I ask this time and time again.

As for those out there whom have said that MechWarrior is a dying game. One might want to rethink that. For no one person can foresee the future, and tell the demise of another. MechWarrior will come to its end when the time and effort have all but gone. When that will be is anyone's guess. As for me, I will continue to play till time has called me to go home and leave this plane of existence.

There are many reasons in why someone would want to play this game. I'll start with these:

COMMUNITY

As I said above, there are many games that come and go, and few stay the test of time. What sets them apart from those that do last a lifetime like MechWarrior, is the following they garner over that time. Thirty years is a long time for one game. And yes, it's a lifetime of years. And yet, with a Community like MechWarrior has, the game still exists. True. League of Legends, War Craft, Star Craft, and even EVEOnline have great communities, but none of them have garnered a lifetime of fans and player like MechWarrior. Except for Star Trek and Star Wars, both which have their fandom and support, they are the only games I know of that comes close, or even better than, MechWarrior. I'm not bad mouthing the game. Rather, I'm only comparing them to this game. Those games, War Craft/Star Craft, have only been around for a few years, and maybe more than ten at best. Star Wars, Star Trek, and MechWarrior have been around a lot longer, and all three have their fans to their credit. It would not suprise me in the least if Robotech jumped on board and entered the Online Gaming World. Cause like MechWarrior/BattleTech, and many know the history between the two properties, it too has a large majority of support.

CUSTOMIZATION

Another reason for joining this: Customizing A Machine of War. Not many games have this ability, and many have tried to copy what MechWarrior has to offer when it comes to gigantic machines of war. And yet, they failed to live up to that promise. Think of it this way: if one has played BattleTech, then one will know where I coming from with this. No other game I know of allows for changing out weapons to fit ones play style or fits into their idea of fun. MechWarrior offers that. We all have our favorites, and mine I stated above. For the Inner Sphere: it's the BattleMaster. For the Clans: No doubt, the Gladiator. Between the two, the Gladiator affords me more of opportunity to make a machine that'll make Russ lose his knickers in a less than a heartbeat. True. I can switch weapons on the BattleMaster, but with Galdiator, aka Executioner, it gives me tens tons more and has a pod space of 26.5 tons. Which is not too shabby. I can make a war machine with Autocannons and Lasers.

That's makes this game so unique. It gives players a chance to make any combination of weapons, even with Meta builds, and then take said machine into the playing, and own or get owned by another with the same concept. Not many games I know of can do this, except EVEOnline, but it's not MechWarrior. True. EVEOnline offers the opportunity to make a machine of war. However, it's not a game of gigantic war machines with a massive chip on their shoulders looking to kick someone's metallic ♥♥♥♥ straight to hades and back again. If one wants to build a ship with long research and skill training over a long period of time. . . EVE Online is the game for that someone. If one wants to go out in a simulated blaze of glory and owning someone else's ♥♥♥♥ with a machine that has a massive chip on its shoulder. . . then one has found it in MechWarrior.

PLAY ABILITY

As I said Before, not many games stand the test of time, and few have lasted as long as MechWarrior has. Not even World of Tanks can compare itself to MechWarrior. Even though, like MechWarrior, the game has the same play ability and fun aspect as MechWarrior, it can't allow one to customize a machine the way MechWarrior can. That's the attraction for this game is the play ability, and that lies in the means to make and change around the weapons to fit any and all situations that one may find themselves in. Sure EVE offers that, but going around space looking for action, mining one asteroid after another, researching and earning skills, and droning about from one of space to another, is not the same as MechWarrior.

Only MechWarrior offers the means to go and get into the action quickly, and yes, World of Tanks has this as well. Yet ask this: can you switch our a 122mm D-25T gun off an IS-3? Sure, but if one grinds the points necessary to get another gun. Here, one does not need to research anything or make a character, and go mine, build, and claim a part of space as their own. Or drive some tank into a battle and hope that one does better than the other players. Plus one does not need to use a Mod of any sort to become a better player.

Now all I ask is this: what are you waiting for? JOIN UP. Make this legendary game come to life, and enjoy the time of playing a great and wholesome game.

I am James Edward Crego, aka Hawk819 of the Second Federated Suns Armored Cavalry, and I and my unit, invite any and all players to join this game, and have a great time playing it. Take care, and Godspeed. <Salute>

reviewText:
I have over 11,000 matches played in this game, and way too many hours invested. I obviously enjoy it.

The pros of this game? You get to run big stompy robots. I love the history and background of this game. I enjoy the fact that the meta has shifted now and then, it makes me relearn various aspects. The mechbay and design of mechs, the optimizing of builds, understanding weapon ranges and timing, all of it is enjoyable. The marketing says thinking man's shooter. People that are not terrible at this game know that to be true. That said, there are plenty of dumbasses with terrible builds as well..

The cons? This game is developed by a small company. They have limited resources. Promised additions and fixes come slowly. They have to focus attention on money making content to keep their business open, and sometimes that trumps adding fun content like game modes or user interface improvements.

The neutral? Game balance has been a rocky road. The tabletop game this adapts was balanced in a way that didn't translate to a real time shooter. They have made slow akward attempts at balance, and the game is in a decent state at the moment. The developers of this game have been historically really bad at their own game, and hesitant to listen to the top tier players. They recently have been playing more in queue, and have joined some tournaments. Their game knowlege in the real playerbase is growing, and I believe that is helping the balance work.

The future? With hopes that we can grow this community via new steam users, I hope that this game can make some money so that staff can be added, and playing modes expanded. I really want to see Faction Warfare fleshed out, and a campaign mode added, and player base expansion will support that. The game desperately needs some more good players. Hopefully the balance is decent enough to retain those type of people at this point.

I'll be here shooting stompy robots for a long time. Hopefully you will be too.

reviewText:
As a long time HAWKEN fan, I avoided this game as I constantly heard pay to win and outlandish mech pricing claims.

Having just started playing, one thing I can say is this is no Hawken and I was wrong to draw comparisons. This is much more of a simulation experience and not a FPS - in the style of something like Elite: Dangerous or World of Tanks. It has a slow, deliberate pace focusing on the strength of the unit and not the individual.

It's deep and complex but once you buy and outfit your first mech (which can be done straight away) you absolutely can compete with those who have been playing since the beta. A few novice light mechs can take down or disable any Behemoth, if they work together and target the right areas.

If you're a big badass robot fan like me who was really skeptical about about Mechwarrior Online, now's the time to give it a try. It's not perfect and the interface is pretty clunky but on the battlefield, where it counts, Mechwarrior Online is the game we all remember.

reviewText:
I've played this one since the open beta and really enjoy the combination of tinkering with the mech you bring into battle and the slightly slower pace of gameplay as a fairly tactical shooter (the mechanics mean you take quite a few hits to die in game which, in turn, slow things down a bit). There is a good range of different successful gameplay tactics and a huge range of customisable different mechs you can bring to a fight.

After several teething issues (pre-steam, so don't worry) game balance is now pretty good between the two main factions (inner sphere" and "clan") and the online population are fairly friendly in a wallaby-name-calling sort of fashion (see Gh1d0ra's review later!).

The "storyline" part of the game
recommended: is fun with much more structured in-game challenges. However as it is pretty much "end game" content
hoursPlayed: it works best as part of a pre-organised team (lots of these accessible via the MWO website community links) and needs a top-line mech.\n\nIt's main limitations are the initial learning curve and a limited number of maps and game types. Hopefully the developers will continue to respond to this in the next few months. Personally
voteText: I'm really hoping for some sort of intermediate gameplay between the random quickplay maps and the involved CW game (some sort of FFA deathmatch tournament would be great...)\n\nAll-in-all

reviewText:
Mechwarrior Online fulfills one of my childhood dreams.

If you are averse to Mech combat, stop reading now; this game will only frustrate you.

Imagine being a knight of a noble house in medieval times, a wayward ronin from fuedal Japan, or a faithful templar during the crusades. These are common themes in Mechwarrior. Also Boba Fett.

Mech-Nerds Rejoice! The O.G. Mech-Daddy has returned! IF you loved Mechwarrior 3050, (No not Super-Nintendo or Genesis, the one for the PC from the era of Lara Croft's Polygon Pyramidoid Breasts.) get ready to POOP with joy. Be warned, some may POOP displeasure and POP anuerism during their first foray into the jungle that is Mechwarrior Online.
Grinding your favorite chassis into ultra bad-assery takes time and commitment!

Some, either out of fondness or frustration refer to it as a 'Thinking Man's Shooter.'
You will be forced to comprehend an insidious heat management concept.
If you like to run and gun, you may not enjoy this style of FPS.
You will be expected to learn and manage new factors beyond your usual method of 'Finding the Best Hiding Spot!', 'Shooting the other guy First!', or 'Getting the Missile Launcher before the other team!'

Some people's weapons and robots will be blatantly superior to yours either by virtue of chassis-weight or commitment level. You will be RENT and PWNT freeborn, keep your wits about you. You are not limited to holding the bomb or not holding the bomb anymore. Roles are diverse and they feel and play differently. You may find yourself scouting and painting targets, the paltry armament on your Light Mech won't stand a chance against that nasty Assault Mech's opening salvo!
Don't feel like running and gunning this round? That's fine, change the loadout for your CPLT-A1  Catapult chassis in order to sit calmly, one handed, safely behind your ironclad bretheren and launch LRM-15 MISSILES while your jittery little friends run around and light up targets for you! Inner Sphere and Clan missiles look and behave differently. Woah.. Just like the tabletop. Such Purist. Much Diligence. Wow.

If you are fat and slow, we welcome you; here's an ULTRA-AC 20 friend! Don't forget fat guy, your usual reliance on the 'dependable center screen reticle' logic that you have wielded with great efficacy for years to point and shoot is a CURSE, that Ultra-AC 20 is mounted on your TORSO YOU BUFFOON!! So why are you firing on the enemy with the circular hand-mounted reticle???

If you can't stop moving? We want you; take these NARCS with you little one.. Reveal our mightiest foes to us so that we may blasteth upon them with Particle Projector canons and PULSE lasers. Although we sincerely hope you remembered to drop some weight off that chasis and put more armor onto those little chicken legs of yours in between matches... No don't take that Trebuchet, pilot the Cicada instead you knucklehead.

If you are sick to damn death of that little guy buzzing around you and you havn't yet maxed out your pilot skills for torso twist, go ahead and pop a U.A.V. for the one-handed guy in back, or drop an Air-Strike! You aren't limited by your own lack of comittment after all!

Play your way! You can brawl, you can snipe, you can 'pop tart'. Yes you can pop-tart. You can run, you can jump, you can FLY! You can POWER DOWN your giant 100 ton weapon of war in protest and NOT PARTICIPATE IF YOUR TEAM IS A JERK! No I swear I've never done it but I've seen it done, and it's hilarious, and yes I was hiding but not because I wanted to, I was looking at my mini-map and saw my teammate there and thought we would team up but it turns out the guy was TOTALLY CHICKEN and powered down because the team sucked, so I stayed and watched him in his powered down state and survived the carnage. But I have NEVER and would NEVER power down and give up! I just didn't feel like going and dying that time because...
You can suicide Eject! You can overheat repeatedly and MELT YOURSELF.

Careful dude, you totally just blew up a teammate.. I only laughed a little bit and that was because my cat was tickling me at that exact moment in time, and it was totally obnoxious of you to Alpha Strike salvo our Dire Wolf right in the ♥♥♥, I would never condone such behaviour.

Possessed of a rich mythos which has spawned numerous novels, audiobooks, toys, and even a 90's television series, the Battletech franchise certainly isn't lacking in terms of it's robust immersion, diverse factions, cultures, aliens, beasts! Robots! TANKS! PLANES! STARSHIP SPACE BATTLEFLEET ARMADAS!... All rooted in a believable flavor of our own milkyway galaxy called 'The Inner Sphere', which means you don't have to be a science-fiction nerd in order to subscribe to this universe. There is even an Earth!
In fact, you might love it as much as that other lore-rich game that you play!
Imagine 'America's Answer to Warhammer 40,000.' and you are halfway there.

You may find yourself trolling  Sarna.net [sarna.net] just like you do Wookiepedia in order to figure it all out.

If you loved Mechwarrior 3050? Welcome Home! I would and could pitch this game to any of you personally and you still wouldn't play it because it is that niche! Woah.. But this is like, the sickest game ever dudes!

The pay model is a miserable mire of misery and ramen and shame. Beware.. These guys probably make more than most publishers out there, and nobody even plays their game! They're that niche. woah..

Pardoning the critiques, this game rules.
Okay fine, this is like my favorite game dude, when I'm bored with everything else; I'm definitely playing this. I would rather die incredulously from some freeborn scum's hacktastic salvo than on the john. There are rumors of a campaign in progress!

With friends that actively built, painted, and occasionally played the table top role-playing game 'Battletech' in the early ninties, owning a small collection of figurines myself, most of the classic 'Technical Readout' glossy-back publications with the nifty specs and drawings of various Clan and Inner Sphere mechs, I am no stranger to the world that spawned the 'Mechwarrior' franchise.
Having a father that was a prominent figure in the virtual reality and next generation entertainment business, I was deeply connected to video games and their various incarnations growing up. (Remember Exhilirama Saint Louis? Stun-Runner!!)
I was even lucky enough to have participated in primitive versions of  getinthepods [getinthepods.com] before it was getinthepods due to this influence.

Uber-Nerd! Uber-NERD!! You have no excuse you slime!!! The Unseen[www.sarna.net]
issue is going away due to retroactive introduction of designs that look recognizably like the mechs we know and love without blatantly infringing on Harmony Gold's copyright to their Macross anime franchise. Download the game now uber-nerd.. It's 'free'..

No, don't even start with me Uber-Nerd, don't even compare this to rolling dice and painting pewter, this is so much better..

And YOU! Don't talk to me about that golden gun you bought for that game you play or that skin for that champion you love dawg. I got a mother ♥♥♥♥ing Santa Atlas with Boom Box warhorns and christmas lights mounted in my cockpit 'lil ♥♥♥♥♥ boi!

If you got through this whole thing, you might have what it takes to play the game.

In all seriousness, if you put in the time to fully comprehend how to play the game (Imagine doing so without the handy client nested tutorials that now exist..) you will dominate and it will make your usual FPS games feel like so much chaffe by comparison. You won't be able to go home again if you reach that Nirvana.

There's no melee combat.. Yet.

reviewText:
I've already logged thousands of hours in this game before the steam release.
I have only two gripes about it.
1st gripe is, invisible corners and or walls.  You can obviously clear a corner, enough to make a shot and you end up hitting an inviso wall.
2nd gripe is, when you run into someone, sometimes it glitches out and you teleport behind them or to the side, or just get stuck for a moment.  This is more noticeable in a light mech, and it really screws with you when you are trying to circle a bigger mech.  All to often has someone back into me when im shooting their back only to find my self glitched infront of them all of sudden enabling them to get a kill shot on me.
Those 2 gripes im pritty sure its just bad physics bugs or bad coding, would really like to see those 2 cons patched ASAP.

Other than that the game is puuurfect.  You can seriously waste alot of time on this, and it can quickly turn into a sport for you.  And thats exactly what this game is, an E-Sport, this is not a little kids game, this is full on mech battle simulation.  You are a Pilot when you log in.  Learn to pay attention to the letter of the alphabet thats on top of your enemy, because people will be calling targets by those letters, example - Target A will be called Alpha" focus fire on alpha
hoursPlayed: ect.  Learn to read and navigate the minimap/radar properly

reviewText: Even though I never was involved in the tabletop games and have zero clue about the lore behind the MechWarrior franchise, I've always been a fan of the MechWarrior games throughout the years on PC.  I came into MWO pretty late in the game, having started playing in March 2015, and have no clue how it released and slipped under my gaming radar, but totally love the game.   It appeals to a certain type of gamer outside of the lore fanatics, as it isn't your fast paced COD like game that appeals to the ADD crowd.  Give it a try, run the trial Mechs, and judge for yourself after throwing a few hours into it.  All you'll lose if you don't like is a little bit of time, but if you do like it you'll gain a solid title in your Steam library that you'll keep coming back to.

reviewText:
There's two sides to Mechwarrior Online.

The good side is that it's actually a really good game.  The core 'drive a giant robot and shoot other giant robots' simulation is well-implemented and quite fun. And the Mechlab, where you customize your giant robot from a huge list of components and weapons, is also very realized.  These two core components are what will keep you coming back to MWO.

The bad side is that I just listed all the good parts. There's no single-player campaign, so forget your fond memories of Mechwarrior 2/3/4's single player. The multiplayer game modes are essentially limited to team deathmatch, so if you get tired of that, there's not much else to do. The persistent element are thin and the social tooling is weak. If you need more than giant robots with a variety of weapons shooting each other, then MWO won't make you come back.

Those two points said; I keep coming back to MWO to shoot more giant robots, and I think anybody that finds the idea of shooting giant robots appealing should at least try MWO.

reviewText:
I've played the first Mechwarrior, Mechassault for Xbox, and Mechwarrior 4. MWO is an enjoyable 12v12 mechwarrior game, but it's grindy.

Very grindy and in different ways. You need to complete basic skills for 3 of the same mech to access elite skills. Then there are pilot skills that seem to take forever to gain experience. Then there's the money needed to buy the mech, and then customize it with the parts you want. After the cadet boost expires after 25 matches, money will be a bit tough to come by, even with the premium boost.

If you don't care too much about customization or progress, there are always 16 trial mechs available for play with 4 for each weight class. Others can use those to figure out what kind of mech they want to purchase and customize with the in-game currency. Some mechs are very expensive, so a trial run is a smart move to not waste money. You start with 4 mech bays and can earn some free ones from Faction play or events.

The sound effects are great. Firing any of the lasers feels and looks good. The same goes for the ballistic weapons. I didn't care too much for the missiles, but if you like firing volleys of them and hearing them blast off into the distance, this game will let you do so.

The damage displayed on the mechs is visually satisfying. I'm a big fan of shooting arms off. Mechs will be covered in bullet holes and damaged metal. They'll walk with limps if one of the legs is destroyed.

Anyhoo, this game can offer a good time. Just make smart purchases and have fun with your builds. I have read that the higher tiers require optimal builds, so keep that in mind, but I'm still in Tier 5 after 30 hours. Go crush some trees already!

reviewText:
Hello fellow gamers. Firstly I want to point out that I am a Legendary Founder of this game and so I have been through the entire roller coaster ride of the good and the bad of MWO.

I must say that overall MWO is quite a fun game to play. Since I have been playing for so long there have been times were I get a little bored and I'll head off to occupy my time elsewhere. I find myself always coming back to play for a little bit here and there and eventually coming back in full force. It comes down to the fact that the core gameplay is simply fun. I love tweaking my Mechs to fit my playstyle and/or to try and get that edge to ebst my opponents.

I typically play as a solo pugger because I like the no strings attached, play a few games and then get some work done. Obviously this means that you're in for some fun with the grab bag of players out there but I generally have a good mix of good and bad games. I must say that if you have the chance to drop with a group it will exponentially increase the amount of fun you experience. The tactical gameplay that emerges from group combat is like no other.

Even though the game is great now, it is continuously expanding. As of this review there are already teasers for the next rounds of improvements. There are even hints to a single player or possibly co-op campaign! On top of this, the president of the company is very active on Twitter and is very helpful in answering questions or providing juicy tid bits of imformation to keep us excited about the future of the game. I find that developers/owners of a company being involved with their community is such a rare treat. I find really helps improve the flow of feedback and generally creates a positive atmosphere.

There is a lot more I could write about this game but instead I will try to summarize some additional points that I feel stand out.

Gameplay
-Core gameplay is very addicting.
-Mechlab can provide hours of entertainment by itself as you tweak your Mechs to suit your needs.
-Faction gameplay is a little lack luster currently.
-Big improvements to Faction play in the very near future will help breathe new life into this mode.

Mechs
-New Mech releases are fairly frequent Helps keep excitement up.
-The current selection is quite plentiful and helps keep the battlefields varied.
-Free-to-play grind can be a little extensive but at least the new player experience gives quite a substantial amount of in game currency to get you started.

Maps + Modes
-A decent variety and styles of maps to keep things interesting.
-More maps on the way but at a fairly slow pace currently.
-Game modes help to change the dynamic of the battle which helps with the map variety.

Overall I find this game quite enjoyable. The beauty of it all is that the game will continue to expand and improve as time goes on. I definately recommend this game. Even if you don't play hardcore, it can be nice to break up the monotony of continuous gaming with a few matches of MWO to keep things fresh.

Hope to see you on the battlefield (on the blue team of course :)

reviewText:
Full disclosure - I've been a fan of the franchise since I discovered BattleTech in grade school, right around the time Mechwarrior 2 came out.

I have a ton of fun playing Mechwarrior Online. There is a huge variety of 'Mechs and wide scope for customizing each 'Mech. I'm mid-tier 3 right now, and matchmaking is fairly quick even in the early hours of the morning. Balance between the Clan and Inner Sphere tech bases is getting better as they tweak it. The Community Warfare/Faction Play part of the game is very much in development, but has additional features en route and I have high hopes.

Whether you're in Faction Play or Quick Play/Solo Queue, teamwork is essential. Stick with your buddies, focus fire, and reap the rewards. Get separated from your team and focused by the red team and you'll have a bad day.

That said, it is an imperfect game, partly due to the difficulties of translating a turn-based tactics game (BattleTech) into a real-time first person stompy shooter. It's coming along, and it seems that PGI has been a lot more responsive to/involved with the community lately when it comes to making changes.

reviewText:
I've been playing on-and-off since Closed Beta, with most of my time played after the original publisher (IGP) departed.
I'm not going to touch on the history of the game, nor its previous states. If anyone out there hates PGI or this game for its history, I think their opinions are valid but I'd like to focus my review on what the game is here and now.

Mechwarrior Online is a game about piloting giant walking tanks.
As far as these things go, this is the best on the market. The initial learning curve can be pretty steep, but once you get your bearings this game provides an experience like no other. Half of the game is customization; swapping out weaponry and equipment on your massive death machine. The other half is tearing other players' mechs apart; shearing off limbs and blasting holes in their torsos.

This is a game where your hitboxes, health, and loadout all go hand-in-hand. You might be missing your entire left half, about to die from one more shot to the chest, but still have armor on your right arm. Many times victory will hinge on your ability to shield your critical components just long enough to get one more shot at the enemy. This game truly shines when both sides are locked in this desperate struggle, trying to mitigate incoming damage while simultaneously finding moments to strike.

There's nothing quite so satisfying as firing the massive, deafening AC20 and watching an enemy mech rock with the impact. No other game makes me laugh with such maniacal glee, as my 100-ton Atlas obliterates an enemy with a cluster of short-range missiles. Nothing gets my heart racing quite like speeding around the map in a light mech, scouting the enemy team's location and harassing mechs several times my size.

I couldn't possibly hope to cover all the tactical elements or loadout considerations in this review. What I can tell you is that all the research pays off. The more time you invest in looking up strategies, loadouts and mech roles, the better you will perform and the more fun you will have. You'll learn which mechs to fear, and the range of their most likely loadouts. You'll learn where to shoot each mech to most efficiently disable or destroy them. You'll learn the best way to play to your mechs' strengths, and the result will be a game that keeps your mind racing as you work to counter each new enemy.

This is a game I can't recommend enough. Nothing feels quite as cool as becoming a Mechwarrior.

reviewText: Well to say I'm enjoying this game is a gross understatement. I use to play the tabletop game back in the early 90's and so was instantly curious. No problems with download, pretty much everything run fines on a mid-range rig at best(mine lol). I've had maybe a dozen bugs/glitches in the near 300 hours I've played so no complaints really. The game is great fun, especially if you like player verse player combat and enjoy teamwork. Alot of depth has gone into the game at this point, tonnes of mechs, well including variants there is over 100 easily. Heaps of customization as well which is one of the best parts of the game. Is the game grindy, yes it is a bit but that can be half the fun. It doesn't take to long to accumulate half a dozen mechs(without spending a dollar) and pretty much every much is available without real money(There are a few Hero/Champion class mechs but the same chassis variants are usually on par or even better). Money does help, especially with premium time but it's most definately not needed. Community seems to be pretty friendly, always trolls about the place like anywhere lol. Anyways, a fantastic game and has heaps of long term value. One of the rare reviews I've ever done, just wanted to people to know. Graphics 8/10, Sound 7/10, Lastability 9/10, Depth 8/10. RATING 8.5/10

reviewText:
My review of MechWarrior Online:  Jan 15 2016

Mechwarrior was one of those games I grew up on when I was younger.  The player pilots an armored mech and does battle with eleven other players on a variety maps.

Graphics:  I have nothing much to compare this against except maybe Hawken and Titanfall and it can match some of their look.  Maps are generally good looking ranging from desert wastelands to artic towns.  Weapons like lasers glow, leaving heat marks. and missles/rockets general smoke trails.  You can tell the damage of mechs by how much smoke they can sometimes generate from the damage they have taken.  Cockpits are fully detailed, though you can't push the buttons, and are unique for each kind of Mech.

Sound:  There is not much to say about the sound as much of it is muffled.  You get verbal warnings and indicators for what is happening on the map or happening to you.  What I mean for muffled sound is;  you are hearing what you would hear inside your mech.  The thumps of your feet stomping around and bumping into terrain. The hiss of your heat sinks trying to cool you down.  The bang of ballistic weapons being fired and the cycling of energy weapons as they discharge.

Gameplay:  In the main menu players can select which Mech they want to pilot.  Once you pick a chassis (general shape and character of the mech) you pick a varient (loadout options)  and you are ready to go.  The roles are broken up into weight classes.  Light mechs are your small light weight fast movers.  Mediums mechs and Heavy mechs seem to be your general all round mechs and Assault mechs are the heavy hitters.  While fighting players have to manage their Mech's heat and torso while they manuever around in battle shooting enemies.   After each battle awards players with xp for their chosen Mech and credits that they can spend on getting new mechs or customizing the ones they currently own.  You spend your XP on skill boosts that affect the performance of your Mech.

New player experience?:  After installing and signing in, players complete a tutorial to learn how to effectively pilot mechs.  Though many of the more advanced systems are not discussed or gone over in the tutorial, players can complete challenges to see said systems.  They recieve a stack of credits where they can save up to buy their first mech.  Trial Mechs are freely given and rotate regularly to allow players to try out different styles.

Overall:  It is a fun game,  you could lose many hours of sleep into it.  The community seems fairly friendly as the game does have built in voice chat.  Games tend to be more group friendly as you get awards for fighting together.  It does have a bit of a learning curve but what game doesn't.  Just remember to not go alone,  lone mechs are tasty.

reviewText:
quickie review:

I'm really enjoying this game.

A couple things:
1) This game is a lot slower and more methodical then your standard FPS
2) your mech can take a lot more punishment then your standard space marine/ww II soldier.  Its OK to take some hits.
3) there is a rather steep learning curve with this game.  You will be killed.  Don't get discouraged.  You'll get better with practice.  Your first kills and wins will be SUPER satifying.
4) This game is very playable without spending any real money.  The tutorial and your first 25 matches give you extra in-game currency (C-bills) which can be used to buy a mech or two.
5) join a faction and dip your toe into Community Warfare (youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PJYWTl3mHuk)
getting to level 2 in a faction nets you a free mech bay.
6) Mechs that can only be purchased with real money will either be: A) not as good as mechs that can be purchased with in-game2 earnable currency, or B) will eventually be available for purchase with C-bills.
7) This game has two currencies: C-bills and MC.  You earn C-bills by playing.  MC is purchased with real money.  The vast majority of the content can be purchased with C-bills.

If that doesn't scare you, or if it sound interesting, give it a try.

reviewText:
This is an amazing game.  Not just for F2P games, this is a game to compete with the AAA titles.  There are some interface issues, but nothing to do with the interface during a match.  That part is extremely smooth.  There is exclusive content available only for pay, but it's perfectly balanced with the F2P content, so matches are never overly unbalanced.

It's all about strategy.  You outfit a Mech, give the limitations of the frame your personal capability / preference with available weapons and you compete against other players in groups of 12 on a fairly limited set of maps and game modes.  Simple as that...

Except that you end up giving up everything good in your life chasing a game that has replaced your meth addiction and you've highjacked your neighbor's WiFi just to play because you can't get Time Warner or AT&T to run a line to your van down by the river.

reviewText:
I started playing MWO back in Closed Beta and have played it consistently since that time. It has gone through a LOT of changes and is STILL undergoing changes (which isn't a bad thing). For me, it is still a lot of fun to play.

Is it perfect? Of course not. Few, if any games are perfect.

Is it Pay to Win?
Not at all. There is nothing you can purchase for real money that gives you any advantage over those who use ingame currency. It may give you the opportunity to play new mechs early, but other than that, no advantages at all. All the Weapons available in the game work the same no matter on what Mech they are equipped (now, Clan weapons work differently from Inner Sphere but they work the same across all Clan mechs). There are no Gold Weapons" or "Gold Ammunition".

Why do mechs cost so much?
That is indeed a good question and one I wish they would explain myself! Personally
date: I feel they would be better off selling them for less money to sell more but I guess they figure their price point currently maximizes their profits. And they are a company out to make a profit (who isn't)! That said
recommended:
every mech (other than Hero and Champion Mechs) are available to purchase at some point using ingame currency that you can earn while playing the game.

Hero Mechs? P2W!
While it is true those mechs are only available for real money
hoursPlayed: they aren't P2W mechs. They are just mechs with a special paint/camo
voteText: and offer a Cbill % Bonus to your earnings. Hero mechs will have a weapon loadout that is not available on any other current variant usually but then suffer from some other disadvantage (perhaps it can't carry as many weapons as the others). But
helpfulPercent: the key point here ... all weapons perform the same
votesHelpful:
regardless of the Mech on which they are installed. So a Medium Laser is the same across all the Inner Sphere Mechs.

Champion Mechs
Champion Mechs are exactly the same mech as their normal variant
votesTotal:
just with a (C) designation and a boost to your Experience earnings.

Trial Mechs
These are what you will start with if you do not purchase any mechs with real money. They are free for you to use. You just cannot modify their loadouts whatsoever. You don't own them but you can play them to earn Cbills to purchase your own mechs.

Learning Curve
MWO is going to be wildly different from most other FPS type games. It is supposed to be a Mech Simulator
votesFunny: whatever they mean by that. Anyway
commentsCount: there will be a pretty steep learning curve for this game! To me
column16: it was worth it and makes it so much more fun and involved. You have to learn how to Torso Twist to spread damage across your mech to increase your survivability. What this means is the upper half of your body can turn independently from your legs. You can be running one way and facing another (the degree of twist is dependent on the mech...some can turn more than others). Mastering the ability to Twist your Torso independent of your legs is a MUST.\n\nAiming Reticles. You will likely have 2 sets of reticules. Your Arms can also move somewhat independently of your torso (depends on Mech) to some degree. The small Circle reticule is where your Arm mounted weapons will fire while the + reticule is where your torso mounted weapons will fire. Oh
column17: the OTHER thing you have to keep in mind is WHERE on your mech these weapons are mounted as far as height goes. While your Reticule may not appear to be obstructed by terrain
column18:
low-mounted weapons may not fire over the hill you are standing behind (for example).

Heat Management
This is going to be one of your MAJOR things to master in MWO. Every weapon you fire (with the exception of the Gauss Rifle) generates some measure of Heat. Your Mech can only handle a certain amount of heat before you risk shutting down and/or doing internal damage to your mech. Each mech has Heat Sinks that add to your heat capacity and also contribute to dissapating the heat you have accumulated. So
column19: the greater the number of weapons you fire at once
column20: the greater the amount of heat you build up. Also
column21: the faster you fire
column22:
the more you generate heat. Heat is your biggest concern and the thing you HAVE to learn to manage.

Ghost Heat
This is something the developers added as a "balance tool". It's not very well described in the game. What this means is they have set up a limit to the number of weapons of the same type that can be fired at the same time without incurring a "Ghost Heat Penalty". If you fire more than the allowed number at the same time
column23: then you incur additional heat
column24: hence the term "ghost". This penalty increases quickly based on how many more weapons past the limit you fire (so 3 more than the limit is penalized much more than 1 past the limit). You will get an indicator in the Mech Lab that warns you of the limit if you have more weapons of that type installed on the mech. For example
column25: you can fire 4 SRM 4 missile packs without a penalty but if you fire 5 at the same time
column26: you start incurring the Ghost Heat penalty. This is only if you fire them all at the same time. If you fire them one after the other (Chain Fire) you are fine or if you fire in smaller groups and pause at least .5 seconds between you are fine as well.\n\nSo
column27: it is a rather complicated game to learn but once you begin to understand and master the skills
column28: it becomes second nature. The game still has some improving to do...matchmaking isn't the best in the land and the game really needs a Lobby available full time in my opinion
column29: but they are slowly getting those things added. I find the core game a lot of fun to play."
column30: January 13

reviewText:
I've played MechWarrior titles since 1995. It's my favorite genre and I've purchased every title in the series since. A few years ago I played this Open Beta for a couple weeks, and left very disappointed. I thought the title was doomed. But loyal fans spending lots of cash have kept the developers motivated. Improvements were made, so I decided to have another look. I've been back for 3 months now and while it's not the MechWarrior 5 I and many other fans hoped for, it is still quite enjoyable to play in its current state. Fortunately I picked a good time of the year to come back as multiple sales were going on both with in-game and premium currency. I was even motivated to spend some real cash for premium purchases which is out of character for me.
So you're here to find out if this title is worth your time? If you love the series or the genre, I would say yes it certainly is worth installing and playing. There is a learning curve if your background is all Player versus A.I. of the previous titles. Humans are infinitely more unpredictable. (that's not saying they are always smarter) If your background is Player versus Player, especially First Person Shooter titles, this game's tactics will be familiar, yet different enough to be a new experience worth trying. You move much slower - depending on the chassis size, have multiple weapon groups to choose from - depending on range and heat levels, and must orient/steer your upper and lower torsos independantly.
There is a strong focus on team logistics. You'll see it time and again: a lone wolf playstyle will get you killed as isolated mechs of any size can be overwhelmed with even just a pair of attackers. Then once you're gone, your team has a numbers disadvantage and the odds of them losing rise quickly. If you're the kind of person that likes team-chat, defined combat roles, and focused fire, you'll love this title.
The in-game chat is 99.9% adult and respectful. Most are willing to give free advice and understand the challenges of playing the game well. Those that choose to swear/slur or team kill can be easily reported and seem to quickly disappear. The out-of-game community is alive and well. Searching the official forums, youtube, or the relevant reddit sites will give you links to many external resources for role-tactics, mech customization, chassis purchasing advice, social ladders, and just about anything you need to be successful except the actual in-game skill of keeping calm while 12 strangers (or possibly even friends once you've been around a while) are trying to melt your face off.
I intend to play this game for quite a while, and I encourage anyone reading this to give the free install a shot. It might just be exactly what you're looking for. It doesn't take long for a new player to have several vehicles in the garage and feel like they can contribute or even turn the tides of a battle. Suit up!

You can buy stuff with real money, but you don't have to.

reviewText:
Terrific game, enjoying every moment of it. If you are familiar with the Mechwarrior franchise, battlestyle-wise the game feels very similar with big bad robots stomping each other. Most matches are done in 12v12s. Each match earns you C-bills, the in-game currency, which you use to buy new mechs or new equipment.

There is a great deal of customization offered from the kind of weapons you can opt for, to the different variants of each chassis you can pick from and even down to what color or paint pattern you want on your mech to make it as visually distinguished as possible.

One remarkable feature that I have to put out, the community is amazing so far. Most players I have came across are really helpful and patient, save for a few, but those a very small minority. Most players here are polite in response and will gladly help out new players in need. There are plenty of units (aka clans / guilds in layman terms) that are recruiting new players so if you have the time, you may want to check them out on the forums to help you get settled faster into the game.

Overall experience: 8.5/10

reviewText:
Pros -

Really great game so far and the development team works hard and keep improving it.  It's a lot of fun right now and I like the ideas they have for the future of the game.  I played a lot of World of Tanks and this is similiar but better in my opinion.  The graphics are excellent and the gameplay really good - the more you play the more depth you find.  I recently started playing light mechs and I really underestimated the power and fun of that playstyle (scouting, harrassing, ect..).  Playing as a light vs. Medium/heavy vs. Assault Mech is very different and keeps thing fresh.  The maps are very different and some are really wonderful.  I LOVE the feeling of landing on an alien planet with your fellow Mech pilots and heading out to battle.  And finally for those of you who like the buliding and crafting part of the game, the Mech LAB is a lot of fun.  You can change weapons and weapon locations and engines and armor and heatsinks.  And all these choices matter and change gameplay.  Weapons placed up high on shoulders allow for differnt play style than lower mounted arm weapons, both have benefits and drawbacks on the battlefield.

Also, they give you tons of money over the first 20+ games so is not grindy at all.  Just play a bit and you will be able to buy some mechs and lots of gear for your mechs.  ALso there are always tournament rewards that you get for just playing.

Cons -

The gameplay modes are mostly just kill everyone.  They are working on changing these in the next few months.  But even with the repetative game objectives - the different maps and mechs keeps it interesting and just blasting apart other Mechs never gets old.  :)

TLDR:  Fun game.  Maps are beatuiful.  MechLAB is fun.  Gameplay is entertaining.  Give it a try (It's free, so nothing to lose).

reviewText:
I've been playing on-and-off since Closed Beta, with most of my time played after the original publisher (IGP) departed.
I'm not going to touch on the history of the game, nor its previous states. If anyone out there hates PGI or this game for its history, I think their opinions are valid but I'd like to focus my review on what the game is here and now.

Mechwarrior Online is a game about piloting giant walking tanks.
As far as these things go, this is the best on the market. The initial learning curve can be pretty steep, but once you get your bearings this game provides an experience like no other. Half of the game is customization; swapping out weaponry and equipment on your massive death machine. The other half is tearing other players' mechs apart; shearing off limbs and blasting holes in their torsos.

This is a game where your hitboxes, health, and loadout all go hand-in-hand. You might be missing your entire left half, about to die from one more shot to the chest, but still have armor on your right arm. Many times victory will hinge on your ability to shield your critical components just long enough to get one more shot at the enemy. This game truly shines when both sides are locked in this desperate struggle, trying to mitigate incoming damage while simultaneously finding moments to strike.

There's nothing quite so satisfying as firing the massive, deafening AC20 and watching an enemy mech rock with the impact. No other game makes me laugh with such maniacal glee, as my 100-ton Atlas obliterates an enemy with a cluster of short-range missiles. Nothing gets my heart racing quite like speeding around the map in a light mech, scouting the enemy team's location and harassing mechs several times my size.

I couldn't possibly hope to cover all the tactical elements or loadout considerations in this review. What I can tell you is that all the research pays off. The more time you invest in looking up strategies, loadouts and mech roles, the better you will perform and the more fun you will have. You'll learn which mechs to fear, and the range of their most likely loadouts. You'll learn where to shoot each mech to most efficiently disable or destroy them. You'll learn the best way to play to your mechs' strengths, and the result will be a game that keeps your mind racing as you work to counter each new enemy.

This is a game I can't recommend enough. Nothing feels quite as cool as becoming a Mechwarrior.

reviewText:
Been playing awile. At first I thought I would be a light scout pilot, but found myself enjoying 300 meter or less scrapping in brawls. Situational awareness is more of a strength for me than being a good shot. I found myself being good enough in the Assualt Class mechs while still enjoying every other class of mechs. I find some Mechs to be higher skill mechs than others. I know Pilots that you give one small laser and a high skill Mech (need skills to hit with or stay alive)and they get massive damage done, a bunch of assists and a couple kills. That is not me in any way.

This game caters to each individuals play style and differenciates everyones skill levels. Each pilot can build a mech that hightens skills or hides the lack thereof. My builds hide my lack of skill shooting while taking advantage of my abilty to know where the enemy is or is moving to, in a brawl, in a flank, or smashing down on my team.

I am better than I was, but you long time Steam players start with more skill than I will ever have! That said, I like my chances against you. Thinking mans game, and you are a child my friend ( just kidding, almost).

Smash and grab play style, long range sniper, big ballistic crusher, short or long range missle havoc wrecker, or the sneeking little evil back stabbing elite scout light that has the temarity to do such to a Majestic slow moving Assault Mech that rightfully and normally strike fear and apprehension to the enemy, showing it's superiority in almost every way, right? heh heh lol

Anyway, I think this game is great. There is a learning curve some find tough, but every hard core gamer I ever met that stuck with it, they loved it and were too good at it to suit me, unless they were on my team stealing my kills.

Do not use the center torso button as a crutch, get on teamspeak, fix your armour and get double heatsinks. Buy 3 of the same chassis leveling them up on the pilot tree, do not spend a dime on the game if you shouldn't, spend whatever you like if you can. Nobody needs to spend money to to be good at this game. gl hf

reviewText:
I've played this game since the closed beta mostly either solo or in small groups (2-3) and I think it is great fun. You can pop in and get in a quick round or spend hours playing and tweaking mechs in the Mechlab. It is free-to-play, which I generally shy away from, but the model works here. You don't really ever have to spend any cash if you don't want to. All things, aside from a few mechs (that just have different loadouts and camo schemes) and cosmetic items, are attainable by using the in-game currency that you get from playing matches.

I really enjoy MW:O and recommend it at every opportunity.

Every opportunity.

reviewText:
Generally speaking it is a fun game to try after looking for some tutorial and vastly improved since CBT (I'm a founder pack buyer)

However, even though I recommend it, I would need to point out that this is only if you play SOLO or in large organized group preferably in 12. I have to teach my friends either through video or private matches...and forced to REFUSE teamming up with them so that they will have a better experience and time to enjoy rather than being stomped by 12-men team.

Why? because, if you ever want to play with even just one friend, you will be dropped into the group queue and has to bear with the very likelihood of being steamrolled by a bigger premade group (a bunch of 2-4 mech teams vs an organized 12 mech team is quite common). and I have no idea why PGI still had not allow a 2 mech team in 'solo' queue as I failed to see, contrary to those forumites, how it will make the game unfair. See, WOT, WT and many other online session based games are allowing 2-4 men platoon, they don't have any problem with that.

2 men team = 1/6 of a full team for MWO (16.7%)
3 tanks = 1/5 of a full team for WOT and others (20%)

And just throw the 4-12 mech teams to CW (even though people crying that it has long MM and whatever things they dislike). They don't belong to pub games. Or just get rid of large teams and make a cap for Lance-sized (4 mechs) premade queue. You will want to allow veterans to bring in and teach their friends rather than giving those people a hard time to do so, so that you will have enough population to support Community Warfare and larger group queue. (and everyone will be happier other than the 12-mech seal clubbing jerks)

reviewText:
Mechwarrior Online has been a regularly played game of mine for 3 1/2 years now.  I enjoy it because the mech customization and uniqueness is very good and that translates into many different potential play-styles.

I continue to play because it is a game that still has the ability to give me an adrenaline rush and white-knuckle game-play occasionally on those close or come-from-behind matches.

It is a tactical shooter and rewards a good sense of awareness and the ability to work as a team.

Community Warfare is fun, although there isn't much of a lasting effect of winning or losing a Community Warfare match, but that system is being continuously worked on and there are some big changes being made that will improve the system.

I recommend this game if you prefer a more tactical, unit-based shooter where you generally must work together with others to be most effective.

reviewText:
Hi! If you are reading this you are deciding whether or not to invest your time and possibly your hard earned money. I hope this review can answer some simple questions you may have.

First off I am not new to MechWarrior as I have grown up with the series starting with the original in 1989. I have played through all the MechWarrior 2, 3 and 4 games and have enjoyed them thoroughly. If you are looking for a single player campaign in the vein of the previous games you may have to wait. PGI is currently working towards releasing a single player campaign in the future that would be loyal to MechWarrior and MechWarrior 2 Mercenaries.
Right now they have two main ways to play the game. The first is “Quick Play” consisting of 3 different modes (more to come in the future hopefully) spread across a dozen or more so maps (more always being added).This first mode can be done as a solo player or as part of a team (which can be found by joining a unit/guild or using the LFG Tool).
The second mode of play is called “Faction Play” this mode is best played as part of a group or as a unit as solo players may find it frustrating because going it solo often puts them at a disadvantage. This mode is still in Beta with more features coming soon (Spring 2016 CW Phase 3).  They recently released a sneak peak here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KdC90yXKRFs

The game offers a ton of Mechs to choose from each with a game play style of their own. The game features 4 weight classes: Light (20-35 tons), Medium (40-55 tons), Heavy (60-75 tons), and Assault (80-100 tons). Each plays differently and has different roles. Lights are great at harassing the slower moving assaults and punishing them for not moving with the team as an Assault will have problems dealing with a fast moving light for example. There are dozens of chassis available for each tonnage and multiple variants for each chassis. For example in the Assault Mech category we have the Atlas which is one of many assault Mechs available to play; and within the Atlas chassis there are half a dozen different variants: http://mwo.gamepedia.com/Atlas.

The game has 4 different types of currency, but in all it is really easy to learn They are C-Bills, MC, XP, and GXP.

C-Bills are earned by simply playing matches, completing achievements, gaining faction ranks, or through events (more on this later). There are ways to boost your income such as buying “Premium time” or using special Mechs that give C-Bill boosts (these are labeled “Special Mechs”  denoted with an (S) these are customer application Mechs or Mechs variants that are purchased when Mech packages are sold. As seen here: https://mwomercs.com/urbanmech). C-Bills will be your primary method of buying Mechs in-game (You must have a free mechbay).

MC is the Real Cash to In-Game Currency. You can buy Mechs with this currency (This is how you attain Hero Mechs 90% of the time), and this is a method of attaining Mech bays (outside events). They have a variety of method of buying this stuff: Karma Koin, PayPal, and Credit Card. However they do have events where you can earn MC so do not fret.

XP is what you will use to level up your Mechs (Yes you level your Mechs by buying skills). XP is earned through matches; however XP is bonded to a chassis. For example if you are playing your Atlas-D and earned 10,000 XP that XP is only useable for that Atlas-D, you cannot use it for that Atlas-RS you want to level up. However…

GXP (General XP) can be earned through matches (at a MUCH SLOWER rate) and can be used on any mech. However GXP is used to level up yourself as a pilot and earn access to modules (which you can purchase in the Mech Lab after unlocking them via GXP in the Skills tab. Also you can convert XP to GXP if you are willing to spend your MC.

I know that is a lot to absorb (and there is even more I am leaving out). I did promise to mention events. MWO often offers events that span Quick play and Faction Play every so often (often). At the time of this review the current event is: https://mwomercs.com/tournaments?t=201601champion3.
As you can see there are some good rewards being offered in these events; In these events you can earn C-Bills, GXP, Consumable modules, Mech Bays, vanity cockpit items, paint, camo/pattern, and even Mechs for free.

You can get just about everything in this game (Minus Hero Mechs) for free if you are patient. All Mechs that are sold in packages do make their way to the in game store for C-bills, and there are ways to attain Mech bays outside of MC (Although they are rare!) However I’m not one for patience and I tend to spend my money on packages and MC (Though they often have MC and Mech Sales so your wallet won’t get hit as hard).
The Community is fairly good however there are toxic members and communities as you probably have noticed just by reading some of these comments. Though some of these negative reviews are from players who quit and haven’t played in a while and are just salty. While PGI has made mistakes in the past they do try hard to make this an enjoyable game and in the last year and a half have made enormous strides in improving the game and their image with the community after parting ways with Infinite Games Publishing (IGP). The president of PGI (Russ Bullock) is often talking shop and features with people on his twitter and you can tell he loves the BattleTech Universe. He often has town halls where players have a chance to ask him questions about upcoming features and events.

I advise visiting https://www.reddit.com/r/OutreachHPG/ if you have questions or are looking for more information.
The game is constantly getting new Mechs and other content (UI Improvements, Maps, etc) and to paraphrase PGI: They will always be working to add more features to this game.

I hope I was able to offer some information you found useful.

reviewText:
I've played the first Mechwarrior, Mechassault for Xbox, and Mechwarrior 4. MWO is an enjoyable 12v12 mechwarrior game, but it's grindy.

Very grindy and in different ways. You need to complete basic skills for 3 of the same mech to access elite skills. Then there are pilot skills that seem to take forever to gain experience. Then there's the money needed to buy the mech, and then customize it with the parts you want. After the cadet boost expires after 25 matches, money will be a bit tough to come by, even with the premium boost.

If you don't care too much about customization or progress, there are always 16 trial mechs available for play with 4 for each weight class. Others can use those to figure out what kind of mech they want to purchase and customize with the in-game currency. Some mechs are very expensive, so a trial run is a smart move to not waste money. You start with 4 mech bays and can earn some free ones from Faction play or events.

The sound effects are great. Firing any of the lasers feels and looks good. The same goes for the ballistic weapons. I didn't care too much for the missiles, but if you like firing volleys of them and hearing them blast off into the distance, this game will let you do so.

The damage displayed on the mechs is visually satisfying. I'm a big fan of shooting arms off. Mechs will be covered in bullet holes and damaged metal. They'll walk with limps if one of the legs is destroyed.

Anyhoo, this game can offer a good time. Just make smart purchases and have fun with your builds. I have read that the higher tiers require optimal builds, so keep that in mind, but I'm still in Tier 5 after 30 hours. Go crush some trees already!

reviewText:
I have over 11,000 matches played in this game, and way too many hours invested. I obviously enjoy it.

The pros of this game? You get to run big stompy robots. I love the history and background of this game. I enjoy the fact that the meta has shifted now and then, it makes me relearn various aspects. The mechbay and design of mechs, the optimizing of builds, understanding weapon ranges and timing, all of it is enjoyable. The marketing says thinking man's shooter. People that are not terrible at this game know that to be true. That said, there are plenty of dumbasses with terrible builds as well..

The cons? This game is developed by a small company. They have limited resources. Promised additions and fixes come slowly. They have to focus attention on money making content to keep their business open, and sometimes that trumps adding fun content like game modes or user interface improvements.

The neutral? Game balance has been a rocky road. The tabletop game this adapts was balanced in a way that didn't translate to a real time shooter. They have made slow akward attempts at balance, and the game is in a decent state at the moment. The developers of this game have been historically really bad at their own game, and hesitant to listen to the top tier players. They recently have been playing more in queue, and have joined some tournaments. Their game knowlege in the real playerbase is growing, and I believe that is helping the balance work.

The future? With hopes that we can grow this community via new steam users, I hope that this game can make some money so that staff can be added, and playing modes expanded. I really want to see Faction Warfare fleshed out, and a campaign mode added, and player base expansion will support that. The game desperately needs some more good players. Hopefully the balance is decent enough to retain those type of people at this point.

I'll be here shooting stompy robots for a long time. Hopefully you will be too.

reviewText: Free 2 Play - but you have to pay with your soul. Easily the most addicting game I've played yet. Nothing quite puts a smile on my face like powering up your mech at the start of the round. If you like tactical shooting games that require some thinking this is the game for you. It's very similar in game play to WoT, however it's nothing like the horrible money pit that p2w game was. However, some rigs might have issues. I have a 3930k and a gtx 980 (all under water in a custom loop), and I have some serious problems with crashing. Reformatted to windows 7 (from windows 10) fixed some issues. Rolling back to the 390.00 drivers fixed some other issues. I still get the occasional crash and restart into black screen but it doesn't stop me from putting 14-16+ hours into the game every day.\n\nOverall, I would highly recommend the game, and if you would like some free premium time to get started please drop by my stream @ twitch.tv/phone_microwave - New players are always welcomed and questions are encouraged!

reviewText:
Long time closed beta vet. Very deep and rewarding mech game. It has the right mix of sim/fps/team tactics. It also stays true enough to battle tech to keep it interesting and nostalgic.

This game is not perfect but it is super fun and it's not impossible to play for years without spending any money.  It does have a pretty expensive pay for convenience and early access system. These do not break the game balance as PGI is mindful to avoid pay to win. Speaking of balance, the game is a modders dream so balance is hard and constant. Lately PGI has done better responding to balance changes and issues.

In short this game is my favorite game I currently play and worth a few weeks try to see if you like it. It's free so try it. My in game name is bradleyusm friend me and I'll be happy to help newer players get acclimated.

reviewText:
I want to start off my being clear that I'm a returning founder who left the game initially because of problems with balance, meta, and PGI's inability to deliver.

I picked the game back up again about a month ago, figuring i'd get in, check out CW, and lose interest within a day or two.  And to be honest, i still feel like i could lose interest any time now.

For better or worse, this is not a direct port of TT.  To be hoenst TT had some mechanics in it that were just not suited to real time simulation.

PROS
The mech models are really good.  There are some technical issues with some models (hit boxes, scaling), but i think that on the whole, the mech models are in good shape.

We got the Unseen showing up.  While the mech modles are altered, they are still immediately recognizeable.

Most of the weapon and component implementations make sense when ported over from TT

Community is generally less toxic than most others (That said, this is a team-based game and people do ge frustrated when people ignore attempts to organize in match)

The number of mechs now available makes it less likey that during drops (at least in the lower 3 tiers) you will encounter  cookie-cutter meta teams.

CONS

Ballistic weapons aer still just a hair to accurate.  While rounds drop in flight, they don't really seem to deviate in any other way.

Some of the weapon conversions are just badly implemented:  A 5 second cool down on gauss rifles, then charge time before you can fire, which really adds up to a double-lencgth cooldown

Clan implementation was just baddly handled, and it still causes gameplay and balance problems

Gameplay/Mech balance issues can take some time resolve, and are sometimes knee-jerk reactions (Ask a veteran about tackling)

Community Warfare just isn't ready yet.


All in all, despite having some issues, the game does have promise, and is fun most of the time.  There are some changes coming up in the immediate future that address some of the outstanding issue and open up more content for Community Warfare.

So with all of that, for now, yes, I'd reccomend it, because you can get damn near everything out of the game without spending any money, though obviously people who spend the money get access to new chasis sooner.
