reviewText:
MWO is, and probably always will be, something of a work in progress. It has it's faults, but can be an amazing game as well.

Pros:
- BattleMech customization: They have struck a fairly good balance between the standard tabletop construction rules and a hardpoint system to prevent rediculous boating and encourage customization. You CAN make pretty much an kind of variant you want, even if it's not always smart (See the Cons)

- Variable gameplay: You can make your play as involved (or not) as you want. Quickplay gives you the ability to jump right into a match, which lasts for a maximum of 15 minutes. More depth can be had in Faction Play (also known as Community Warfare), where group play is strongly encouraged and players fight across various planets in the Inner Sphere. Keep in mind, this mode is scheduled for significant changes in the next few months (CW: Phase 3)

- Community: This can be a negative in any game, but MWO at least has the redeeming feature of a strong population of mature gamers and Battletech veterans to balance out the annoying trolls. You can find groups to match what you're looking for.

- Visuals: It's made by a small dev studio, and some of the graphics can show it at times, but they are rescued by an indredibly talented art department. Mech models in particular are almost universally superbly done.

- It's an F2P that is most assuredly NOT Pay2Win. Real life purchases are for cosmetics and boosters, as well as early access to newly released Mechs. It may take a month or two, but any mech that is initially released for $$$ will always subsequently be released for in-game currency

The Cons:

- Time-sink: Yes, it's a time sink. The grind can be pretty severe at times, as in-game earnings can take quite a while, especially if you are playing as a solo player.

- Release Schedule for mechs: This can be a matter of perspective. While the game is not pay2win, there is a tendency for new mechs to be initially relased (during the real life $$$ period)  with op" characteristics. Sometimes it's oddly coded hit-boxes
date: sometimes it's poorly thought out design quirks that give an advantage. The design is then fixed/nerfed just as or shortly before the design becomes available for in-game currency. Taken individually
recommended: any of them appear to just be mistakes by the devs
hoursPlayed: but it is slightly suspicious that the pattern has repeated itself so many times.\n\n- The "pro" or "comp" community: MWO has a small but dedicated group of competetive players. They play in the Faction play
voteText: and third-party tournaments. While there are plenty of good people who participate
helpfulPercent: the overall comp scene can be quite abrasive
votesHelpful: and it's members pompous and annoying. It likely stems from being the top dog in a very small community
votesTotal: like being boastful of being elected Class President of your home-school class of 1 person. If you've ever known that team in an adult rec league that take things too far
votesFunny: as if they're pros or something

reviewText:
As a three year vet, I love this game.  There are too many reviews to wade through for me to egotistically believe that a long meandering review will cut through the rest.  So I'll keep this short and sweet.

It's a free to play FPS game where giant stompy robots shoot each other in 12 v 12 matches.  To the new Steam players that are joining us: this is not a simple game.  Your twitch skills from other shooters will definitely help you, and may even give you an edge over the old timers eventually.  But prepare for a steep learning curve.  There is SO MUCH nuance to understanding this game, let alone succeed at it, that no one will be an elite pilot without some serious time logged.  But, if you want a challenge, this game is it.

My advice to you, the new player, is this.

Join the game.  Jump into the tutorial system and get the hang of the basics of movement and shooting.  Play 10 matches or so in quickplay to get a taste of combat.  Save up that starting cash and play trial mechs at first.

THEN: Ask in team chat or General chat if there are any vets that would be willing to help answer your questions and show you around.  You can lone wolf all you want in this game, but there is simply too much to understand if you don't ask questions.  Established units all have teamspeak servers and would love to help you learn the game.  Please take advantage of the existing community.  Most of us are drinking beers, having fun and are ready and willing to share both with anyone that wants to learn.  You don't need to make any commitment to joining units.  The community of vets truly want the game to succeed and grow, and we know that the best way to do that is to tutor new players.

When you know what you're doing, you've built a stable of mechs that fit your playstyle and you drop with a group of pilots that you have grown comfortable with, there is simply no better gaming experience to be had anywhere.

Crack a beer and look me up on the Steiner Teamspeak hub.  ts1.housesteiner.com  No Password.  My Callsign is Veritae and I'm the XO of Team Cortez Merc Corps (TCMC).  I'll vouch for any unit on the hub.  Peiper and the Devil Dogs are a great group of guys that switch between Wolf and Steiner and enjoy roleplaying.  FFI is a growing and emerging comp merc unit that switches between Clan and Inner Sphere and are a blast to hang out with.   6RCT, 5RCT, OCP, LoP and on and on and on all have vets that play every day and would love to help you out.

Play the game.  Join the community.  Welcome to Mechwarrior: Online.

reviewText:
For a start, I am not a newcomer to MWO or the battletech universe. I know quite abit about lore, the mechwarrior series and battletech.
At first I wasnt much into MWO though. But I kept casually playing the game because I liked the mech combat.
I can tell you the game has improved much over time and PGI keeps going.

Overall what I like most about this game is the customization in the mechlab. You can spend hours thinking about possible builds and how they might work out in the game, then go for a test run just to be back in the mechlab after 1 game.
Many possiblitites to play the game and pretty much any mech is viable depending on your piloting skills.

If I should point out a negative it would be that balance is still shifting. Considering the amount of mechs and weapons though that shouldnt be too surprising and currently MWO is in its most balanced state. All weapons, with exception to flamers and maybe MG, have a role in the game. I think its up to  you to find out what mech and weapon you think might suit your style.

This game is far from perfect but it has a caring community and developers willing to listen to its community (which has led to some people even thinking they listen too much to us...). Great gameplay and options for most play styles and the design of the mechs kept me hooked onto to game, so I suggest that everyone can give this game a shot, its f2p afterall.

reviewText: Been playing MWO for years now. It is my favorite free to play game hands down. If you like fps,give this game a try. It can be a little daunting. It is fairly complex. There are endless variations for loadouts on mechs and play styles that go best with certain loadouts. You have to balance power, cooling,ammo,rate of fire,etc. You have to put in effort if you want to have fun. This means learning how to play your chosen mech and unlocking upgrades for mech to give you a bit more of an edge. Modules for mech also play a big roll. To give a couple of examples,these can be consumables in the form of coolant shots that greatly reduse heat in one shot or weapon modules the increase the rate of fire or range on a particular weapon. Your loadouts are fully customizable. This is a great game!

reviewText:
I've been a fan of the BattleTech Universe for over 20 years.  I've played many iterations and versions of the games.  I've enjoyed decided that this is the best I've played in a long time.

This game is a Free-to-Play game, with in-game purchases available.  However, it's perfectly playable without spending anything.  It puts you in the cockpit of a giant robot weighing anywhere from 20 to 100 tons.

The game does take a little bit to get used to.  I found I had to reprogram the default keys to match my playstyle better.  Once I did that, I found myself doing much better.  There is a plethora of guides and tutorials available as well as a large number of communities.

Give it a chance.  If you're into this genre, you won't be dissapointed.

reviewText:
Looking for the honest opinion of a veteran of big stompy robot goodness?  Someone with an intimate understanding of even the smallest game mechanics, and who can give an objective review for all of MWO's features without sugar-coating them?  Well sit back and read on potential mechwarrior.  I, the venerable Carchemish (in-game name) do kinda sorta fit that description.  Mostly.

I'll break this down into what MWO is, and what it is not.  First the 'is':

-  Mechwarrior Online is a player vs player, team arena style game set in the venerable Battletech universe.
-  It is a beautifully rendered game, both in the landscapes and of course the mechs.  PGI has done a fantastic job making the mechs look amazing, especially given the awful source material. Anyone familiar with the old crappy Battletech artwork" knows what I mean.  I really can’t say enough about this.  I’m always blown away by how they continue to make such gorgeous mechs from such bad original art
-  It is a great blend of slow
recommended: and then fast paced action.\n-  You’ll have a huge mech variety to explore.  Want to race across the map in a fast
hoursPlayed: agile scout?  Done.  Want to slowly lumber into the battle in a behemoth carrying a blistering array of guns?  Make it happen.\n-  MWO is well balanced across the two opposing factions
voteText: the Inner Sphere and the Clans.  Those familiar with the BT lore will know how insanely strong Clan tech was compared to the Inner Sphere.  PGI has done a very good job of balancing the two sides without entirely neutering the Clans.\n-  MWO has an appreciable learning curve
helpfulPercent: and will take some time to fully absorb.  The actual gameplay is essentially point and shoot
votesHelpful:
but the mech and weapon variety will take a while to get used to.

Now for the 'is not':

-  MWO has no PVE content (yet).  If you prefer a story-driven game with missions and NPCs and such
votesTotal: this may not be the game for you.\n-  MWO is not a ‘fast action all the time’ game.  Players will have to scout
votesFunny: find the enemy
commentsCount: set themselves up in the best positions they can
column16: maneuver on the fly
column17: and duke it out with the other team.  Planning and forethought will help you win games. Which brings me to my next point.\n-  Mechwarrior Online is NOT a single player game.  It is a team effort which rewards players for working with their cohorts.  Running off by yourself (with few exceptions) will likely get you and your team murdered.\n-  It is by no means a perfect game.  It has bugs
column18: though they are few in number.  The mech balancing isn’t complete
column19: though they continue to work on that.\n-  It is not “pay to win”.  This one deserves some attention.  Yes
column20: there are some mechs (the so-called “hero” variants) which can only be purchased with real cash
column21: but in most cases they are actually inferior to the standard variants!  So why would you buy them in the first place
column22: you ask?  Hero mechs provide a c-bill (in game currency) boost when playing them
column23: so they’re a good way to earn more money to buy more mechs!  And when I say “inferior”
column24: I mean marginally so in most cases.  Sometimes they are just as good.   And yes you can purchase mech packages with real money
column25:
but they offer no advantage over other players who choose to grind out the in-game money!
-  It is not World of Tanks!

All in all
column26: MWO is a solid game with a lot of playability and huge potential for even more features in the future.  If you enjoy the PvP experience
column27: and are into the mech genre
column28: this one won’t disappoint.  I fully recommend it
column29:
so long as you know what you’re getting into.  Last thing…getting a hold of a decent headset/mic and Teamspeak will make your mech life much easier.

Hope to see you on the battlefield!

Carchemish the Wise and Powerful"

reviewText:
I recommend this game, with some caviats.

The gameplay is generally pretty solid, the visuals are beautiful, and the audio is very satisfying. 'Mech customization is very thorough, and combat is supremely fun. It requires a lot of teamwork, and is slower-paced than a typical shooter.

However, waiting for Community Warfare matches can be very frustrating. This area of the game seems particularly poorly designed. I frequently wait 10-30 minutes on a match, which for the most part renders this mode unplayable for me and a lot of other players.

Because the game is entirely dependent on teamwork, whether you win or lose a match doesn't have as much to do with individual skill, and so when you wind up on a team full of noobs or uncooperative players, it's a landslide loss. That's usually how matches go. When your team works together and communicates, win or lose, it's incredibly fun, but the overwhelming majority of my matches involve silent, uncooperative, and/or seemingly bewildered players, which unfortunately has a dramatic effect on the quality and trajectory of the resulting gameplay.

The ranking system isn't particularly fair. I'm a good player but remain stuck in the bottom-ranked tier" 5 because my teams lose most of the time. You can have a great match
hoursPlayed: pulling off great tactics
voteText: and your rank will still go down if your team loses. It can be frustrating when you are stuck playing with new and low-skill players because your success is overwhelmingly dependent on the team effort. I understand that wins and losses should play into your ranking but they need to adjust the formula to account more for match performance.\n\nCombat is far too focused on the use of Long Range Missiles (LRM's)
helpfulPercent: the "noob tubes" of the game. Not only do they do quite a bit of damage
votesHelpful: but they lock onto you and can hit you behind obstacles (except for tall buildings or geographical features). There is also a consumable item called a UAV that allows the enemy team to spot you without having line of sight
votesTotal: making the use of these LRM's even easier (granted
votesFunny: UAV's can be shot down but they don't show on your minimap). What this means is that the overwhelming majority of matches play exactly the same
commentsCount: regardless of game type (Assault
column16: Domination
column17: Skirmish
column18: etc.)--you hide behind obstacles while people with LRM's slug it out
column19: and this involves a lot of waiting because LRM's have double the range of smaller energy weapons. It's just a shame for the most boring and easy-to-use weapon to be so dominant in almost every single match
column20: more so on some levels than others of course.\n\nThe game has been out for several years and the updates pretty much focus on release of new mechs
column21: so I doubt any of these issues will be resolved
column22: and may or may not even be regarded as issues by the developer or the broader community
column23: depending on who you ask."

reviewText:
MWO is possibly the best free to play game I've played, but then again, it's the only free to play game that has huge sod-off stompy robots in it (Hawken doesn't count because they're more Ballerinas than 'mechs). Oh and machine guns don't cost 10 quid like some F2P games do. *Looks at Planetside 2*

Oh and I have played since closed beta in 2012. For whatever that's worth.

But yeah, onto what makes MWO good and better than atleast 100% F2P launches on Steam in 2015.
IT'S NOT P2W
Shock, horror a F2P game on Steam that isn't P2W? The humanity!
Sure you can pay for 'mechs with the ingame MC and they can be rather expensive, so my advice? Don't, it's easy to rack up money with the cadet bonus which extends to 25 games netting you around 10mil, the tutorial gives you like 5 million to start and doesn't force you to purchase stupid things for the sake of a tutorial that 5 mil it gives you, is all yours.
Speaking of money, let's talk in game money 'mech prices. The cheapest is currently the Locust, a 20 light 'mech, starting at around 1,388,241 and peak at  1,777,326 C-bills. This doesn't include upgrade costs like Double heat sinks or endo steel structures or even the paramont need for an XL engine, which can easily cost around 5/7,000,000 C-Bills on a light 'mech.
The most expensive? The Executioner a 95 ton Clan 'mech that can 'sprint' for short durations, has jumpjets and some of the most tanky hitboxes seen in any Clan 'mech. Ranging from 17,505,967 to 18,142,422 C-bills (In lore it was far more expensive at around 36,000,000 C-Bills so thank God that isn't a thing.)
There are however 'mech packs released occassionaly on the Website, these typically contain 4 Battle/Omni Mechs.

Battlemech packs including Clan IIC 'mechs start off at $20 and peak at $80.
Omnimech packs start at $30 and speak at $120.
These little packs can be hit or miss, personally I'd only go for them when released as they have a 'Early Adopter' bonus which gives more value to the pack within the first 30 days of it originally going on sale.

PGI have recently started doing solo packs as well starting off with the venerable Urbanmech, followed by everyone's fave the Marauder, in January the Warhammer, February the Rifleman and finally in March the good old Archer. These are $20 for the standard pack which has three variants and a little bit extra on the side, the collector's which has a nice paint job for the 'Prime' variant and a 30% C-Bill increase for that 'mech which is $40 and the Hero add-on which is $15 and can be purchased with either the Collector's or the Standard.

There is a grind, like every game practically ever. And is frustrating at start, you may get hate for starting which is stupid yet it happens everywhere, still don't let what they say bog you down, they most likely started off in the same place a while back. To minimize stress and whatnot, look at the forums and search for in game units, they most likely will have a teamspeak server or something on those lines and trust me, premaking is what makes this game amazing, the fact you have a team you can actually talk to and will listen to orders if given and also, y'know you can talk to people rather than yourself when playing a game, which is good. Before you know it, you'll have like ten games played and the time would've flied.

I rate this game, legit, 8.5/10, it's a Mechwarrior game, it's not the perfect Mechwarrior game, but they're taking it in a nice direction ever since they seperated from IGP.

Play it.

reviewText:
This is my all time favorite game.  Ive been playing for 3 years now and I still get home and want to play it in the afternoons.
I came from CS:GO where I spent alot of my time being gunned down by players who were just quicker than me.  MWO is a thiking mans shooter, as the slogan goes.  It doesnt so much matter about raw reaction time but more planning and awareness.
I imagine the initial learning curve can be harsh, once you get your cadet bonus, have a look around online and see which mechs are recommended.  Alot of this game relies on finding the right combination of mech and weaponry and there in lies the fun.  So many mechs to play, so many build types, so many formulas.  1 person can be good at a certain style and another a totally different style.  Finding out what works is amazing.
Give it a go and stick with it for a while.

reviewText: Been playing on and off since beta and I highly recommend this game if you want a different kind of FPS experience. The gameplay is slower and more tactical than about any other FPS on the market, not only in the way you have to focus on team play but also how you have to fight. With the ability to destroy parts of the enemy mech you have to make choices in the heat of the battle, do you go for the kill by destroying the center torso or do you first destroy their ability to fight efficiently by destroying their weapons (arms and/or side torso)? The game gives you a lot of different possibilities on how you want to fight, just keep in mind, this game will punish you hard of you try to do the Rambo".\n\nThe game has its problems

reviewText: I found this game a little over a year ago and fell in love with it. I have been playing battletech/mechwarrior games since the late 80's and this was the first one that has a robust multiplayer mode. The game has been evolving since I first joined the ranks of MWO pilots. It is really an enjoyable game that allows me to immerse myself in Battletech Lore and Mech Combat. The addition of Community Warfare last year upped the intensity of the game. PGI has really listened to the community and added funcitionality while maintaining balanced play. I am glad I invested in Mech Packs along the way as I could get some much needed experience in a wider variety of Mechs than I would otherwise have been able to get ( I am not the best pilot, so C-Bills are hard to comeby). I really recommend this game to any Battletech Fan, or those FPS players who are looking for something different to develop you skills and enjoyment. See you on the Battlefield...

reviewText:
This is a condensed version of my full review that can be found HERE[legionofmyth.com].

---------------------------------------------------------

What I hate about MechWarrior Online:
1. This is NOT Battletech – and shouldn’t even be allowed to wear the name.

If you are a Battletech fan and want to play this because of Battletech, leave now. Do not play MechWarrior Online!!

Here are just a small list of the glaring examples of how MWO has nothing to do with Battletech:
Pin-point fire.
No physical attacks.
Water has no effect on movement.
2. General game play issues.

Community Warfare leaves a lot to be desired. Quite simply, it’s pointless and boring.

The game needs more maps – maybe slow down on the ‘Mech releases and create more maps for a while.  (Though I really do love seeing Marauders and WarHammers in the game.)

With the exception of River City the redesigned maps haven’t really impressed me.  Forest Colony is especially horrible; it went from being my favorite map in the game – by far – to my third most hated (after Terra Therma and Viridian Bog.)

What I love about MechWarrior Online:
If this game was called Giant Stompy Robots Online (GSRO) – which is what I am going to call it from here on out – I would be a pretty big fan of the game.

The improvements made to GSRO in the last year or more have been slow, but plentiful and (generally) well done.  It's true that PGI may never repair the trust they lost with many of us Founders; however, as a generic Giant Stompy Robot shooter goes, it is good and getting better.

The quirk system is mostly working, 'Mech modules are a neat way to add minor (but helpful) features to your 'Mech, and any balance problems seem to be minor.  Remember, an online game like this is always in flux as the players and meta-game change.

If you’re the type of person like likes to play a game for 30 minutes, knock out a couple of drops then return to reality, you can’t go wrong with Giant Stompy Robots Online.  If you’re like me and you binge play for a few hours once a week, you still can’t go wrong with Giant Stompy Robots Online.

---------------------------------------------------------

As much as I do not want to like this game – (I want to hate GSRO and I want to keep making horribly offensive remarks toward the PGI development team) – but I can’t keep hating it. Some day, someone will make a real Battletech/MechWarrior game, until then Giant Stompy Robots Online will keep me entertained.

Hate: It’s NOT Battletech no matter how you try to ram that down my throat.

Love: It is a good Giant Stompy Robot Shooter.  The changes they have made in the last few months really have improved the game substantially.

Against my own angst and animosity toward MechWarrior Online and PGI, I would not be a fair reviewer if I did not recommend the game.  I play it, I have fun, and I look forward to playing it more.  Just remember, it is NOT Battletech or anything legitimately belonging to the Battletech/MechWarrior IP.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game since right before Clans dropped, when fellow clanmates got me into it. As such, I have no gripes with what the publisher and devs did before I started playing, unlike so many people who are still salty about this game's beginnings. As it stands now, it's a fun mech game which focuses on player positioning, teamwork, and mech customizability.

One factor that the salty ones are going to rant about is that they think the devs are greedy. Yes, the monotization model is rather expensive, but the game is not pay to win. You can play and enjoy the game just fine without shelling out any money. In fact, as a closed beta World of Tanks player, I can say the game is better priced and less pay to win than world of tanks is.

I suggest you play and make up your own mind about this game. No point in not even giving it a chance. After all, it's free to play.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is amazing. The combat gets my heart racing so fast. Exhilarating combat experiences await when you have a good team leader and team mates.
However, if you are flying solo, it can turn into a complete slaughterfest very quickly and very often. This game needs to be played with a group of people who are willing to march as one coherent group.

Then we have the game store. This completely kills it for me. if you have the money you can buy everything you want. No need to grind in-game credits when you can avoid it entirely with $20-50. This makes the grind a wall setup to impede free players.
What my biggest gripe of all is there is no way to expand your mech capacity for free. You have to spend hundreds in order to collect these mechs. And collecting is fun! It's not fun selling your hard grind just to make room for another mech. This one shot the score down for me. I would be willing to forgive most of the shop, but not this one.

Pros:Beautiful graphics.
The world and the mech models are amazing.

Amazing combat.
This combat is action packed when it heats up and you can feal the heat! Some feel the fights are too slow paced. I however like it. Big hulking machines pounding each other as if there is no tomorrow.

Completely team oriented.
You need team work or you fall apart fast! This is kind of a con at the same time if you don't find a team to play with. You wont have as much fun if you solo queue.

VOIP built in.
It doesn't sound bad and mostly works well. Still recommend using your own VOIP with the team you play with. Communication is key in this game and this was well needed to be built in.
Cons:Too few free mech slots.
You end up having to buy additional space for your mechs with real money. If you dont have space for another, you have to sell it. That's terrible!

MicroTransation store can purchase anything and has exclusives mechs.
This store is completely anti-free player. It has the essential Mech garages (needed to increase mech slots), exclusive mechs and every mech available. There is nothing you can't buy with this store.
No free way to obtain this pay currency on a regular basis.

Needless Grind.
The games grind is 100% setup to hold free players back. The store is a shortcut to buy your way out of it.

Match Making.
It will put you up against a complete pre-made. You will get slaughtered and you will get this often if you fight alone.
Overall Rating:76/100

PC Specs
Hardware        Type                CPU        Intel i7-3770k @ 4GHz                GPU        EVGA Nvidia 680GTX                RAM        16GB DDR3 2133                OS        Windows 10 Pro

reviewText:
If you played any of the older games you'll know what your getting into.

Getting started:

step 1 : Play some rental mechs
step 2 : Take a look at the store page
step 3 : Save up for the mech chassis you like most
step 4 : Buy it and customize it into whatever you want it most to be.

Intresting things are this game has no tiering system and yet it works great. If you don't want to go crazy you don't have to customize a mech at all, as there are variations on every single one in the store, along with a premium version that earns more exp.

Only real con i can come up with is they don't have ALL the mechs I want. But they are still adding them it the order they were made... So if the mech you want isn't in game, it probably will be eventually.

All in all I would highly recomend this game if you want to play a mech game that isn't to zippy like some of the ones are today.

reviewText:
If you like Mobile Suit Gundam, Macross, Pacific Rim, or even played any of the BattleTech games (tabletop from the 80's or video games in the franchise) you'll want to give this one a go. It fills in that niche giant robot slot you've been craving.
The game appears like your poorly-interactive-MMORPG at first glance (it took me a couple days to figure out just WTF is going on in the Mechlab), but once you get the hang of the wealth of information presented, it becomes much more intuitive. Every piece on the screen, in-game or in-menu, serves a purpose and tells you something. It just takes a bit to get used to it.
The piloting segment of the game is very fun but is a challenge to do well. Many aspects are occuring at once, and it's up to you to manage them all effectively (ex. heat management, ammo, presenting armor, etc.). If you are a tanker (World of Tanks, War Thunder, Armored Warfare, etc.) you can apply your knowledge directly to this game and do pretty well. If you aren't, the learning curve is about the same. The idea is to play smarter, not harder. Coordinate with your team and you'll likely take home the big money.
My biggest credit to this game after playing more Pay2Win games is the free-to-play model. The game is very much playable for free; in fact, the game will help you grind for your first 'Mech, and even so, supplies you with rental" Trial 'Mechs throughout the game. There also isn't a progression tree
date: so you choose what you want to play

reviewText:
TLDR: Dont even bother, if you cant tell from the over priced packes on the store page, this game is a Freemium title running on a minimumly viable build, and will continue to do so for a long time. The developers prioritze money (overpriced mechpacks) over any real content, it's shown through the lack of finished content added to the game in the last two years. If you really want to give it a try, go for it, just set your standards low. It's not a AAA title, its not even close to finished. In fact there's little this game does well. If you want to know more, please read below, and thank you for your time.

My experience: I've played off and on since its release, mostly off, because the game hasn't changed much since release. A few maps have been added, but the over all main problems are still in the game. The worst part being the developers lack of effort to really fix them.

PROS:

- Its freaking mechs!! Battle Tech Mechs!

- They hold monthlyish contests in the Clan Warfare. Though CW is in beta and widely considered trash. Seriously its terrible. I'm not sure why they keep pushing people to play it.

- The community is helpful, only if you agree with them though. Dont say the game is bad around them lol.

- Its Free, but more on that in the cons.

- They do give you just enough to buy a low level mech at the start. Which is only a little nice since you'll be in that mech for a long time until you can buy another. The trail mechs are a joke and you don't gain exp on the mechs.

- Voting system for the 3 game modes. So you'll rarely have to play the terrible Conquest game mode or the terrible maps.

- The tutorial is probably the most polished part of the game. Note: They didn't make it, a third party did, which is why it looks nice

I honestly cant think of more things I like about the game. If I do ill add them. Now for the long list of cons.

CONS:

- PGI cant stop the hackers. Seriously.

- Global chat is NOT the game. It may be to limit people from knowing how many players are on.

- The UI for the mech bay is terrible, and that's after they revamped it.

- The UI for your friends/Unit/and LFG window is just a crappy block window. It doesn't even have ranks for your Unit.

- Few maps, made even fewer by the vote system. You'll constantly play same 5ish maps over and over because most of the maps are just that badly designed, and no one wants to play on them.

- Only ~3 game modes. Skirmish, TDM, and Conquest. Skirmish and TDM are pretty much the same. Conquest is the worst mode due to the maps not being designed for it and teammates not knowing what do to. So

-  Its freaking mechs!! Battle Tech Mechs!

- They hold monthlyish contests in the Clan Warfare. Though CW is in beta and widely considered trash. Seriously its terrible. I'm not sure why they keep pushing people to play it.

- The community is helpful, only if you agree with them though. Dont say the game is bad around them lol.

- Its Free, but more on that in the cons.

- They do give you just enough to buy a low level mech at the start. Which is only a little nice since you'll be in that mech for a long time until you can buy another. The trail mechs are a joke and you dont gain exp on the mechs.

- Voting system for the 3 game modes. So you'll rarely have to play the terrible Conquest game mode or the terrible maps.

- The tutorial is probably the most polished part of the game. Note: They didnt make it, a third party did, which is why it looks nice

I honestly cant think of more things I like about the game. If I do ill add them. Now for the long list of cons.

CONS:

- PGI cant stop the hackers. Seriously. Hack the ♥♥♥♥ out of this game. They cant stop you.

- Global chat is NOT the game. It may be to limit people from knowing how many players are on.

- The UI for the mech bay is terrible, and thats after they revamped it.

- The UI for your friends/Unit/and LFG window is just a crappy block window. It doesnt even have ranks for your Unit.

- Few maps, made even fewer by the vote system. You'll constantly play same 5ish maps over and over because most of the maps are just that badly designed, and no one wants to play on them.

- Only ~3 game modes. Skirmish, TDM, and Conquest. Skirmish and TDM are pretty much the same. Conquest is the worst mode due to the maps not being designed for it and teammates not knowing what do to. So almost every match in any game mode will boil down to death balling from cover until a team has a huge lead.

- The balance in this game is all over the place, because PGI will completely destroy a weapons/mechs and leave them broken with little hope of ever fixign them. Their style is to nuke the flavor of the past 6 months instead of trying to bring the game to a blanced playing field.

- The monetization of the game is quite possiblely one of the worst I've ever seen. From Mechs packs being sold from $30 bucks to an astonishing $220. Thats a premium price for an unfinished game that doesnt have a bright future in terms of content.

- The Free part of the game is laughable. Only mechs may be bought with in-game money at an exorbitant price for each one. Then you have to buy weapons, a new engine, modules, for your mech. The cost alone to deck out a mech far exceeds the cost of the mech it's self sometimes. If you want to max out said mech you have to repeat that process , except the modules, for 2 more times to buy the other variants. That whole process will take months of play just to max out a SINGLE mech. Math: You will make around ~100,000 C-bills a match. Mechs range from 12mil to 20mil or more. And thats just for the mech, not all the gear. Also those other variants you will buy are most of the time really bad.

- Cosmetics cost around 15 bucks to really make a  SINGLE   mech look unique.

- Gameplay is stale af and slooowww

- The common tactic is to just shoot and go into cover, and sit there until a team has a large number advantage. If you have dreams of being a brawler, keep dreamig.

- Maps end up being narrow/wide long range path ways with little cover to effectively push up and get close to enemy mechs. Leading to my point above.

- The meta is centered around alpha striking only (How much damage and be done in a single shot.) Rarely will you see someone going a DPS build because that dont work. The DPS weapons need to be up close to be effective. See above why that sucks.

- The sounds effects and motions of the mechs dont feel visceral. Giant 25-100 ton mechs walking around dont feel very large. The massive weapons dont sound like the 16inch cannon they are suppose to really feel/sound like. Even the more power weapons feel like their smaller counter parts.

- Clan Warfare is the biggest joke in the game. If your Unit takes a planet from someone else...good job. Thats all you get. C-bill reward is higher for each match, but you need 4 fully fleshed mechs to really be on par with the enemy, and if you dont do well you wont get a great reward. Also you will be mostly playing against a 12 man team. Thus making solo dropping pointless unless you want you be fighting a losing battle from the start.

- The community is torn into two groups those who are burned by the developers who not making the game the promised and those who spent too much money on the game to see it die and watch their money go to waste. Just check the message boards on Steam, Reddit, and dont bother on their main forum. They auto delete/downvote any criticism that isn't praising the game at the sametime. Seriously I'll be surprise if you see this review.

- A small development team means VERY SLOW small releases if they arent delayed for months.

- The small development team has a long history of lies to their player base about what content they are working on.

- Graphic are just ok, and battle damage looks like something made in MSPaint.

reviewText:
This is an awful game.

The balance and gameplay changes have consistently taken a turn for the worse, and the equivalent of the star wars NGE experience is about to hit it.

Most mechs that you use will be bad, or one particular variant of it will be good. In order to actually use it, you will have to grind out several variants of it that are abominable and make you farming fodder for long-time players (which is everyone still playing)

The pricing for the F2P is catered exclusively to a few remaining whales. Unless you want to pay the full price of a regular game for one mech chassis (why would you?) then don't bother.

The developers are known scam artists. They have consistently missed deadlines and outright lied about promised features or things they would never do (clan mechs, 3rd person view, etc.)

My verdict is do not buy this game. You will be farming fodder for long-time players in a dying game with an intolerable grind, lying developers, and an obscene pricing system. If you love mechwarrior, go install one of the older games instead of playing this.

reviewText:
I've played the game since founders beta so on and off since 2012.

This game hasn't fixed its huge issues for years.

Mech combat is poorly balanced, favouring clans, the more expensive faction, since they were released.

The grind is rough, the first 25 matches gives you a large bonus so you can buy one IS mech and most of its upgrades. But that is only once and each new mech requires some basic upgrades like double heatsinks, a necessary update at 1.5 million for every mech, endo-steel, and new engines and weapons. After you get one mech you need to master 2 other variants of the same chassis to unlock the skills required to compete with veterans who have been playing for a long time.

The queue times are probably the biggest killer, taking 5+ minutes to find a basic match for the game's most common game mode and that's the fastest it gets. Community Warfare queues can take up to 30 minutes.

Game modes in this game are all really simplistic with the TDM and team conquest styles because really basic kill-all-enemies is fine but the community warfare mode is completely lacking on any deeper roles or meaning despite it being supposedly the final game mode for faction vs faction warfare. Factions are so empty that everyone jumps around to whatever faction has enough people and there's no meaning to planetary losses or gains.

Overall, this game has been developed poorly for years, minimal viable product being an actual term used to describe it by the developers, and this is just an attempt to gain a few more people before the game goes under. The free to play game is usually described as having whales to make money and a large amount of people to fill the game so everyone's happy. MWO is a game that only has whales left and they're desperate for the game to appeal to people who don't want to spend hundreds of dollars on this game.

reviewText:
I've got more than a couple hours into this game, playing on and off for about a year and a half. It can be a fun game, and is most of the time, but there is a ludicrous amount of grinding to make progress, even for a free to play game.

15+ hours of gameplay to unlock a single top tier mech is ridiculous, especially when you have to buy three variants (all for full price, mind you) to maximize the potential of a single mech. This adds up to hundreds of hours played to field a decent mech of each weight class, and when new mechs are released which are clearly superior to mechs already in circulation, the frustration caused by either devoting over a hundred hours of your time just to stay competitive is... significant.

Hopefully the steam release will increase the size of the community enough to motivate PGI to fix the balance issues and ease the grind but I am not optimistic.

reviewText:
I backed this game in 2012 due to my love of battletech. A love that this game has poisoned.

As a gamer, is this a terrible game? No. It sorta works, there is some fun to be had here. The F2P model is terrible, its grindy and expensive. Worse than wargaming games. But if you throw away some money and grind forever, it can be fun. Sadly, the whole 'outfit your mech' doesnt work well here. You generally have to set your mech up with whatever flavor of the month builds are working to be competitive. If you end up wasting your hard earned cash on the wrong part and/or mech, you're in for a bad time. Even some of the paid stuff is garbage.

As a battletech game, it is blasphemy. Nothing is right about this game, the devs know nothing about battletech. They just jumped on the license, hired someone else to make this game.. then fired those guys and went on to milk battletech fans for their money. Now they are here to milk you for your money. Seriously, go watch some of their videos. They are canadian car salesmen, not programmers or gamers.

Ultimately, I hate this game, I hate the devs, and I hate the spineless legion of white knights who hold this turd up in the spotlight. Most positive reviews will come from these guys, they are all 500+ dollars in and they desperately do not want the game to die. They want you to play and will say anything to get you to play. They are sad broken people, and if you do get sucked into scam warrior online you will end up sad and broke as well.

UPDATE: Just to be sure i tried the steam version. Some things are better than i remember, some things are worse. The most dissapointing issue is that groups of 2 are still put against groups of up to 9+. So if you want to play with just one friend, you are doomed to constant and quick defeats. And no, the devs will not fix this. This is INTENTIONAL. They are feeding you to their whales who have dropped $1000's into this game.

Also the time to kill is way too low. You spend 90% of the time loading, and walking to the spot where you will die. This is not a thinking mans" shooter."

reviewText:
Of Mice, 'Mechs, and Star Lords: Threads of Ambition
Once upon a time in the late 20th Century, in an era of vintage classics, the great Lords of Gaming bestowed upon their subjects a series called MechWarrior. Those were good times indeed.

In those days I had happened upon a copy of MechWarrior 2, after being an obsessive fan of sci-fi simulation games like X-Wing, and strapped in to my first Mech Simulator and powered up - All Systems Nominal." Everything got better from there that is until the Golden Century of Gaming had ended and the Great League of Publishers fell into dissarray (or were destroyed by the Word of EA and Microsoft).

reviewText:
A game that could be great held back by a terrible developer.
Short version first:
I had played this game during closed beta and for roughly 2 years after that. I stopped playing just after the release of the Clan mechs. I was disgusted with the developers choices and behavior. This made me and my friends decide to stop playing entirely. The game could be good but the developer holds it back.

ProsIt's a new Mechwarrior game.
The controls are pretty good.
Deep and rewarding customization.
Combat can be pretty rewarding.
Team play can also be rewarding.
Deep backstory.

ConsThe developer.
Long delays in changes, balance, and content releases.
Many lies about release dates and pay to win elements.
Convoluted and sometimes frustrating game systems (Heat Scale is the big one here)
Did I forget to mention the developer?
Bait and switch sale tactics for content releases.
Balance, but this is typical in a game with such freedom and inherently built-in unbalance in the original game this is based on.
Russ Bullock, Paul Innouye (Trained by Nexon), and Bryan Eckman.
The grind is beyond ridiculous last I played.
Oh and finally, the Developer.
Seriously, these guys made Navy SEALS: Weapons of Mass Destruction.

Now for the long version.
Through a glitch in the developer's website I got an invite into the closed beta. The game was much simpler then and was actually pretty fun. I told my friends about the game, got them into the open beta, and we had a lot of fun. Then they started adding in some missing gameplay elements and we started to see how the developer was going to handle introducing systems and balancing. As timed passed we've played through an LRMpocalypse, Squawkalypse, ECMalypse, Splat-cats, Poptartpocalypse, and the Return of the LRMpocalypse: The Quirkening. We played through all of this. All during this time it seemed as if the developer that was creating these new systems were not the original developer of the game.

Once Clans were released ($500 for a gold-plated one) is when we really saw the developer's true colors. You could not purchase the 'Mechs in game unless you spent money. They were quite a bit more powerful than the regular IS 'Mechs (they technically were supposed to be...). This forced you into a terrible situation where you were playing with IS 'Mechs and losing often or spend money and winning 90% of the time. All of us gave up on the game shortly after this. We've watched the descent of the game's population ever since.

The grind, last I played, was particularly awful. It required many days of consistently good matches to be able to afford a single new chassis with no upgrades. You also could not test-drive them. If you choose the wrong one, you were out the money... no refunds.

I mean, I really like Mechwarrior and Battletech. I used to have a spinning wireframe Timberwolf from Mechwarrior 2 as my Avatar. I really wanted to like this game... but, after ~2 years of abuse from the developer I just couldn't take it anymore.

tl;drI do not recommend this game, especially if [you're] on a bit of on an island"."

reviewText:
Played this for about a year and a half before the glaring issues eventually forced myself and my friends to quit. To start expect a heavy pay to win experience or at best a pay to not grind three weeks for a standard mech. Also expect to be charged ridiculous amounts of cash to obtain hero mechs or even just mechbays or colors/patterns. Seriously it's in the neighborhood of $30+ PER MECH. Don't even think about the bundles and such as you'll get very little for $100+. Just standard mechs you can buy in game a little faster and MAYBE a bonus mech with a slight cbill boost.

Once you get into the game expect two things. Fun stompy mech action and complete and utter bs metabuilds. In my time it went from LRMs for a brief period to PPC/Gauss builds. The PPC/Gauss was the worst because it was instant pinpoint HIGH damage. You'd wait 5-10 minutes for a match and die in seconds if you weren't in a light or assault class. Unless you got lucky matchmaking wise and the other team wasn't loaded with 5-6 metabuilds and you'd get a decent match. After the forced mech setup for matchmaking requiring x of each class it got a little more even in matches but the wait times went skyhigh. Eventually the high alpha BS and long wait times drove myself and my friends to stop playing.

The company also has issues. One of the WORST I've ever dealt with. I understand Niko left a bit ago but still damn. They also can't balance their way out of a paper bag. Things get buffed WAY too far or not remotely enough and stay that way for months if not years. It took them six months or so to even start to nerf the high alpha metagame and even then it was weak nerfs that did very little curb it. Not even the bizarre ghost heat changes ever successfully killed it. The highest alpha to a side torso or center torso is the only real way to fight with any real success.

I will admit before the issues started piling up and things with the company got worse it was a blast. It really captures the stompy mech action quite well. However the magic is long gone so if you play do it without wasting money like I did. Get in, do a couple rounds for some fun, and get out when the lopsided matches get to be too much. The trial/standard mechs work well enough for light play. As long as you don't invest too much time or money it's a perfectly fine game to play a match or two on occassion.

EDIT - It seems they fixed up the wait times at some point. So it's faster to get into a game. The rest still stands.

reviewText:
This game is like mustard:
-There are people who hate it while others who love it. It all depends on what you personally enjoy.
- It takes a while to get used to so dont get discouraged if it leaves a bad taste after a while for it does get better with  repetition and experience. (steep learning curve)

Pros:
- It's free so you wont lose anything if you give it a try.
- No pay to win through added steroids and costly rare seeds.
- Many and continued improvements throughout the years
- Enjoyable and clean game play
- Plays best when accompanied by other helpful entities (TEAMWORK and friends)
- Many play styles to choose from like up close and personal or support (I like my mustard off to the side)
- Occasional free items through eating contests
- Many varieties to choose from (mech variants)
- Friendly community of enthusiasts

Cons:
- Lack of teamwork will make the game sour and spoil the experiance
- Stains carpet
- Pay for branding (colors/camo/aesthetics)
- Some minor ingredient imbalances but nothing really worth throwing it out over
- Learning what play style you enjoy EARLY in game given limited starting resources can be frustrating

Final thoughts:
I dont really see this game as much of a grinding type game due to the enjoyment i get out of it. Given that, either you will enjoy it or you wont. I find this game relaxing and fun to play, plus it's free which is just an added bonus and gives ME an incentive to help the developers through in game purchases such as camo, colors, warhorns or to obtain mechs sooner. Not like other twitch FPS but requires thought and stradegy given lots of different variables.

There is a lot to learn so do the tutorial and look up mechspecs to help you out and then fine tweak it to your play style.  I sucked at this game at first but at least give 10hrs(?) of play time to develop an understanding of game play mechanisms and tactics before leaving the community which may be hard to ask for someone to do.

reviewText: Its a decent stompy robot game, but its got alot of problems.  the biggest is the low turnaround to fixing issues with the game.\n\nWeapon balance has been outta whack for some time with some weapons being unusable for years.  There is generally only one major balance pass" a year rather than iterative changes

voteText: that have been basically ignored.\n\nThere are issues with map and gamemode design.  For gamemodes
helpfulPercent: the problem is that theres only 3 modes
votesHelpful: and most of the time theres no real difference between the 3 of them.  Map design has a tendency to funnel everyone to the same spots every game
votesTotal:
due to a combo of defensive terrain in select areas and both teams starting spread out rather than togeather.  By the time you grouped with ur team you are under attack or about to be.  This makes most maps seem very small and cramped no matter how large they are because ur fighting in the same small defensive areas.

The time to kill (TTK) is very low as well.  There has been alot of power creep in this game to the point where a game which involves huge stompy mechs of doom that are supposed to dominate the battlefield instead plays more like COD with mechs hunkering down behind cover and popping out to fire and duck back in.  The TTK has been shinking for years  with no end or solution in sight.

There is a part of the game called "Community Warfare" (or CW) which allows you to pick one of 10 factions and fight each other for control of the galaxy.  In reality the population is too low and most of the time its the Innsershere vs the Clans which gets real old after awhile.  In addition the issues with map design and gamemodes are even worse in CW

reviewText:
I'm gonna write this negative review, and then not reply to ANYONE that whishes to whiteknight this turd for no reason other than the fact that, in their hearts, they wish that they were space nazis with no parents.

Look, I was there.  I played this game on a table top, where company-level games between two players took an hour for one turn, and I loved it.  I played many incarnations of Mechwarrior on the PC, from Cresent Hawks Inception the Mechwarrrior 4, and I loved it.  I was there in the early days of closed beta, when we still had all the goodies that Cryengine 3 could deliver, like inverse kinematics and all that, and I loved it.

Now, like three years later, after launching a beta product as a general release, after not having more than two game modes between pick up death match and community warfare (and don't come back and say that there are three game modes in public death match, they all boil down to skirmish in the end), I have absolutely no reason to believe that this product is anything more than a shameless cash grab aimed at the absolute bottom of the gamer community, one that thought that the previous games were too hard" or too "niche"

reviewText:
Arena combat shooter with stompy robot's that function similar to tanks. This game has a lot of content, and lots of customization. Fan's of classic MechWarrior will feel familiar, and new players have a great tutorial to study.

Don't expect 360 no scope headshots, mech's take time and tactics to kill.

Despite critisim from some battletech loyalists, the game is on par with most popular F2P titles like WarThunder and WoT. It recently become more balanced and less 'grindy' and you can unlock 95% of the games content for free (playing monthly events also rewards you with free swag).

Investing in Hero mech's and premium time is well priced, and worth doing to keep the game alive.

reviewText:
I have played this game since close beta and I enjoy it.

It is the nicest time since I have started to be a free to player. There are many more free items in the game then ever previously.

So to the basics-

The Good:
-Basic mechanics feel good.
-Balance has had a lot of work done and is in a good place.
-The mechs look and feel good.
-The sound design is solid.
-One of the best team games on the internet now for 12 v 12 fighting. I know because I have been looking.
- The community is passionate. For good and bad they are passionate. There is a subreddit dedicated to the fall of PGI and great competitive leagues! For good and bad they are super into the game and this is awesome.
-The devs are much more responsive than in the past and are improving the game quicky. It has been the best year for this game so far.

The Mediocre:
-Does not use the lore as well as It could.
-There could be more focus on mechanical development and not just items in game (this has improved a LOT in the last year so its not in the bad category.)
- The pricing. I have spent a lot of money on this game but thats because I enjoy it. IT is not the best or the worst F2p model. (I would say Dota 2 is better while most is worse, such as World of anything or warthunder.)


The Bad:
- No single player.
- There is repetition. It is a arena fighter but Community warfare has helped with this.

Do I enjoy it tho? I love this game. Whenever I do not play for a week, I come back to it and remember it is great.

reviewText:
I played this game from closed beta. Many fun times where had, it felt like a reasonably good battletech game, there was only a handfull of mechs, there was no Double heatsinks basically 3025 tech. When wanting to play a match it was easy to get a drop in, click launch and wham you were in and playing.

If you wanted to play with friends you could group up and easily get into a match. There was repair and rearm mechanic which was a good way to govern people running munchkin builds.

Over time numerous changes were made that made this game less and less fun, until finally I was forced to stop playing with the introduction of cockpit glass, since then I never went back.

Now with the introduction of steam I thought I would be fair and have another crack at this game I used to like playing, however sadly it just does not have it. It is not what I would expect from a mechwarrior game, it is very shallow, limited repetive gameplay. The tier system is not a true ranking system and the only goal in the game is to pokemech so you can collect them all.

The mech chassis are mostly just skins, and lack real variety or flavour, you have a few key loadouts replicated multiple times with just a different look. Since I last played it looks like they introduced the quirk system, this attempts to provide some unique flavour to mechs, but is more complicated then it needs to be and you need to play spreadsheetwarrior to be able to make sense of it. If mech customization was a bit more restricted I feel the balance would have been more natural then the artifiial quirk system that was introduced.

Since the lack of repair and rearm munchkin builds became prolific, and continue to do so to this day, there is no consequence to running the most expensive kit in your assault mech. Every other F2p games introduce a repair mechanic and it works quite well as a natural balance mechanic, ala World of warships, World of tanks ,Warthunder and Armored Warfare and it manages to work quite well but PGI could not make it work.

The graphics looked great back in Closed beta and were amazing, nowdays they are very hohum, the mech Models up to a certain point look pretty decent, but looking at some of the more recent releases, it looks like they are just calling it in doing the Bare minimum to pump out mech packs. The textures and effects are very dated looking now. Whether that is the age showing , or as Ihave heard they have dumbed the quality down because they couldn't make the game run optimally on higher settings I don't know.

The community is polar opposites generally, you have black knights who hate the game with a passion, and the white knights who love the game like it was brought to us by the messiah. In my eyes both are wrong and the game is just meh.

I may try a few more sync drops with friends that still club pugs over the next few days as that is the only way to get matches going quick enough, but taking the game as it stands today I find it a very shallow and meaningless game, unable to easily and quickly drop with friends for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles anymore.

The beauty of it being F2P is you can try it out and make your own decision as to whether you want grind away or pay to skip.

reviewText:
Fantastic game, has had it's ups and downs in development, yet it always bounces back better than before. Give the game a try, and play at LEAST 25 matches before deciding if you want to keep playing or not because this gives you all the rewards for being a new player. Shuffle through the different trial mechs during these games, as this will help pin down your best play style. Each mech plays differently. To help minimize frustration as you learn;

Tips and tricks:
-Lrms have a minimum range of 180m (unless they are clan-tech)
-When playing lights always keep moving.
-3rd person hurts you in major ways.
-Be aware of things like your armor paper doll. Even when you think you are safe someone could be shooting you in the back.
-When you see an enemy mech press R" this locks onto the target and transmits data to your team. It also helps in picking already damaged parts of a mech to shoot at.
-Avoid running off
date: and stick with the team. Stragglers often meet untimely demises.\n-Don't be the first one in line when in combat. Frontline units are the first to die.\n-Spreading damage across your mech is key; twist your body while not firing in combat
recommended: as you become a better pilot this   will be more natural. Choosing a shoulder/arm to always show is also helpful when one side has less weapons.\n\nHope this helped. Good luck
hoursPlayed: and have fun!"

reviewText:
Ok, so unlike alot of commentaries here I'm not going to discuss the progression of this game since Closed Beta, through Open Beta to today. Today is what matters, as the game goes to STEAM.  To be up front, I have about 11,500 matches under my belt and hundreds of hours of game play so I'm not new to the game, it's background or it's challenges.

Video fx/Graphics (8): The artwork for the Mechs is fantastic imo. Even if you don't necessarily agree with the direction of the Art team or modeling of the Mechs, they still look well done and attractive. Intimidating and lethal, they look much as any fan of the intellectual property of BattleTech might imagine. I deducted points here due to some pixelated terrain that looks like a game from 2003 in places and some odd modeling/animation mistakes. Additionally, some of the mechs need a scaling overhaul, as some smaller tonnage mechs are larger than mechs in heavier weight classes. Overall tho, a great effort and all indications are this will get better.

Audio (9): Again, barring some minor aesthitic disagreements, the sound effects are well done and the game sounds good during gameplay. Autocannons have a great bang/crunch mechanic, lasers sound vicious and explosions/getting hit add to the immersion.

Immersion (6): This is where the video excellence and audio excellence fall short, in tandem with other things that are decidedly lacking. The musical backdrop is solid usually, but there are no immersive ingame sounds. While you are in the Mechlab/game join screens. If I'm in some giant bay somewhere modifying a 60-ton warmachine, shouldn't there at least be some air-wrenches screaming or the sounds of metal clanging or SOMETHING besides simple music? Missed opportunity there. Additionally, there's no tie to a back story within the game. If you're not already familiar with the IP, most of the game will mean nothing to you nor does the game give you much information in that respect.

Backstory (0): PGI makes no effort to tie the grand-lore that sets this IP apart from any other walking-tanks" battlesim and misses out hugely there. Hiring some writers or poaching directly from the novels/game books that are associated with the IP would make sense here

reviewText:
I am not an old school mechwarrior, but I have played this game since 2013 and have enjoyed it immensely.  The community is great (although, there is quite a bit of disagreement between players about the game itself), and it is easy to find a friendly, mature group of people drop with.

People who say there is a learning curve are correct, don't be surprised if on your first drop you find yourself bouncing off walls and dying in a hail of fire.  Stick with it though, the controls are tight once you get a handle on them, and it gives you a sense of satisfaction when you finally get it down enough to effectively pilot a light mech.

I have enjoyed all of the game modes, although I wish there were a few more, and find customizing the mechs with the in game credits you earn to be endlessly enjoyable.

In short, this game is definitely worth a try for free.  (That said, saving up for mechs takes a good deal of time if you are going straight though in game credits and last I checked you do still need to buy mechbays to hold them.)

reviewText:
Certainly a thinking person's shooter. With communication, teamwork and stratagy dictating the skill ceiling of pilots. mWo is not for those who expect to play the game for a week and assume completion and own everything in the game. You will need to work hard at mastering the in ingame mechanics; switching views, torso twisting and information processing. The free to play format is perfection, PGI are generious if you put the time in. And even more generious If you use real currency in the game. Solo queue and go it alone expect the longest possible grind to attain your C-bills and Mech's. Join the forums and community, fast track your training and ability and understanding of the universe. Find a unit, join a house, perhaps become a loyalist and reap the rewards offered. This is a game that will keep you on your toe's, last the ages and give you friendships that will last a lifetime.

For those interested in making the most out of this game without spending money, each and everyday mechs have a x2 bonus on your first win for the day. So if you win a game on all the trail rotation mechs and play 1-2 community warfare games a day you make plenty of c-bills. There is also Cadet bonuses, faction rewards, tutorials and Achievements. Keep an eye out on your launch client as events that reward premium time and all sorts of goodies are a regular thing!

We welcome you steam to our war harden universe, see you on the battlefield warriors.  o7

reviewText:
Cons:

All the negative things you've already read about the devs are true. The price points for cash purchases are absurd. New mechs are released for real money at absurd prices ($30-$500) and are unbalanced but once available for in game currency they are nerfed down to match the rest more or less. The devs are morons... you can watch their video blogs if you don't believe me. It is true that they dropped the ban hammer when people disagree with them on forums. I have heard but not verified that they nerf mechs that beat them in game (I do believe this however because many of the nerfs they do are absurd and they never seem to nerf the mechs they play). The user interface is the worst I've ever seen. It is overthought, convoluted and rediculous. The current UI is the third version that I'm aware of. All 3 versions have been terrible and I can't say any version has been better than the other. It is absolute garbage. As you play and start to notice the fine tuning that could make this game good you will also notice the devs reall focus is on pumping out new mech variants at exorbidant prices. Ultimately this game is a money grab aimed at gen-x'ers who are established and may have a few bucks to blow on a ♥♥♥♥ game.

Now to end on a good note:
pros:

Actual gameplay is fun. I feel like I'm in a big lumbering badass mech.
That was actually the only pro.

In conclusion I'd say play the game if you want to drive a big mech but don't pay any money. I gave them $30 early on and have probably logged in the range of 500 to 1000 hours (what can I say? I do like driving a bigass mech). Despite this if I knew then what I know now I would pay $0 to get to play this game

There are other F2P games far more deserving of your support (Robocraft for example I have gladly given a little over $100 over the course of a year and would gladly do it all over again)

reviewText:
I'm sure there's been everything I've written down already said, and I'll also point out that I put in time since the closed beta, got the Atlas Founder's Pack and Overlord Phoenix pack (both of which I regret to this day), so I'll basically sum up first, and explain my biggest (not the only ones, just the biggest) beefs with this game. If you like Battletech/Mechwarrior, Don't Play This Game. It's not Mechwarrior, it's some sort of terrible World of Tanks clone wearing Battletech's skin. Don't even download the installer, just pop in that Mechwarrior 4: Mercenaries disc that I know you have, and play that until Jordan Weisman's real Battletech game comes out.

Let's put down some details.

The good stuff - The 'Mechs, and about 2 maps are real pretty. End of list.

The rest - The development of this game has honestly been a fantastic, 3-year long trainwreck in slow motion with 3-D effects. Although I'll mention that deciding to use Cryengine (an engine that is poorly optimized, and completely miserable to work with) is typically a good indicator that the developer has no clue what they're doing, they just want it to look pretty, that's not even the main problem.

The first biggest issue is they absolutely have no idea how to balance their game. It was busted in Beta, and they continue to keep busting it under the guise of fixing, but after this long in active development, it's pretty clear they have no idea how to make it an enjoyable, balanced game. Going back through the patch notes, you can see that they dance around several problems that they blatantly refuse to fix for who-knows-what reason, and as a result, certain mechanics such as ECM and about every other patch, missiles, have been broken and will continue to be so. The second issue in the balance bucket is their matchmaking system. if you want to do anything other than drop with 11 complete strangers, you have to drop into the team matchmaking, which can put you up against a full company team, while you and maybe 1 or two buddies just wanted to play a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game together, not get rolled 24/7 by full teams of meta/balance abusing goons.

Secondly, the pricing for their pay content is completely ludicrous. Don't feel like farming credits to get a new 'Mech? 15-20 dollars please. Oh, is that 'Mech a Hero Mech, I'm sorry, that will be 30-40 dollars, please. 5 dollars will get you a colour, though! Oh, that's colour singular, not like, a colour range, I'm sorry. No, if you want all of the purples, that will be about 50 dollars, please. But, if you pre-order our content for 80-120 dollars, you get 16 'Mechs, 3 colours, and a cosmetic item for your cockpit!

Lastly but not leastly, like with any fine, upstanding multiplayer-only title, the forums and in-game chat are roughly 99.9% a cesspit of vitriol and imbecility, and the remaining good bits are mostly folks making art.

This game goes in the deepest shame hole for making an absolute shambling mockery of this fantastic universe.
voteText: 21 of 43 people (49%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Oh, I forgot to mention this but it's important, the game has no aimbot detection. At all.

Mechwarrior Online is a game plagued with problems. I backed and founded the game based on the strength of the franchise, but I'm going to bring up any of my personal disappointments and the only mention of the Transverse fiasco will be right here. I'm giving this game a negative review for a few reasons, but if current trends continue I may choose to recommend the game instead.

PGI, when's the Flea coming out? It's been nearly two years since you announced it and MASC exists now. To whoever has the job of moderating the negative reviews, at least pass this question along when you moderate my review into oblivion.

With this review I mostly wanted to point out that the game typically goes months without anything resembling a balance update. MWO also features a few HIDDEN mechanics specifically designed to punish new players who don't know about it. That mechanic is colloquially known 'Ghost Heat,' which causes your BattleMech to gain additional (and often excessive) amounts of heat if you fire more than an arbitrary number of one type of weapon. This is never explained anywhere in game, and while the game does have a 'heat warning' that pops up in the mechlab if you've taken too many of one type of weapon that warning is small and easy to miss.

Up until about a month ago (over a year after MWO's launch) MWO was also completely without a tutorial, and the typical 'new player experience' was 'pick a trial `Mech at random, die three or four times without really understanding why, and uninstall the game.' If you didn't have a friend to show you the ropes or warn you about Ghost Heat or several of the other 'traps' (like LRMs currently being absolutely terrible weapons due to their slow speed, scattered damage, and tendency to ram into the nearest wall) you weren't going to make it very far.

This has changed, the tutorial is actually pretty nice, and there are some bonuses to help new players buy a BattleMech quickly so they can start customizing and using actually good weapons and the latest balance patch (the first one in MONTHS) has brought back a close-range brawling playstyle that's actually quite fun, but that doesn't change the fact that all of this was done immediately before the Steam launch and that the buffs to close-range weapons will almost certainly be reverted.

The real-money cost of BattleMechs is also completely absurd. They could cost a quarter what they do now and they'd still be expensive for a free-to-play game. An Assault BattleMech in MWO costs  Coupled with the fact that new releases often aren't balance-tested and aren't available for in-game currency for months after release means that new `Mechs are often pay-to-win, and due to the high prices (often approaching the cost of a AAA game for a `Mech pack or even a single Assault-weight BattleMech) this means that players who aren't shoveling their money directly into the furnace often become the punching bags of the players who are.

You also, and this is a real killer for me, have to spend real money on Mechbays (at around $1.38 per bay) to even buy a `Mech at all. Now, the MC cost of a Mechbay ultimately isn't that high, but it's another 'hidden' cost slowly nickel-and-diming the userbase to death.

MWO is a game best played with friends, and individual matches can be enjoyable once you get a handle on things. But the learning curve is steep even with a tutorial and you'll often waste tons of in-game C-Bills just trying things out. If you do play, my only advice is to save the 'Cadet Bonus' you earn over the course of your first 25 matches and buy a 55-ton Stormcrow. It's one of the most efficient `Mechs in the game and has access to the more powerful Clan versions of all the weapons, and will probably always be a good workhorse for grinding C-Bills in since it's fast enough to get to the fight and fast enough to get itself out of trouble.

Once you've learned what 'trouble' actually looks like.

reviewText:
Ladies & Gentlemen, boys & girls.
- This here isn't your average run of the mill game, and the amount of hatred & white-knighting is immense, when it comes to this game.
- Where does the great divide stem from?

- The Former Publisher IGP's calls of pushing PGI around. Right after IGP left the scene and PGI took over as a Publisher... everything changed.
- Within 6 months, Community Warfare Beta Phase 1 was released. By now, in around two years PGI has took the 'nigh toxic community by the horns. Cleared the air, voiced concerns & opinions. This sounds more like a company that loves its community, instead of whines for more money, like it originally was.
- Was I about to abandon ship when IGP was around? I seriously was. I would be raging here with the negative feedbacks along with the rest of 'em.

After PGI bought the publishing rights from IGP, everything changed:
PGI is fixing the game, a milestone at a time, and thus far... it has delivered. +100 mechs & variants, and they all feel different.
- This alone, is quite a feat to accomplish. The core of the game is 'nigh rock-solid. Extra content is on its way for 2016 to bring first vehicles for the game as well.
***

Everything in the game can be bought with in-game money, including basic colors.
- Events are held where you can get free Mech Bays.
- Anything that you can buy with money, won't give you an advantage.
- Grinding is a lot smaller in part in comparison to most f2p games, though getting C-Bills(in game currency) fast is mostly up to your pilot talent.
- What is in major part is the simulation, and finding the right role for your talents.

Best community in TS Servers I've thus far met. Also, the most mature & the most aged in general.
- This isn't for those energy drink whopping, twitch shooter friends who crave for their next fix.

This is for us, who require a blend of wisdom/tactical thinking, and strategy, while commandeering a role that will either make the team, or break the team.
- Teamplay is the key word, so think wisely... This game is unlike any other simulator out there. Keep a cool hat and see only after 25 matches how things go. 5-10 rounds won't get you nowhere(you just might thank me later).

There's also a lot of great youtube videos out there to help you get acquinted with various roles, weight classes & How To Build Your Mech" kind of schematics.

And one more thing: www.sarna.net ||| Use the Search

reviewText:
Before i begin, I'm somebody who has played this game for over a year and a half now, and one thing has become painfully apparent: THIS IS A HARD GAME. I cannot stress this enough. It needs a level of tactics above most modern FPS.

With that out of the way, this game is bloody great. where to begin, where to begin! first off, there are many great-feeling mechs to pilot from the nimble, 20-ton Locust, to the heavy-hitting 50-ton Hunchback, to the absolute dakka platform that is the 65-ton Jaegermech, to the big, beastly, lumbering 100-ton King Crab, and many, many more.

All the weapons feel spot on. The ballistics all feel big and thumpy, even with the tiniest one, the AC/2. The lasers are very easy to use, if with a bit of a learning curve of damage over time. All the missiles are, well, Missiles! (DISCLAIMER: Long Range Missiles [LRMs], while good for getting damage in your early games, are very much a crutch until you learn to properly pilot with them. please stop boating them.)

This game is not without it's downsides, such as Faction Play (formerly known as Community Warfare, or CW") still in beta long after it was initally planned for release
