reviewText:
MWO is a very teamplay focused 12v12 tactical shooter. Teamwork and good positioning including good use of cover are key to winning. It is free to play and there is no pay to win. Definitely worth to download and give it a try.

There is a nice, short ingame tutorial that teaches you how to move and kill stuff.
Beyond that there is the mechlab, where you can customize your mechs and adjust their loadout to their playstyle. It's easy to spend more hours in the mechlab than in the matches themselves.
In higher tier matches, even the geometry of the mechs and placement of weapons on them become important. The higher the weapon mounts, the less you have to expose yourself from cover to shoot your enemies. In short: There is a lot of depth to the gameplay to explore.

The usual MWO Quick Play match lasts for about 10-15 minutes. Faction Play matches last longer, usually about 20-30 minutes. MWO is perfect for one to three hours of gameplay in the evening and a ton of fun. For longer playing sessions, it feels a bit too repetetive, but that's just my personal experience.

Quick note for newcomers:
If you are new to the game, you should finish the tutorial first and complete the callenges in the Mechwarrior Academy for extra CBills (ingame currency). Try out the different trial mechs available to you in Quick Matches, until you know which kind of mech suits your playstyle best. Once you earned your complete cadet bonus (you get extra CBills in your 25 first Quick Matches), you will have gathered more than enough money to buy your first mech and start to customize it.

That's about it. Good hunting mechwarrior!

reviewText:
Riding on the back of battered and neglected franchise was PGI: Offering promises to a desperate fanbase to take them for every penny they could get. MWO is a good example of a F2P game done wrong, absurdly overpriced founders packs paved the way for consistantly overpriced mechs that in some cases cost as much as a entire AAA game followed by even more expensive and gated mech packs that mean that even when a mech will be available for 'free' (by free I mean spending hours and hours and HOURS grinding for) they wont be available for SEVERAL months while the poor smucks that dished out buckets of cash will be using these fancy new but unavailable to you mechs to curbstomp you. (Unless they got one of the bad eggs, then they have a high priced turd you can demolish for free!)

Now don't get me wrong, at its core the game is pretty fun, just grindy as hell and having buy buy buy constantly being thrown in your face by a dev team that has consistantly abused its playerbase (in some cases belittling them). Most of the original MWO fanbase either hates the amount of money and time they wasted on this game or they fanatically cling to a dying dream coasting on the sometimes thousands of dollars 'invested'.

Do I recommend playing the game? Yes. Do I recommend spending a single penny? Hell, no.

reviewText: While the basic Mech on Mch play is ok, that's all there is to the game. There's pretty much nothing here from the lore other than PGI trying to cash in on nostalgia. reviewText:
So here is the deal with MWO.  Its NOT a tabletop game.  Its more of a shooter at this point with a huge selection of chassis and loadouts.  Depending on the chasis and loadout depends on how you play.  Its a huge cooperative/teamwork game.  If you dont play with your teammates you die.  Your team dies and you all look like noobs.  Its very unforgiving in this regard.

There is really no endgame at this point and as I am sure you have seen in some of the reviews it was promised to be much much more but it is not there yet.  They have been implementing new content at a higher pace recently and the balance and tweaks have been generally good.  The 3 different gameplays of Skirmish, Conquest, and Assault really do not vary much as it usually just turns into an all out brawl at the end.  Community Warfare is fun but intense and absolutly REQUIRES teamwork as you end up going against coordinated opposing teams that absolutly dominate uncoordinated teams.  However, some of the funnest, heart pounding, got the shakes gameplay has come from CW as it is very...well,,intense.

So if you are wanting an RPG style shooter this is not it at the moment.  If you are looking for a good well rounded stompy robot game then this is it.  Literally endless options on how to tweak your mechs and customizations.  Serious fun team play and solo play.  Find yourself a good group of friends to play with or a friendly unit to drop with and you will enjoy this game.

btw I have been playing MWO with theskjaldborg.com (SoR) for 3 years now and we can help point you in the right direction if you want.

reviewText:
Hello everybody. I write this review as a fan of Battletech, MechWarrior in particular, and as an MWO player since late closed beta. According to the stats page of the game, I have spent 205 hours in-matches. Note that this does not include Community Warfare matches which should be roughly another 30 hours and tinkering with mechs inside the mechlab or one of the many player-made mechlabs available on the web. The money invested into this F2P title is around 70 dollars which includes the Hunchback IIC package (40$) and a few other MC (MechWarrior Credits, the IRL money currency in-game) transactions for hero mechs, premium time and colors. I primarily play as a Heavy pilot, with a few choice Assault and Medium mechs. I am also a Tier 2 rating, so I like to think I have an O.K. understanding of the game and it’s Meta. All these things may have colored my perception of the game and the experience it offers.



The Good:

-Unique gameplay that seems to be underrepresented in today’s market

-Vastly improved controls over its predecessors

-Complex and meaningful customisation (MechLab)

-A mostly mature community that is supportive and enjoys explaining their passion about stompy robots

-A great selection of mechs with varied play styles. This game has so many of them, there will be one for you. During the writing of this review 12/9/2015, most mechs are in a good spot with some underpowered exceptions.  The most recent balance patch was on 12/1/2015 so the new meta has yet to solidify.



The Neutral:

-Starting Trial mechs are a mixed bag. Try all of them

-Steep learning curve

-Lacking in-depth tutorial about most important part of the game (MechLab and Mech Customisation)

-Runs on CryEngine and has performance issues on weak CPU’s. Recommend lowering “Particle” setting

-A fair selection of maps, but could use more. Maps also vary in quality

-Owning 4 mechs of each chassis allows you to “Elite” your pilot with the chassis, used to grant you considerable buffs. Those buffs were since nerfed hard, but are still noticeable. Investing in a mech chassis you enjoy is still recommended and somewhat expensive

- Mech Upgrades are expensive, required for competitive play and are NOT factored in the initial mech buy price (hidden costs). Same goes for different engines ratings or engine types. It may look like Light Mechs are the cheapest but a competitive Light Mech can run you the price of a Competitive Assault Mech (hidden costs)

-All new mechs release in a Pre-Order Pack model, where the mech becomes available for those who pre-order, a month later it releases of MC and a month later for in-game CBills

-Community Warfare technically no entry requirement, but having 4 custom mechs is highly recommended

-Performance based economy. As in any game, you probably won’t be amazing at it right away. The game can be somewhat grindy between your first and second mech. However, once you perform well consistently, the money will be flowing in.
-Controversy around developer and their practises

-Community Warfare lacks a matchmaker. It’s considered the “hard core” mode where people play with their units!


The Bad:

-Limited base game modes .Quick Play only has TDM with a base, pure TDM or Conquest. Community Warfare features an asymmetrical Attack/Defend mode with turrets and dropships that let you deploy up to 4 of you mechs (Each mech acts a as a life) as well as a TDM mode where the invader team defends the destroyed base from a counter attack. That’s it until a new “scouting” mode drops sometime next month.

-Signature game mode Community Warfare has low population on off-hours and work days (This may change with steam release)

-Somewhat slow development rate on big features. However, there are 2 patches per month and fast hot fixes (even on weekends).

-Hit or miss balance patches

-Minefield of an in-game store. Somewhat expensive too! Please research a Hero Mech before purchasing, not all of them are good!

Overall, the game is solid enough to warrant a download. Most importantly, even if I find it somewhat stale nowadays, it has a way of being FUN. Try it out, but it’s not for everybody. Look up some of the excellent player guides and resources.
I recommend visiting www.reddit.com/r/outreachHPG it has a great player resource selection. MechWarrior has a passionate community that are willing to help out new players. It might be overwhelming at first, but this game can grow on you easily.

reviewText:
Welcome back to the Mechwarrior Universe, where you can bask in the glory of many different Mechs both Inner Sphere and Clan as they spew death upon one another in the beautifully crafted maps of MWO.

The combat is highly tactical, the skill of a mechwarrior is not in their twich reacations but their choice of target and how they engage it, with the build they have entered the arena with. The game encorages players to work together & improve their teamwork and to be tactical with their shots managing their mechs heat levels not only when deployed in combat but when creating the loadouts for their purchased mechs. That large pulse laster puts out a lot of focused damage at good range, great for removing opponents limbs and components, but it also puts out a lot of heat and it is heavy!

I have been playing MWO for about 2 years and i can honestly say that i have seen a continuous improvement in the game over that period (it has had some downs as well). There are not a lot of games i am still playing after such a long period which i consider testament to its quality.
MWO caters well for casual play if you just want to stomp around in a big robot spraying laser death for an half an hour or so as well as more involved clan matches and alliances in clan warefare.
The regular challenge weekends have been fun and provided insentives to get players using new features when they have been added, as well as giving players hats" to adorn their mech cockpits with.

reviewText:
I've played Mechwarrior Online since closed beta, been a fan of the franchise since first picking up Mechwarrior 2 Mercs many years ago and even played online with Mechwarrior 4 and I still come back to play MWO. It has it's niggles, its bugs like any game. Sure you can get frustrated at times especially in community warfare but roll with the punches becaused you get to dish them back out. Taking out three or four opponents with a light mech dancing between laser fire or watching arms and legs fly off your Centurion as you grind your way through the shattered remains of your enemy never fails to put a smile on my face.

The key thing with Mechwarrior is patience, it's not a simple game to pickup but it's a rewarding game, there's lots of subtle nuances you can pickup that makes a skillful player vastly better than his opponent (of which I have yet to pickup half of them years later).Take your time and learn the game, do not be disheartened and remember that you WILL get better through practice.

I'd reccomend this game for anyone willing to invest a bit of time in picking up a slower paced F2P shooter.

reviewText:
I have played MWO a lot in the last two years. I find the gameplay is good, the maps are fun, and the variety in the mechs adds a lot of flavor, strategy and planning that needs to be done before a match even starts.

Is the game perfect? Definitely not. There is a steep initial learning curve, the matchmaker can sometimes take a while to find a match, and with all the customization it's easy to bring something to the battle that is very sub-optimal. On the flip side, I really enjoy the high skill ceiling, the high level of customization, the intense matches, and that good strategy/tactics pay off in the field.

Would I recommend this to anyone? Absolutely. Is everyone going to find something to like about the game? Absolutely not. If the theme or style appeals to you at all, there is a lot of stompy robot goodness to love in the game. If you like shooters, I'd say give it a try and see if it's your thing. I'd still recommend anyone slightly interested give it a try, as the game is great for a free game. I continue to get a lot of enjoyment and entertainment from it.

If you try it out and don't like it, then I wish you luck on finding your next game.

If you try it out and do like it, you are in for a lot of fun! I'll look forward to dropping with you in the near future. :)

Cheers!

Malum

reviewText:
I have played this game since closed beta, and a Legendary Founder for the game. I have seen this game change very much since those days. Ever since IGP went bankrupt and the license has been under PGI control, they have done a lot to make the game so much more. From Faction Warfare, to a robust tutorial system, to a future PVE campaign.

This game is not Call of Duty, this is not Rambo rampage, this is MechWarrior. The combat is slower paced, and team oriented. Running around solo, trying to be superman will get you killed. Stick with your team, focus fire, provide cover fire and try to move from cover to cover.

Don't be scared by the price of mechs and mech packs, every single mech (except for hero mechs) can be earned for free by simply playing the game and grinding cbills. There is no 'Pay to Win' mech, buying mechs with cash does not give you a mech thats superior to a standard mech bought with cbills. The only difference between a standard mechs, champion and Hero mechs is that champion mechs earn 30% mroe xp (that stacks with premium time), and Hero mechs {designated by parenthesis like (F), (L), (I), (S), etc} earn 30% more cbills (which stacks with premium time). But you can get standard versions of the same mechs without the bonuses.

Not to mention that almost every month PGI has an event where you can usually earn free cbills, MC, mech bays and sometimes even mechs for free. And you can earn free mech bays for doing faction warfare. [Warning if you are a brand new player, I do not recommend doing faction warfare until you have 4 full mechs that are decently skilled)

This game will give back to you what you put back into, whether its just a couple quick drops for after hard day, or you are binge-playing over the weekend to get event rewards, The more you play, the better your understanding of the maps and mechs will do you will. Torso twisting, focus firing, cover from LRM swarms, This game will take time to get good at, and putting skills into mechs will make your mechs play better, which will in turn make you play better.

Dont be afraid to ask for help, the community thats been here for over 3 years has no problem helping out new players, but for more indepth answers to your questions, go to the MWO forums. There is only so much people can answer in the games chat.

reviewText:
Technically, this is free to play. Yeah, well, technically. In reality, if you want  to compete you'll be plunking down cash for one of the two in-game currencies you can only buy with cash. Works like this: To max out your pilot's abilities on a chassis, you need to level-up four different variants of that chassis, so you need to buy four different variants of that chassis. To compete in something other than skirmish play (random pubbies) you need to have leveled up four different chassis. So four variants times four chassies equals sixteen different variants.

Problem: you only start out with space for four chassis. So if you want to avoid paying cash for more you'll be selling chassies for underwear-streaking losses to fit the next one. While you could *technically* do this, it's a giant waste of your resources, which means it's a giant waste of your time.

And the very best variants of every chassis are only available if you pay IRL money. So, yeah, enjoy losing to whales who can drop $600 on in-game purchases.

Free to play my ♥♥♥. It's free to play until you hit the soft paywall and you're left feeling like your time's been wasted.

OK, So why didnt i know about this game sooner? Im loving it as a long time mechwarrior fan. Most of my childhood went to MW2 and MW3, then i found MW4: Mercenaries and my teenage years were spent too. On the plus side after 3 matches in this game the rust has already been knocked off and all that time spent farming Solaris VII matches in multi player and single player paid off.

Honestly i find this game very loyal to the lore and universe, being a veteran from both the pc games and the tabletop. The gameplay is accurate and feels alot like MW4, loads of customization. If your a veteran of the series you'll slot right in and find the learning curve pretty easy, alot of players have sited the game as having a very serious learning curve, im not having that trouble. Fits like a comfy old slipper.

10/10 would club newb mechwarriors again!

reviewText:
I've been playing this game since beta.

At first, I was somewhat hesitant about MWO. You see, I’m not all that into PvP games. And, when I learned that MWO was all PvP, I really wasn’t interested at first. But, the lure of Big Stompy Robots eventually dragged me into trying it.

So, there I was grinding out my twenty five cadet bonus matches in a Trial JM-6 Jagermech. My first mech purchase was a Blackjack as they were first released. I realized that this was a different kind of PvP game- it was slower, the concept of walking tanks did a good job of mitigating the twitch play that I didn’t like. Sure there was still twitch play with light mechs, but it was still a little slower and methodical that other FPS games I played.

Now, a few years (and a bunch of mech packs) later, I find I truly do love this game.

What I like most about this game, compared to other tank games, is the method in which you get your vehicles. See, in other tank games, you have to contend with tech/progression trees- forcing you to drive or fly equipment you don’t like in order to work your way into gear that you do.

Not so with this game. If I want to drive a Timberwolf, I can either grind the CBills to get them, buy the MC to get it or buy it straight away from the gift store. Can’t do that with an M1 Abrams, German Tiger or P-51.

I love how customizable the game is. Much of the fun of the game is spending time in the mechlab finding that perfect build that synergizes my playstyle with the mechs quirks and hardpoint arrangement. See not all build fit all, some build that work great for one guy may not work so well for other. But, finding that great build that works for you is truly satisfying.

Another thing I love about this game is the regular events that PGI holds. Grab bag events, Leaderboard events, Faction play events and Cumulative stretch goal events, there’s always something going on.

There’s a lot of good stuff on the horizon for this game-
The fabled Unseens are being released on a monthly basis as we speak.  If you’re a Battletech aficionado, you can truly appreciate the return of these classics.
PvE is coming; we already see glimpses of PvE in the Mechwarrior Academy.
A large update is coming to Faction Warfare that will appeal to small groups (4v4) as well as large.

If you’re new to the game, do check out the Spike Brave tutorials on youtube. Also, play the Mechwarrior Academy, play it a lot, play it some more. The Mechwarrior Acandemy is a great resource.

Give the game its fair shake, just like I did, and I think you will be impressed with it, just like I am.

reviewText: Definitely a good game to get into if you're into Mech combat. While not exactly a fast pace game, there are moments of all out slug fests when head to head engagement over a point become inevitable. This game comes in second place just under Mech Warrior: Living Legends mod, only because that mod allowed the use of air units and tanks along side mechs. There is the issue of expensive mechs, and I agree the prices for them are pretty steep and the grind for them is tedious. However when it comes to mechs it isn't about having many, but mastering the one you own. A light mech can just as easily out manuever and harrass the heavy tonnage mechs. Though the risk is there for being outright killed if they get a shot on you. They do a good job at immersing you into a battle as well, with game rounds starting with your pilot doing a systems check in a drop pod into a battlefield.

reviewText: I have been playing MWO off and on for about 3 years now. I highly reccommend it if you favor strategy and team play over a lone wolf, arcade style shooter. As far as Battletech fans from the table-top or past MechWarrior games, this is probably not for you, but as it is free-to-play, I would at least give it a try. It is a solid game with TONS of customization and it still feels great getting into those mechs and bringing the pain. It's very possible to have fun playing the game solo but the most fun I've ever had playing this game has been joining up with a full drop team and communicating strategy and tactics during tournaments and scheduled team vs team skirmishes.\n\nOne thing I will say about the game as a negative, it has a rather large learning curve. The new in-game tutorial is great and a significant improvement for welcoming new players, but I would still definitely recommend trying to join a MWO clan or group that is willing to teach you the game or at least give you some tips. At the very least maybe watch a tutorial video guide about weapon systems and loadouts. As an example, overall, the premade load-outs for the mechs you use are decent but definitely not the most optimal. Learning which weapons, engines, armor, etc, work best in your mech of choice and which role you should be playing on the battlefield with that loadout, is imperative to your (and your team's) success and overall enjoyment in the game.

reviewText:
To the new players for this game:
The people who have been giving this game negative reviews are mostly salty players who expected an AAA game almost four years ago when the game was under the name of a completely different company. The game was run under IGP and they were horrible and stunded this game's growth.

Now with that said, the game has been under to control of a new company, PGI for a while now. PGI has made GREAT strides in providing balance, reducing grind, and avoiding a pay-to-win game.

The game is rather simplistic in game-modes but is not tiring as each map can be VERY different from the next with the simplest changes to a tactic. Tactics and team-work are huge in this game and makes everything so much more interesting. It is has a nice balance between teamplay and first person shooter that makes the game so much fun.
Get a few friends to play the game with you, form a group, be aggressive, work together, and use the MIC and you will have a lot of fun. The game has made great strides this year alone and I high recommend it to anyone as it is one of the few games that truly changes and just has something that not even HAWKEN could provide. There's a huge learning curve but getting past it is SOOO satisfying!!!

Anyway, in conclusion:

Big-stompy-robots/10 would play again.

reviewText:
Long time Mechwarrior here. Played since Alpha stage. I am a Legendary Founder.

I have played this game through it's roller coaster ride of development. I was there for LRMggeddon, LASERPocalypse, and many other trying moments for this game. I can say that there have been more than a few moments where I've been frustrated with the direction that PGI chose to go in. I really miss knockdown and really wish that melee combat was a thing. I don't let that stop me though.

If you are looking for something that is super fast paced with lots of jumping around and has big robots, I recommend Armored Core or Hawken for you Japense Mecha fans.

Otherwise, if you want GIANT stompy robots then this is where you come. This is based on Battletech, many people already know and love what FASA did all those years ago in creating that game. PGI has actually done a good job at crafting a great quasi-arena style game. In the beginning this game looked weak and pathetic. Now a days this game has gone from looking like a C grade game to a B+ or possibly even an A grade game. The kicker there is that PGI isn't done yet. They are continuing to improve and extend the life of their game.

Big things have been announced for the future. A new phase in community warfare is going to see that mode expanded by a great deal. Inner sphere mechs are about to receive clan type mechs that utilize Clan tech on Inner Sphere chassis'. A new decal system is in the works to allow for greater mech customization.

Also, this is a prediction, due to the expanded and continually expanding nature of the training grounds missions. It is my belief that in the future, sometime in 2016 I bet you, we will see some form of single-player instant action or story type gameplay. THIS IS A PREDICTION, I HOLD NO FOREKNOWLEDGE IN REGARD TO PGI's PROJECT SCHEDULE. Just making a wild ♥♥♥ guess.

Keep it tuned and keep stomping!

reviewText:
This game isn't quite BattleTech and does have some balance issues. The Pay-2-Win crowd is also pretty fiece and playing a Quick Play match will drop you in a team that's a lot like the Keystone Cops. I have no interest in faction play (it gets way to Tribal in there) and without some sort of story line or AI combat; I can't justify the time I put into this title.
The game heavily favors Clan Mech over Inner Sphere Mechs (The in game meta factions) as far as build options and for a perpetual tinkerer like me, it gets frustrating to try and balance a build.
There's also a strong vein of elitism and anti-Steam user chatter that will put a lot of us on the outs. There is also no active monitoring of user age. Getting slagged by a kid is one thing, but having to listen to some 11 year old scream into the VOIP and Caps-rage about how no one will do what they're told needs to stop.
There are also legal issues at play that will continue to slow or even alter game content. I don't know enough about FASA, the old pen and paper BattleTech IP or the various people involved to make a flow chart, but there is another MechWarrior game in developement and a lot of the old 'Jocks in the Forums are still bemoaning the lack of certain Iconic Mechs in MWO.
Give this one another 2 years and another major update. If it's still up and running, go for it. For now, I'd recommend holding off.

Perhaps one of the best ways you can go feed your nostalgia in the way of some old school shooting. As your pure mechanized machine goes to pound off the armor of another, whether it's by guns, lasers, or missiles. Unfortunately, despite it's release, it still can feel rather beta.

If you carry knowledge of the game, they are trying to stay very close to the story of what Mechwarrior is. Here are some of the things are making this go so wrong.
- The Inner sphere take on equal amounts of clanners, where as the clanners. still have their unmatched firepower.
- They are desperately keeping clan weaponry to the clan. The Inner Sphere will most likely never see their integration into their systems.
- There is an uneeded, visible, TIER system in the game to make you struggle and hate your skills to get to the top.
- The maps that they carry are only about small/medium at most in comparison to what size older maps could have been, though this is reasonably required for a 15 minute match.
- (Personal) Weapon customization is limited on mechs (But there are many Types" to choose from)

reviewText:
I have been playing this game on and off since the closed beta, it is true that its not the greatest game in the world and that there is a heafty price on some mechs if you dont want to grind and want everything now. The actual gameplay of the battles and customization of the mechs in the mechbay is where this game is great.

The battles are fought as 3 4 mech lances (squads) so to get the best out of the game you need to work together and support your team (it only takes 1 mech to run off by themselves to turn a garanteed victory into a defeat) each mech class has its own advantages and uses that you will find out from playing.

The grind in the game isn't to reach the biggest mechs as you can pretty much get these from the get go and each class plays verry differently suiting different people, if you like to run and gun darting from cover to cover in hit and run tactics then a light mech is your thing, if you like heavy firepower and the armour to stand your ground (because you are not moving very fast) then assault mechs might be your thing but remember even in the biggest baddest looking mech you can still be turned into a smoking wreck in a matter of seconds by light mechs without the support of your team.

So I will leave with this, the game is f2p you have nothing to lose so give it ago, compleet the tutorial, use the trial mechs to get a feel for the different classes and find the class that suits you then once you have finished 25 matches and earned all the cadet bonus you should have a fair amount of credits to get a mech of your choice all without spending any real money.

So have fun and I may see you on the field of battle mechwarrior.

reviewText:
Long time Mechwarrior here. Played since Alpha stage. I am a Legendary Founder.

I have played this game through it's roller coaster ride of development. I was there for LRMggeddon, LASERPocalypse, and many other trying moments for this game. I can say that there have been more than a few moments where I've been frustrated with the direction that PGI chose to go in. I really miss knockdown and really wish that melee combat was a thing. I don't let that stop me though.

If you are looking for something that is super fast paced with lots of jumping around and has big robots, I recommend Armored Core or Hawken for you Japense Mecha fans.

Otherwise, if you want GIANT stompy robots then this is where you come. This is based on Battletech, many people already know and love what FASA did all those years ago in creating that game. PGI has actually done a good job at crafting a great quasi-arena style game. In the beginning this game looked weak and pathetic. Now a days this game has gone from looking like a C grade game to a B+ or possibly even an A grade game. The kicker there is that PGI isn't done yet. They are continuing to improve and extend the life of their game.

Big things have been announced for the future. A new phase in community warfare is going to see that mode expanded by a great deal. Inner sphere mechs are about to receive clan type mechs that utilize Clan tech on Inner Sphere chassis'. A new decal system is in the works to allow for greater mech customization.

Also, this is a prediction, due to the expanded and continually expanding nature of the training grounds missions. It is my belief that in the future, sometime in 2016 I bet you, we will see some form of single-player instant action or story type gameplay. THIS IS A PREDICTION, I HOLD NO FOREKNOWLEDGE IN REGARD TO PGI's PROJECT SCHEDULE. Just making a wild ♥♥♥ guess.

Keep it tuned and keep stomping!

reviewText: You'll see alot of people whining about this game saying it's not like mechwarrior, or it's a cash grab. It is indeed Mechwarrior and it's alot of fun. The game can be a bit grindy especially if you don't put a small amount of money into it,Premium time is where it's at to get credits. The hero/champion mechs aren't broken or OP you just get more money/xp and hard points ooo wippity doooo. The game itself is great there are alot of mechs to use, not to mention a decent chunk on trial. You should only buy a mech when you think you like it and want to customize the loudout and camos and paint. The faction play is also pretty awesome it's a unique way to get into a team based shooter. I'd say the main probelms with this game are the intense amount of time it takes to grind if you're a free player, Sometimes you will get mercilessly stomped by a clan in faction play while you're with a bunch of randoms, and the lack of costumization options without using real money as well. But paying to look pretty isn't pay to win, or a reason to stay away from this game. Like come on people do you expect every f2p game to just give you a full game experience? The people who make games need to make money too. I'm tired of people whining and complaining because you can buy this or that in f2p games . This game has a great community and decent VOIP built into it as well. 90% of the people who use it are very nice and helpful, you'll run into a toxic player here and there but that's the internet fo you. Out of all of the f2p games on steam I'd reccomend this one to anyone who likes giant robots or games where teamwork and coordination are required. 9/10 Big Robot Peneee

reviewText:
First review. I don't tend towards the hyperbolic, so I think all this is fair.

Great
-F2P done right. Fans of Planetside 2 will enjoy this model. You could grind for ages and still have the best equipment eventually. I ended up paying about $180 and it was all well spent. No regrets. Recommend budgeting at least $80.

-Matchmaking. Going up in tiers really helps weed out poor players and griefers. Lunatics will always be present, but you can mute or block them.

-Clans. You don't really have to join one. You can find a group of folks and they will always be happy to associate with you. They may be a clan or just other individuals (your friends list).

-Mech combat. Well balanced (aside from typical forum bemoaning) that is ultimately gratifying. Go fast, go slow; go long range, go 120m brawler. Whatever you want.

-Mechs. Customizable, skinable, and relatively true to lore. You can roleplay yourself as a hardcore pilot or just play casually. Fun fun.

Good
-Developers keep on developing. They are slow, promises tend to be 2-8 months after delivery date. It'll arrive eventually though.

-Content continues to be released, along with rough timelines published each month. New pre-orders are always in the hopper. Enjoyable to watch the options grow.

-Faction content/loyalty. I enjoy repping my faction but the differentiations are pretty slight in general play.

Poor
-The engine has some pretty crappy object hit detection. Not ballistic - think mechs running into each other (weird clipping) and terrain issues. It can't really be fixed without upgrading the software engine...which is probably never.

-UI. A bit arduous to do relatively simple inventory management and accounting.

reviewText: Dabbled in this momentarily in the closed beta, and didn't touch it for 3 years until the middle of 2015. MAN has this game come a long way since then! It's a beautiful game with giant stompy robots, and combat is exciting and never the same in any two games. Sure, it's effectively 12v12 deathmatch for 80% of the quick play games. Noone complains about having only one map on DOTA. each different mech feels different, handles different, and the breadth of customization, while not fully open to anything under the sun, makes spending time in the mechlab sometimes more enjoyable than playing the game itself. You can effectively have fun without paying a single cent (and not be disadvantaged compared to those who pay). However, for those with the money and no time to work the grind, their system allows for a good time-vs-money tradeoff. I've paid for stuff in the game, and have not had any regrets (at all!). Highly recommend it, keep the improvements coming, great job to PGI!

reviewText:
NOTE: I have NOT played MWO before it entered Steam and hence will not take into the account of what the company has done BEFORE it's release onto Steam. This will be a first-impression of the game without any prior knowledge of the company, community and their actions.

So is MechWarrior Online worth playing?
Hell yes.

Is it worth paying the premium for?
♥♥♥ No.

Let's start with the overall basics of the game, it's the closest you can get for a latest-generation MechWarrior game. Being a Mechwarrior fan since the 1995 MechWarrior 2, I felt an extreme sense of nostalgia while playing the game. Launch PPCs using a TimberWolf from far has never felt better. However, the P2Win element, as per all F2P games, is obviously there. And the game IS shoving that right into your face. Despite that flaw, I'd say that MechWarrior Online is worth playing, but not worth paying for.

Here's why.

Gameplay Wise, the game is as solid as a MechWarrior game can get. You pick a mech, you drop into the landing zone, and you blow everything up. It isn't as fast paced as the spin-offs such as MechAssault, and stays true to the classic, oversized, clunky mechs that stomp around blasting each other with lasers. Newbies to the series will HAVE to play through the tutorial before going into matchmaking or risk getting stomped. Older Veterans from past MechWarriors should have little to no trouble getting familar with the game's controls asa in my opinion, the game plays very similar to MechWarrior 4 Vengence.

You pick a mech, you click on matchmake, and you're off to blow stuff up. There's several game modes, but most of them just consists of blowing up the enemy team, because it's THAT fun to blow up mechs. There's also a more serious matchmaking called Faction Play, where you team up with people on your selected Faction, and work together to win--imagine ranked play or ELO, or comp, you get the point.

The sound?
I'm using a subwoofer below my desktop, when my mech fires it's weapons, it's amazing. The lasers, rockets and autocannons are amazing for a F2P game. Or it could just be my childhood nostalgia kicking in.

The P2Win Element?
Yes, it's there, RIGHT SMACK IN YOUR FACE. As a newbie, your first mech is free, after about 25 games. However, you only have enough money to buy 1 Mech and equip it with decent weapons. Make a mistake in your mech purchase and you're outta luck. A typical matchmaking game would land you about 100-300k credits (or so). A new, stock mech, should you choose to buy a second (which you will), can easily go for 15M credits. Do the maths. Yes, it is a huge grind to get to your second stock mech, and the cost of equipping it with decent weapons? Ugh.

Matchs end with credits and how well you've scored, also, a screen which says how much YOU COULD HAVE EARNT if you've played on premium time. Yes, you can buy bonus credits using real money.

Stock Mechs for real cash? Yeah sure, just hand over $30, and they'll give you a stock mech, which you could have bought for 15M worth of grinding. The amount you hand them is NOT, in my opinion, worth the amount you receive. For instance, other F2P games such as Dota, LoL or heck, even MapleStory gets you decent items with say, $6?. That amount here gets you nothing close. Skins for a single type of Mech would hit insane prices of $10 and above. So imagine you have 3 mechs, you'll have to spend $30 just for skins themselves!

No, they're not marketable like CS:GO skins. Don't bother talking about reselling.

Also, Faction Play normally consists of players with insane mech build ups, most of which can outgun, and outclass you. So I'd personally advise for one to play normal matchmaking, get a nice mech collection THEN jump into Faction Play.

The Community?
2 game modes - Normal play and Faction Play. Normal play matches you with just about anyone, no coordination most of the time--it's essentially a 12 v 12 deathmatch. Faction Play, people get more serious, they use mics, they use fully equipped mechs, all the good stuff--Essentially, most of the guys here have played for a long time. They can be extremely elitist, or, welcoming to new players. For my time spent in Faction Play, the people that I've been matched with were really friend, save for a few exceptions.

Overall
This game plays ALOT of nostalgia for old MechWarrior fans, it might be fun for a while, but you'll begin to notice the grind element creeping in. Personally, as a fan of the series, I don't mind sitting at my desk, spending an hour or two a day on normal matchmaking and doing other stuff later.

TL:DR?
It's worth playing for FREE.
The premium content is ridiculous in pricing. Absolutely ridiculous.

reviewText:
It's not a MMO, it's not a FPS.
It's neither a turn-based nor a real-time tactics or strategy game, even though it's based on a tactical board game from the 1980s.

It's flawed, eternally stuck somewhere in the middle of a glacial development cycle.
You will lose badly, unless you gather some friends and work on you small unit tactics.

But as long as shooting lasers at each other from a building-sized bipedal tank will be fun, I'll be playing MechWarrior Online.

reviewText:
Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys first person shooters. A slower paced game, great if you want to get away from the twitchy, super competitive madness that is Halo/CoD.
Customization in the mechlab is phenomenal. Spending time in the mechlab building and tweaking mechs and testing their effectiveness is half the fun. Anything from armor values on all 8 of your different components (11 of you count the rear armor), weapons, ammo, engine size and type, and equipment, can be relocated and swapped to suit your needs.
Anyone who has played any other Mechwarrior title should feel right at home. If you haven't played/heard of Battletech before, I recommend reading up on some guides and strategies before you hop in. The learning curve is steep. You WILL lose a lot at first.
Combat is slow and methodical. Engagements will often last several minutes. The feeling of brawling with an enemy mech and having parts blasted off, will keep you on the edge of your seat; especially if it comes down to a 1v1 situation. Being '1 shotted' is very rare and is often the result of bad positioning and multiple enemy mechs focusing you down.

PROS:
-Solid game play mechanics
-The artwork and attention to detail behind the mechs and maps is visually stunning
-Mechlab/building mechs is quite fun
- Not P2W. More 'Pay to skip the grind'
-Huge selection of mechs to buy
- Encourages teamwork. Teamwork is often the deciding factor between winning and losing.
-events usually every second weekend that hand out all kinds of free goodies
-It has adhered well to the original Tabletop stats and rules, which makes balancing hard. But the game is in the best state of balance it has ever been

CONS
-The meta game Is very strict
-Development is rather slow
-Balancing tweaks are few and far between. The same meta can reign supreme for months
-The grind can feel overwhelming is you play only for Free.
-Lack of tutorials/briefing for mechlab and Faction Play
-Game mode variety is limited. Basically Team Death Match over and over again
-No real feeling of 'end game' you need 3 variants of a mech to level it up past Basic skills, then Elite, then Master. Master unlocks a module slot, but modules are basically C-bill sinks to improve your mech. A new skill tree is in the works.

All said and done, it's Free to Play, and if you enjoy the game it doesn't feel like a grind. Development has grown in leaps and bounds since the publisher broke off from the developers.
Good luck and maybe you'll see me out there
o7

reviewText:
Have you played War Thunder, World of Tanks/Warships, Robocraft, Hawken?If the answer is yes to those F2P titles, Mechwarrior is another entry to the genre of tatical, partial-simulator FPS. Slower than your average FPS, grindy as any other, with a skill curve sure to be steep.

Have you played Arma or Operation Flashpoint?It is much simplier sim/combat than Arma or OF, harder than your average FPS. It is more Battlefield than COD, with the team depedancy of TF2. And even a good team can end a game in a crushing defeat.

ContentIt is slow to release actual features but mechs are frequent, and I would consider maps release acceptable. Early access to mechs cost money like the recent trend of games. Weapons are tweaked like all good F2P games despite the whinge.

MonniesThe most efficient use of money is mechbays. Or if you want to spend less time grinding then premium time and mechbays. No purchase will guarrentee you victory (although may increase your odds). Time spent learning the pace of the game, learning your mech, observing when your team mates are aggressive or hesitant; these are a few points of focus in the first 10 hours of gameplay (I'm a slow learner).

It was my lifestyle game, I'd play it every day for 2 years. According to my madstats I have clocked 528 hours of in-match game time (tinkering not included). If you think it mech combat might tickle your fancy and don't mind F2P, you have nothing to lose. If you only have time for AAA games, you probably want to give it a miss.

Currently on a break (picked up elite dangerous) and I'm waiting on something different changes before I return.

Time spent learning the pace of the game, learning your mech, observing when your team mates are aggressive or hesitant; these are a few points of focus in the first 10 hours of gameplay (I'm a slow learner).

It was my lifestyle game, I'd play it every day for 2 years. According to my madstats I have clocked 528 hours of in-match game time (tinkering not included). If you think it mech combat might tickle your fancy and don't mind F2P, you have nothing to lose. If you only have time for AAA games, you probably want to give it a miss.

Currently on a break (picked up elite dangerous) and I'm waiting on something different changes before I return.

reviewText:
Mechwarrior has been a fantastic series of games, but in the past, the multiplayer options never even began to capture the feel of the old pen and paper.  It was always a race to the top.  Run the biggest mech or die!

MWO has fixed that.  This is a tactics game.  This is a game where how you play your role is REWARDING.  This is a game where two large teams enter, but every player counts.

And this game rewards you for finding your favorite balance of speed, armor, firepower, and battle field enduance (heat and quantity of ammo).

This is a game about trading blows, taking risks, and defining the envelope.

And the best thing about this game, is it truly is free to play.  The light mechs are cheap, but POWERFUL in skilled hands.  The medium mechs are affordable and are the standard battlefield units.  The expensive assault, though expansive, may have a role to play, and are worth every penny, but they do NOT own the battlefield.

And every patch rewards people who play their role more and more.

I am a freelance mercenary.  I am not a part of a unit, I do not use team speak, I am a pug player, and I still thrive in Community Warefare.

I cannot say how amazing this game is.  It is amazing, it has been amazing, and every month, more and more value is added to the game.

DOWNLOAD IT!!!! You cannot lose if you get it for free, so what are you wating for?!

reviewText:
I've always wanted to write a proper review for this game but I still can't be arsed to write a lengthy, detailed writeup over a video game; everything I'd want to say has already been said again and again anyways. So I'll just get down to the important stuff.

This game has its pros and cons but the important thing to remember is that it -IS- free and if you play semi-regularly the grind doesn't really feel too hard. Everything performance-wise you can get with real money you can get with in-game money except for Hero mechs, which aren't even remotely P2W but do have unique playstyles and loadouts compared to their standard variants. Also, some of them look sexy as hell. (Most of the pay model in this game is cosmetic btw)

There are a LOT of mechs you can pick from and decent variety between the individual models. You can customize the loadout and there's a fair bit of playstyle flexibility for MOST of the mechs. However, this game suffers from a terrible state of forced" meta due to the way rebalancing is handled (or not handled)
date: making things considered non-meta really hard to be competitive in. Still
recommended: if -you- like it and you can put in the performance
hoursPlayed: go for it and do you. All my clan mechs are ballistic-based and I love the unexpected facetime and carries I get against people expecting pulse vomit or streams or other meta Clan stuff.\n\nThis game hates AMD FX processors!!! Full stop. It's a known and somewhat long-term issue and
voteText: while not incapacitating

commentsCount: as do the particles and shaders. The LODs are terribad but I guess that's the price you pay for super-sexy giant stompy robots with full first-person cockpit views.\n\nAnother big con for this game is that the developer doesn't always make the best or brightest decisions in regards to balance passes and content updates. But!!! Things have been way better in that department in the past few months/past year

so that's refreshing.

reviewText:
Product received for free

It looks decent, and it plays well. At least through the tutorial, but once I got through that, I found there was no content to speak of.  Just some 'practice missions' and matchmaking. I was expecting a MechWarrior RPG game, with characters and a story, but it turns out that it is essentially a MOBA, and I detest those. I like storylines with a world to explore, and characters to love or hate. Something to fight for. Not random skirmishes with strangers.
It does seem stay true to the BattleTech lore, and how can piloting a giant death robot not be fun?

I won't say it's bad just because it's not my thing, because I wouldn't know a good MOBA from a bad one, as I've only played enough of them to know I dislike that style of game.

If you like those sort of games, then give it a try.
If you like missions, with storylines and places to explore, then avoid it.

Still it's free, and if you are a fan of the BattleTech universe, it's worth at least checking out.  You may find you like it. I wish there were more options than yes or no. Because I would recommend it to those who like these style games, but I wouldn't recommend it to someone who likes RPGs.

reviewText:
To truly enjoy MWO:

1) Get a microphone
2) Get used to team work
3) Remember that FF is on and to not overheat because you will damage yourself and you will kill yourself.
-

Short Review: It's a good game that is very addictive, very fun and very team oriented. If you're a lone-wolf type prepare to be disappointed because this game isn't for you.  MWO uses a number of effects that you rarely see in FPS shooters and requires more thought to kill one mech than I have ever seen in any game before.

Things that I liked about the game:
+ HEAT: Mechs don't just fire lazers endlessly, you have a certain amount of HEAT before you pass the thresh-hold and just shut down. This makes firing something as unlimited as lazers tricky. HEAT is effective by the ambient temperature as well as other enviornmental quirks. What I liked about HEAT is that it balances the fire-power within mechs.

+A lot of variants: MWO has tons of variants and classes of mechs to choose from. Don't like being a big clunky and slow target? Pick a light class mech. Don't like using only lazers? Well there's different variants for different chasis. Because the variants are so easy to get and the upgrades for them are cheap this makes experimenting with the bots less costly and more fun.

+FACTIONS: This conquer and defend style of factions kept me in a very happy mood. Loads of banners to cast your loyalty to and loads of perks and rewards for siding with those factions. FACTION PLAY is the big leagues for MWO. With thousands of planets and maps to explore you will be occupied with more than just the DM style of quickplay. Not only does FACTION demand a sense of loyalty but a sense of tactical approach I have never seen in an FPS. You will find that players are actively trying to call out and use plans to thwart their enemy combatants. From defending a planet you own to attacking another to increase your factions control of the galaxy this is something that I really enjoyed!
-

What I didn't like:

-Mech Bays: Mech bays limit the amount of mechs that you can buy and add to your MECHLAB. This doesn't seem like much of a big deal but the SKILLS for certain variants of mechs require you to buy and maximum level 3 variants. You only get 4 empty mech bays at the start and you can only aquire more by either paying real money or by earning them through faction promotions. This makes it difficult to get EXPERT into mechs and limits your choice of weight class if you're interested in experting in a certain chasis.

----

That's all I feel about MWO. The content is grand and the players are fun.

reviewText:
Having Played the original Mechwarrior series years ago, i was absolutely thrilled to see this title on Steam.
Despite being a very different game i still love MwO. This game has a solid learning curve and being F2P amassing wealth and exp to buy mechs and upgrades takes a good while if you choose not to Pay real money. However... that time is definately worth it. I have not been playing this for long and allready i like the community. I will most likely sub the game pretty soon if i continue to have as much fun playing it as i have now. This game needs support and i will do my part for sure.

A little list of positive and negative things about the game...

Positive:
- Good and friendly community
- Great potential for epic team battle provided you have a good strategic leader.
- F2P. It is actually possible to build very deadly mechs without using real money
- Some awesome maps with very good looking graphics despite still providing good strategic points.
- High learning curve... Means you won't get bored soon if you have an ambition to matter in the game.
- You Pilot Mech's ... Who wouldnt want to pilot a 100 ton Mech? Think Pacific Rim... Seriously... Mechwarfare!!!

Negative:
- F2P has its drawbacks... Hopefully Piranha Games wont pull the plug anytime soon and make enough cash to see the game as a financial success.
- Steap learning curve means that you propably need to love the genre to stay in this universe for long.
- Some maps are awesome while others are downright awfull.
- F2P Speed at wich you can gather wealth is pretty slow so you really need patience here...
- as far as i have seen no support for multi monitor... wich is sad if you have the system to carry it.

i would give the game 8/10 points tilting towards 9/10 but there is still room for improovement. If you are into the Mech Genre... This game is a MUST HAVE!!! If you are not... you will still have lots of fun.

reviewText:
Warning! This game can be extremely addictive!

I am a Tier 1 MWO veteran who has been playing this game for 2 years almost exclusively. You won't understand why until you are the last pilot alive, forced to confront five enemy Mechs with a cored centre torso, having only half your weapons at your disposal. The adrenaline rush in this game is real.

When you achieve victory on those situations, your satisfaction is immense: both intelectual and physical. You can't win at this game with just twich reflexes. You need tactical and situational awareness, teamwork (not even the best MWO players can win their matches on their own) and some serious multi-tasking skills. You need to know your Mech inside out: temperature thresholds, weapon ranges, cooldowns and projectile speeds, just to name a few, all while you aim at open components and hide yours from enemy fire.

The learning curve is steep and extremely rewarding: you learn from every defeat and victory. You hate some Mechs or weapons until you learn something new that makes you love them. You learn how to handle your legs independently from your torso, and then it's time to spread damage by torso twisting...

I have been playing this game for 2 years and every day I learn something new. And that's why I keep coming back.

The experience is so rich and engaging, you just can't get enough of it. I know I can't.

reviewText:
Having Played the original Mechwarrior series years ago, i was absolutely thrilled to see this title on Steam.
Despite being a very different game i still love MwO. This game has a solid learning curve and being F2P amassing wealth and exp to buy mechs and upgrades takes a good while if you choose not to Pay real money. However... that time is definately worth it. I have not been playing this for long and allready i like the community. I will most likely sub the game pretty soon if i continue to have as much fun playing it as i have now. This game needs support and i will do my part for sure.

A little list of positive and negative things about the game...

Positive:
- Good and friendly community
- Great potential for epic team battle provided you have a good strategic leader.
- F2P. It is actually possible to build very deadly mechs without using real money
- Some awesome maps with very good looking graphics despite still providing good strategic points.
- High learning curve... Means you won't get bored soon if you have an ambition to matter in the game.
- You Pilot Mech's ... Who wouldnt want to pilot a 100 ton Mech? Think Pacific Rim... Seriously... Mechwarfare!!!

Negative:
- F2P has its drawbacks... Hopefully Piranha Games wont pull the plug anytime soon and make enough cash to see the game as a financial success.
- Steap learning curve means that you propably need to love the genre to stay in this universe for long.
- Some maps are awesome while others are downright awfull.
- F2P Speed at wich you can gather wealth is pretty slow so you really need patience here...
- as far as i have seen no support for multi monitor... wich is sad if you have the system to carry it.

i would give the game 8/10 points tilting towards 9/10 but there is still room for improovement. If you are into the Mech Genre... This game is a MUST HAVE!!! If you are not... you will still have lots of fun.

reviewText:
one of the best F2P action titles ive ever played. as a long standing fan of the series, i can say this holds up to what they've always aimed for; a realistic take on giant mechanized war machines. the game looks beautiful, the mechs feel as they should, and if you know of any previous titles, you'll instantly recognize some of your favorites from the past, and even some new models that all offer many variants and customization options that will leave you with literally 1000's of hours of play time! this game allows you to play like a lone wolf, but your influence on the battle field with be negligable to non-existant, so if you wanna have a strong effect on the game, make sure you work together, and think before you step around the next corner, or you could be a pile of twisted metal before you can say 'Sweet tooth' (see what i did there?).

i will say this, if you end up falling in love with the game, your going to want to spend about 5-10 dollars once your 'new player bonuses' wear off so you can expand your mech bay, allowing you to own more mechs, otherwise your limited to 6. but they also always have a rotating roster of free to play mechs as well, that are all usable even if youre short on bays. (this paragraph is null and void as literally right after i wrote this, i found you can earn mechbays through faction warfare)

all in all, an amazing game that i'd happily spend 10 dollars on for the time ive put into this game. (i played before it was on steam)  i would recommend this to any giant robot fans, fans of the series, or people who enjoy driving tanks (as the controlls closely resemble tank controls from other games).

reviewText:
Well, I played this game since july 2012 (early closed beta), when there were only 6 people for a 8v8 match and only testers were in the game. Since then MWO went a long path and had its UPs and DOWNs. This game is not perfect, and some times it is quite a mess, to be honest. I wont go into too much detail and bore you with indepth describtions.(There are TONS of guides, for Christ Sake)
Ok, Here's the deal:
-12v12 - DeathMatch, CapturePoints, KingOfTheHill, BaseVSBase and Marco-Polo (FactionWarfare).
-The game itself is a shooter, but very unusual one. The pacing is slower than in most shooters. It requires methodical and thoughtful approach. There are a lot of things to be taken into consideration both during the match and when building a mech.
-There is a great variety of Mechs (Big walking robots) to choose from. Some are Good. Some are Decent. Some are Situational. Some are terribad and only MIRACLE can save them; buying those might seem compelling, but it is not recommended.
-Mechs themselves are exreamly customizable. Most of the customization options directly affect gameplay.
-Success highly depends on team work and situational awareness.
-Since Battletech is relatively old universe the player base mostly consists of adults with semi-serious approach to the game. Most of the time you can find friendly unit/group without problems. But there are always butthurt exceptions.
-Learning to play MWO is hard. Though it became A LOT MORE newb friendly, since now it has Tier System, PROPER training mode and bonuses for new players.
-Free To Play model is tolerable. There are mechs that can be purchased only for real money, but they are not OP. And you still have to grind to build your own config.
-Still some of the 'Good' Mechs are easier to be bought for real money rather than grinded. Shoving 30-60$ down game's throat will save you WEEKS' worth of grind.
-Balancing needs some serious tweaks.
-Some of the game features are introduced too hastily.
-Some maps need rebalancing. Older maps are being remade to proper fit player count and team balance.
-Developer team is constantly introducing new stuff and fix/tweak found bugs. They work at their own pace but they seem to know what they are doing.
-There are REGULAR events and sales.


This game is GOOD but its NOT FOR EVERYONE. Its slow, hard and demanding. Try it out if you have what it takes.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Product received for free

Plain and simple, if you are looking for a run in and kill game, this is NOT for you.

MechWarrior Online takes time and patience to learn all the aspects of the game.

Highly custimizable Mechs, but a LOT of grinding to afford Skill Upgrades, Weapons, Modules, and other items needed to build to suit your playstyle.

PUG (Pick Up Games, or running without friends) are usually chaotic, for people tend to run about without a plan. Playing with Friends does make things easier and more enjoyable (for most).

MechWarrior Online is the only game that interests me enough to keep playing. Most of the players are like me, a bit older and like games with planning and strategy.

Plan, Communicate, and work together then things work in your favor, even when PUGging

Good Hunting

reviewText:
DEFINITELY WORTH A DOWNLOAD

I just started playing the game December 2015 and within a week I've put almost 80hrs in. This game is addictive and tons of fun if you play with a group. Its good alone, but I imagine it could get really frustrating once you understand whats going on.

If you decide to go ahead and get into this, know that the first 20 mil or so C-Bills you make is much easier than the rest due to bonuses from leveling, and many of the factions have dedicated faction teamspeaks if you want to get into faction play.

Also know that focused fire on particular components is always more lethal than things like rockets. So skilled shooting and knowing when to turn to take hits will make all the difference when brawling.

9.9/10 Best multiplayer game I've played this year. I only regret the population isnt higher in faction play for faster matchmaking (get in faction teamspeaks to accelerate the matchmaking).

reviewText:
If you're a fan of battletech this game is a must have. It's the long awaited continuation  of the Mechwarrior series with an amazing roster of mechs and a complete customization system. There is also unit play to conquer areas of the inner sphere. The community warfare system is still fairly young with a lot of growth ahead of it, despite it alone offers a lot of content.

The packages like most free to play games are a bit pricey however nearly every mech in the game is avaible for in game currency (c-bills) with the exception of hero mechs (special variants with +30% c-bill earning) and staggered releases on new mechs (Pre-order Release, Premium Currency Release, In-game Currency Release).

Highly recommended even if not a fan of battletech or simulators, it comes off as a great tactical shooter.

reviewText: I've been a Mechwarrior fan since the original PC game in 1989.  The bulk of my Mechwarrior experience has been with MW2: Mercs where I ran a unit called ComStar Mercenaries.  Ahhh those were the days....no easy multiplayer interfaces....limited options....however Mechwarrior has always been on top.  After Microsoft's mutilation in MW4 I had started to lose hope in the series.  Then, out of the blue MechWarrior Online appears and war had returned to the universe!  The graphics are very good, gameplay is a little imbalanced in favor of the Inner Sphere(IS).  Community Warfare is an awesome part of this game allowing players to play out the changes in the game universe.  It will be nice if they add an interface similar to MW2: Mercs where you can sign up for smaller contracts and gain loyalty with other factions or lose loyalty if working against a faction.  Choosing a path for loyalty is also a good way to make some friends and work together toward a common goal.  I've chosen my path with Clan Wolf, which path will you take?

reviewText:
I beta tested this game.

Pros:
The staff are friendly, care about the community and want bugs fixed.

The game engine is very fluid.

The mechs are well designed and true to cannon.

Cons:

There are 'variants' of mechs which use 'hard points'. Due to two problems occur.
1) There are less mechs in the game than there could be.
2) There is less theorycrafting to make the best mech because you are locked to specific weapon type slot.

Some people might like that con if they are fans of the Microsoft Mechwarriors. I am an Activision pilot, so it's a drawback for me.

Regardless of this, the game is still amazing and worth the time to play. 8/10.

reviewText:
This is a great addition to the MechWarrior franchise. I've been playing it for years and PGI (the developers) keep making improvements. I wish the real-world prices for some of their mechs was a bit lower, but otherwise they've done a very good job of keeping things balanced and not letting only those with real cash get an advantage.

The key to success is patience. Stay with the group, concentrate on the same target(s) as everyone else and don't wander off alone or stand in the open. Don't play this like you're in a Gundam. I personally find this game a lot more enjoyable when I play with friends.

Oh, and in case you were wondering, this game is PVP only (for now). No solo campaign yet.

reviewText:
I beta tested this game.

Pros:
The staff are friendly, care about the community and want bugs fixed.

The game engine is very fluid.

The mechs are well designed and true to cannon.

Cons:

There are 'variants' of mechs which use 'hard points'. Due to two problems occur.
1) There are less mechs in the game than there could be.
2) There is less theorycrafting to make the best mech because you are locked to specific weapon type slot.

Some people might like that con if they are fans of the Microsoft Mechwarriors. I am an Activision pilot, so it's a drawback for me.

Regardless of this, the game is still amazing and worth the time to play. 8/10.

reviewText: This is a pretty good game. It's lot of fun to play, with pretty smooth matchmaking. The objective modes are kind of garbage though, conquest is especially lame, having a mech ready to fight and losing by points is a bad feeling. Most of the maps are good, Terra Therma isn't imo. The game has a lot of customization and you can mess around with mech builds for hours. I guess this could either be a pro or a con, but not every setup is viable, there are rescources out there to learn good builds, or you could test things out yourself. Just know that cheap mechs are usually cheap for a reason, and at best, you'll have to spend a lot more to make them useful. You shouldn't need to use real money though. I would say the game is not pay to win. The premium mechs aren't really better, just different and with cool paintjobs. Try it out if your into mechs or tank games, since the mechs are pretty much tanks in this.

reviewText: I've been a Mechwarrior fan since the original PC game in 1989.  The bulk of my Mechwarrior experience has been with MW2: Mercs where I ran a unit called ComStar Mercenaries.  Ahhh those were the days....no easy multiplayer interfaces....limited options....however Mechwarrior has always been on top.  After Microsoft's mutilation in MW4 I had started to lose hope in the series.  Then, out of the blue MechWarrior Online appears and war had returned to the universe!  The graphics are very good, gameplay is a little imbalanced in favor of the Inner Sphere(IS).  Community Warfare is an awesome part of this game allowing players to play out the changes in the game universe.  It will be nice if they add an interface similar to MW2: Mercs where you can sign up for smaller contracts and gain loyalty with other factions or lose loyalty if working against a faction.  Choosing a path for loyalty is also a good way to make some friends and work together toward a common goal.  I've chosen my path with Clan Wolf, which path will you take?

reviewText:
If you're a fan of battletech this game is a must have. It's the long awaited continuation  of the Mechwarrior series with an amazing roster of mechs and a complete customization system. There is also unit play to conquer areas of the inner sphere. The community warfare system is still fairly young with a lot of growth ahead of it, despite it alone offers a lot of content.

The packages like most free to play games are a bit pricey however nearly every mech in the game is avaible for in game currency (c-bills) with the exception of hero mechs (special variants with +30% c-bill earning) and staggered releases on new mechs (Pre-order Release, Premium Currency Release, In-game Currency Release).

Highly recommended even if not a fan of battletech or simulators, it comes off as a great tactical shooter.

reviewText:
Back in 2013 this game left much to be desired.

Having returned in 2016 it is quite possibly one of the best free to play experiences out there.

There's an Intro/training area, then your straight into matches with a LFG system, ingame VOIP, and a helpful community.

There's no requirement to spend money (unless you wish to support the game).

My only gripe after sinking the better part of a week into the game, is that once searching for a match you cant fiddle with your other mechs' setups.

8/10 easy, more so if you like mechs. :)

reviewText:
Wow. 9/10, straight up. Amazing game.
MechWarrior Online is a truly stunning shooter game involving giant four-storey-building-sized robots known as BattleMechs. It's graphics are visually gripping, with highly detailed textures and shockingly realistic sun shafts and shading. Yes, when you first load it up your brain will probally be instantly overloaded with information, but you can replay the tutorial as many times as you want, and the entire game seems to be centred around progress ad improvement.
The only negative thing I can find to give the game is that those stunning grahics come at a performance cost: unless you've got a top-end graphics card you're going to need to tone them down a lot. Personally, I've got an AMD Radeon A10, so I'm running on full power with barely any lag at all, but when I first played this game with an old Nvidia something-a-rather I experienced quite a lot more 0-10 frames-per-second than 30-60.
All in all, MechWarrior Onine is one of the best free shooter game there is on Steam, second only to perhaps Team Fortress 2.

reviewText:
This is my first review of a game on Steam so bear with me.

MechWarrior is fun and seems to offer some good tactical choices due to the use of heat and ammo 'n whatnot...however this is all pointless if you can't play the freak'n game. I played a couple games of it and now can't even get into the game. I click on the button for a random game, then it loads up, i get to vote for map and mission type, then it goes black and after 10-20 seconds I get dumped back at the mech lab screen.

*can't even get in game now*

I did a search online (google is always your friend) and found that this problem goes back to atleast Feb 2015. They haven't put out a patch for the problem that has been around for a year and info about is strewn across the net like silly string at a birthday party... Plenty of talk on different forums about it.

So, I guess that while it may be a great game being unable to play is kind of a deal-breaker for me but hey, your mileage may vary so if you're looking for a thinking man's FPS, try it...if you can play, great, if you have the same problem as i and many others have just delete it same like us. Wish it worked 8(

reviewText:
6/10

The main thing this game has going for it is that there are no other mech combat games. If It wasn't for that I couldn't recommend this game. Only having 3 game modes is downright lazy.

Pros:
- Decent Graphics
-You feel like a mech pilot
-matchmaking doesn't take long

Cons:
-If you play solo it is common to get put on teams with no communication or ability. This game is about teamwork far more than solo gameplay. So you get put on these terrible teams that kill themselves like lemmings and there is little you can do to win the game.
This game really sucks to play solo.
-Many invisible barrirers on objects blocking shots
-Have to grind a lot to get money and xp to unlock or buy stuff for your mech
-The only game mode people want tto play is skirmish (TDM) out of the 3 game modes.
-Auto Locking missile spam
-Graphical bugs with textures popping in and out
-No melee combat mechs
-Overpriced Mechs

reviewText:
I was an original Elite Founder of this game when the funding campaign launched in 2012...before Steam Greenlight and many other community funded games.  I eagerly backed at the Elite ($60) level and chomped at the bit for ever to get into the game and then I did.  I was elated with how fun the game was in it's early days and was enthralled with the promise of what was to come, so my friends and I waited eagerly for that content...and waited...and waited...eventually got frustrated and stopped playing feeling like we had wasted $60 on broken promises.

That's what things were.  We backed the game with that understanding but PGI's approach was not that same as what you see on Kickstarter or Greenlight today...they did it all independantly.  So in short, we kept up with what they were doing for a while hoping to come back one days and things just seemed like they were going down hill and the game was going to crash and burn.

When we saw it launch on Steam, my initial thought was Well
date: one last ditch effort to keep the game alive it seems."  Then one day we were talking about it and decided to pop in one last time to see if things had changed...and were very surprised.  So now I have over 70 hours in the game in less than two weeks and am eating crow.\n\nSo
recommended: I may not agree with everything that PGI did when they got started but I think they've been trying to find a way to make it work and had to grow some thick skin in the process to keep things afloat.  I'm not defending them by any means but this was an early learning lesson in crowd funding a game.  Lots of things they promised came very late or are still not in the game today.  That's OK
hoursPlayed: I'd rather them get it right but they had issues communicating this to their backers.\n\nIn short
voteText: mistakes were made and some people are still mad about it.  I'm happy now and hope to see more of the content come to fruition.\n\nWould I recommend this game?  Yes

That doesn't mean you shouldn't play
