reviewText:
What a Gem.
I have to admit i was a bit sceptical running around in robots over using a marine type toon. But the gamplays great. Its got loads of depth too, there must be hundreds of machines and 1000's of load outs/ways to equip your tin can/mech. Mature loyal game following too. This is a FPS that is not too heavy on your PC too but that doesnt take away from great gameplay. Games at first are bit like hide and seek but when you get in front of your target you either got to have back up or hope your mech's set up can dish out more DPS than the other guy because it can be over in seconds.
Also you can get into games very quickly compared to others in this genre.
One of the things that i really liked is that even as a noob you can have value on map. If you pick a trial mech that has one preferably 2 AMS (anti missile system) hard points on it you can offer anti missile defence to your team mates, just by standing near them, as your learning the game by watching others.
Also for a free to play! you can earn alot of in game cash at the beginning  so you can try out different tin cans/ robots and find your own style of play. Dont be like me though, play tutorial and first 25 games before you actually buy anthing in game (its about 500k a game which is enough to get you going), thats what  the forums said and its true.
With about 10 free mechs you should play these because it will take you a while to actually work out what to buy. Its best to find out the best style of game for you be it machine guns or LRMs/missiles/lasers etc or 5 different classes of Mechs.
Its got Faction warfare too, that takes the strategy and depth of the game to new level, I have not really got  into that just yet but the player base is friendly and solid.
This franchise has been around for years but its been a well kept secret!
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Product received for free

I started seriously playing the game just after it's release on the Steam Store. I however, was introduced to the game ages ago when I was a little younger (bout 3/4 years ago) but me being the typical teenager who couldn't grasp the games slow paced concept decided to fall back into the COD spiral before finally stepping into proper PC gaming. As you can tell, if I couldn't play this as my younger self, then you know this is a game for a older audience (not saying kids don't play the game, i just believe it would bore them). It's got a very tactical approach in game rather than Titanfall's rip of giant robot brawling. 12v12 and every mech counts, each class (light, medium, heavy, assault) have their own responsibilities in game and if they don't play the way that logically fits your class then you're a dead man. Heavy's and assaults are the brawlers, let them get up close and personal with the other big mechs. Mediums are the heavy/assaults right hand man when it comes to engaging. Lights are your scouters to feed the team information and pester the bigger mechs to take some of the pressure away from your teams push.

It's a great F2P game if you decide to give it a little time before making a final verdict. MechWarrior isn't a game you can just pick up straight away on. It's a game, that if you play for a while and dedicate a decent amount of hours to you will appreciate it down the line.

I'd love to make some sort of mechwarrior pun, but most of mine are unBEARable. I'm not really allowed to make puns because I'm relatively new. (does 5 hours of playtime 4 years ago count??)

reviewText:
WARNING! THIS IS A GAME FOR PEOPLE WHO ACTUALLY KNOW WHAT STRATEGY AND TACTIC IS.

So, you have a mech, you sit in cockpit, waiting for drop, then you push forward to meet your enemy. Prepare to live exactly 10 seconds if you do that, because it's the best way to get f...ed. This game requires coordination, strategy and tactics. No matter if you drive lightweight fast Locust or 100 tons beast of doom like Atlas. Don't pay attention where your team mates are, and your internal organs will decorate the landscape. This game requires you to think. From the moment you decide what mech to drive, through it's design and specs to the battle itself.

Sure it has it's flaws (it begs for better terrain simulation, because f.ck it annoys me when I shoot on a clear line of fire and then it turns out it's not so clear after all, because some model had invisible boundaries). That begs to be fixed or just done better.

The system itself is nicely balanced, good if you are a beginner or if you already know Battletech. I used to play board game a lot and Mechwarror from the old days when it first came out (yay for 486 DX4 ;)) so I must say I love it. Best online game for me. If you tried other online multiplayer and you lost your temper because each time a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥s kicked your ♥♥♥, this is a game for you ;)

reviewText:
As I have played Mechwarrior 2 back in the mid 90's, my love for this game series was pretty limited to that series of games (MW2, Mercenaries, GBL) on the PS1 and PC.
I never played or tried Mechwarrior 1, 3, 4, Mechcommander, or any of the other spinoff games, and only played the TT game one time.
However I thoroughly enjoyed playing MW2.
With that said, I find this game to be an exceptional successor to the Mechwarrior 2 name.
Combat is well done, and these feel like big walking tanks.
I think each mech is unique and feels different, even though they have similar loadouts.
The only item that I feel is extremely lacking would be mission variety. I know this has been said time after time, so I will not go into the subject again. PGI please add more variety of meaningful game modes and this game will really shine.
Yes there are issues with balance, the 'skill tree', CW/FP needing fleshing out, and roles being useless in the PUG scene (I dont have the time to play in a Unit or regular group).
But I can overlook those issues as I am not a hardcore player (I may get +/- 5 hours of play a week)
PGI please keep up the good work and I look forward to watching this game grow from an arena shooter to something more meaningful than just another arena shooter""

reviewText:
Been Playing this game since Closed Beta, and ive gotta say, the Devs have just been getting better and better.
After some definitly shaky beginnings, they absolutely delivered on an excellent mech shooter.

If you like big stompy robots blasting each other to pieces, then this game is for you!

Very recetnly the grind was largely reduced, and even though there is a micro-transaction model in place, you can honestly never spend a dime on this game, and still have everything the next guy does.
The devs put out enough weekend give-aways, and events to reward players with goodies, free mechs and premium time to mean you've got plenty of in game currency to buy what ever you need, wheter it be Mechs, Colours, items or Mechbays!

reviewText:
Pros:

A free to play first-person shooter. Some 'Mechs are for real cash only, but after sometime (?) these become avialable for in game currency.

This is a slow paced shooter (Think World of Tanks). You're in a big stompy robot, and movement illustrates this in game.

Customization is abound for each 'Mech. Don't like what weapons you start out with?NO PROBLEM! You really get to tweak each 'Mech to your own playstayle. However, my one problem with the customization is the requirement to have 3 Chasis of the same 'Mech to level pilot skills, this can be kind of grindy.

New players will be glad to know that you are injected with what I consider to be a large amount of in game currency for playing 25 matches as a new player. This injection will allow you to get a few 'Mechs and totally fit them out, which is great.

Cons:
The game can feel grindy at times, especially if you gotta catch'em all" or are a completionist.

Some 'Mechs are only availble at their release for real cash (gotta make money somehow
recommended: early adopters can be penalized for purchasing underperforming 'Mechs. Solution for you? Don't buy the new 'Mechs right away.\n\nLimited number of maps. There are less than 10 for quick play at the time of this review. Community Warefare has different maps
hoursPlayed: but that is an entirely different gamemode and for more experienced players.\n\nYou can screw yourself up and buy bad 'Mechs with in game currency and then be stuck with these 'Mechs until you earn more in game money
voteText: do research before you buy 'Mechs is my suggestion."

The learning curve can be a little steep as it's a very team oriented game and going lone wolf usually won't turn out well against vetern players.

There's plenty of good advice to be had on the games official forums where you can find tactics and Mech builds.

There are some clan versions of popular innersphere mechs and i feel the game is going to get better.

reviewText: I've been playing this game for just over two years now and it has come a long way.  PGI is dedicated to making this game a quality product and has worked tirelessly, especially since splitting from their former publisher IGP over a year ago.  Content in the form of new mechs, new maps and game modes has been steadily increasing while PGI also puts a lot of work into game balance.  The community is a very passionate one and does not always agree with PGI's decisions regarding balance but PGI usually has it's eye on the long term and, for the most part, balances choices have been for the best.  The game is picking up more depth and although I have had periods where I was unsure about my passion for the game, I return to it with fresh enthusiam and hope.  Thank you PGI!

reviewText:
This game takes a lot to get into, but it is totally worth it. Mechwarrior is a shooter that doesn't reward reflexes rather than it rewards careful strategy and knowledge. Understanding the game is your key to winning, but unfortunately it can be a bit difficult to get into.

There is lots of things to juggle and pay attention to at one time while you play. Heat, Armor, Ammo, Movement speed, Limb Strength, current torso direction, current leg direction, radar. Its a lot. When you first play it is a bewildering amount of information that confuses you and makes it hard for you to really know what you are doing. But once you get it, it becomes second nature. You find yourself calling out enemy locations while getting missile lockons, targetting air strikes, and keeping your heat/armor carefully managed.

This is the game's strength. When you finally master the game you really feel like you are piloting a 100 ton battlemech. It feels good to fire autocannons and break the leg of an enemy mech and see him limp away in fear. It feels dire when you run as a light mech, dodging enemy fire and attempting to sabatoge the support units of the enemy team.

Sure the game is complex as all get out, but that makes it all the more *real*. Nothing gives you such grim satisfaction as turning off your heat protection and blowing out your engine in order to suicide kill an enemy mech. Feeling the loud slam as Particle cannon tears off your left arm and you retaliate with your remaining right. Never before has any game but the Mechwarrior series made me feel like I'm actually driving something. You feel connected to your Atlas or Timber Wolf as you would your car or truck. They even made it to the point where you can hear your engine malfunctioning if you are on low health, and you can listen to the hissing of your failing heat sinks if they are destroyed.

Make no mistake. This game is in beta. It still has a long way to go before it is perfect. There's also a lot of skill involved, and it isn't the kind of game that you can learn in just a few hours. But once you do, it is great fun and it is also free!

So join me, and maybe I'll see you on the battlefield mechwarrior.

reviewText: A truly outstanding mech game. If you're looking for a simulation experience with tactical gameplay, solid cooperation in every match and a positive and friendly community then look no further. Given that there is very few mech/mecha type games out there of this calibre, luckily MWO really has nailed most of what you want. The maps are big and detailed. The mechs are very customisable. This is a simulation where skill is required - but forgiving enough for a novice. When you relay coordinates and see people actively respond it shows you the community understand teamwork. When you spend the time and effort tagging opponents and people thank you for it - it's worth it. You can play a ranged game, a stealth game or get amongst it and brawl. As a final bonus, there are paid elements but you can do everything in game and there is no pay to win - David can always beat Goliath!

reviewText:
To the future players.
This game brings back old memories of the tabletop game and is a lot of fun. Enjoy a wide variety of mechs that specialise in different ways of play. They range from your up close an personal brawler, to your sniper, missle battery, support class and many others that are too many to name. Pretty much what what ever your play sytle is, MWO has something for you. and enough variety that you don't get easily bored. The number of maps are growing steadily which is nice to see. Also the maps them selves can be either balanced, or favored to one side or to a certain type of play. this makes teamwork extremely crucial for victory and gives something for everyone to do and be happy with. all in all this is a great product as long as you have the time to spend.

The game is a bit grindy so to speak. it will take a lot of effort to get everything you would want in the game. there is also a premium pack that you can pay for with real life money if that is your thing. I personally don't mind spending $5-$10 on a free game since it helps developement of the game. however if you want things like paint jobs or accessories or to buy mech flat out with cash it is so expensive it will make your wallet snap shut. it would cost you $30-$40 to buy a mech flat out with cash which is kinda stupidly expensive.

Advise to new players,
Int he beginning do the turorial it gives you ingame money also save all your turotrial money and your new cadet bonus money until you figure out what type of mech you want. You can have anything from light to medium, even heavy and assault classes. when you figure out a chassis that you like and your play style buy a mech and outfit it to what you want out of it. until then, again save your ingame money because it can be difficult to reaquire.
________________________________________________________________________________

To the developers,
the prices of your consumables and other items are what you would expect. However the cost of mechs are stupidly expenensive. making them $10-$15 would bring in more sales. since you have the softcores and the hardcores buying mechs instead of only the hard cores. Also the price of unlocked paint/camos/cockpit accessories is also extremely high.

The MWO product is self is a great product, runs smooth even on an old computer or a high end new one, so you have a very wide player base in terms of pc budget. The graphicsa are nice, although it would be nice to see the pilot breath during boot up and shut downn modes for a little extra eye candy. also please make a setting for depth of field because the game can get kinda grainy when your sniping 1250m+ away.

Innersphere/Clan mechs

the innesphere mechs are stupidly unbalanced to clan mechs and have a but ton of useful quirks while a clan mech may only receive a slight exp bonus at the end of a round. Clan mechs are suppost to be drastically more high tech in comparisson to innersphere mechs according to game lore. because of the advantage of innerphere with both mech costs and quirks the clan mechs are severely at a disadvantage. if the balance is not going to be fixed at least make clan mechs relatively the same cost as innerphere instead of them often being 50%-100% more expensive

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that I have played this game more or less continually since closed beta.

Everyone asks if it is pay to win. No. It is NOT pay to win. Pay for convenience, absolutely. I spent the first year or so that I played without dropping a dime. It will take you time to build up a large reserve of cash and mechs if you don't invest anything but you absolutely can. Sure there are a few things that you can only buy with real world cash, about two dozen mechs, mech bays and paint. The mechs are nothing special, the bays can be won in some challenges/in-game achievements and the paint is purely aesthetics.

The next problem I see people have is that there is a large learning curve. The game has become much more newbie friendly recently with the addition of a training academy tutorial and a tier system that will help to place you with similar skill level pilots. The issue many people have coming into the game is expecting a Hawken or CoD like shooter. This game is about tactics and attrition. You will need to hit your opponent more than once to bring him down at the same time avoiding as much damage as possible. My number one recommendation is to join a unit. Your peers are going to be a HUGE help with teaching tactics, mech building and the like.

There is also a quickly growing competitive side to the game with PGI even hosting a tournament with a 100k cash purse. There are player driven leagues with cash prizes and a shout casts on twitch and with the new spectator tools allow for some really fun to watch battles.

Overall I strongly recommend this game.

reviewText:
To Preface: I've been playing very consistently since the beginning of open beta, eons ago.  My actual experience is more than Steam hours suggest.

MWO, in its current development, is a solid and reasonably fleshed out shooter.  More specifically, it's a Mechwarrior game, meaning it's at least somewhat loyal to the Battletech universe.  It's fun to play, fun to plan out, and quite challenging as you progress through the Tiers (skill level system that tries to match you against similarily skilled players).

The good:
1. Lots of big robots of varying kinds, each with unique qualities, shapes, weapon options, and experience.
2. Quite a decent list of different locations/planets/terrains/environments to carry out a match in.
3. Decent selection of weapon types to suit different playstyles, ranges, loadout mixes, and flavour/interest.
4. The beginnings of an overarcing goal in the form of a galaxy map where you can expand/defend your chosen faction.

The bad:
1. Not a lot of gamemodes to play, and fairly limited variance between them.
2. No real reward/benefit to conquering planets on the Faction/galaxy map other than ego.
3. No missions or similar kinds of matches to make it feel like a real galaxy/war that you're fighting in.

In the end, MWO is a lot of fun to play - so right there I have to recommned it.  Everything is free, if you want, so you really don't have to invest any cash in it at all.
I find myself regularly logging in after a couple of years, and still having a good time.
I think MWO could really expand to the point of having a lot of depth - which would make it a really killer option.  In reality, though, it still feels a little bit incomplete/lacking.  The matches themselves are fun, but there doesn't seem to be a grander purpose - which I think would be valuable in a galactic game with a rich story background.

Worth checking out.  Stompy robots, my friends, with big guns.

reviewText: I've been playing this game for just over two years now and it has come a long way.  PGI is dedicated to making this game a quality product and has worked tirelessly, especially since splitting from their former publisher IGP over a year ago.  Content in the form of new mechs, new maps and game modes has been steadily increasing while PGI also puts a lot of work into game balance.  The community is a very passionate one and does not always agree with PGI's decisions regarding balance but PGI usually has it's eye on the long term and, for the most part, balances choices have been for the best.  The game is picking up more depth and although I have had periods where I was unsure about my passion for the game, I return to it with fresh enthusiam and hope.  Thank you PGI!

reviewText: I have kept up with this game from its crowd-funded days. I was an Elite Founder myself. There were many rocky patches during development, I even had to take a break for a while. However I can assure you that what you see here on steam is one of  if not the most solid mech game out there, especially for the current gen, the only games that could compare would be Armoured Core 4 or Chrome Hounds.\n\nIf you like a slow-paced tactical shooter, or if you like big stompy robits, or if you like flashy lazar beemz, frankly if you like vidya I recommend you give MWO a try. Heck, its free, whats to lose?

reviewText:
This game takes a lot to get into, but it is totally worth it. Mechwarrior is a shooter that doesn't reward reflexes rather than it rewards careful strategy and knowledge. Understanding the game is your key to winning, but unfortunately it can be a bit difficult to get into.

There is lots of things to juggle and pay attention to at one time while you play. Heat, Armor, Ammo, Movement speed, Limb Strength, current torso direction, current leg direction, radar. Its a lot. When you first play it is a bewildering amount of information that confuses you and makes it hard for you to really know what you are doing. But once you get it, it becomes second nature. You find yourself calling out enemy locations while getting missile lockons, targetting air strikes, and keeping your heat/armor carefully managed.

This is the game's strength. When you finally master the game you really feel like you are piloting a 100 ton battlemech. It feels good to fire autocannons and break the leg of an enemy mech and see him limp away in fear. It feels dire when you run as a light mech, dodging enemy fire and attempting to sabatoge the support units of the enemy team.

Sure the game is complex as all get out, but that makes it all the more *real*. Nothing gives you such grim satisfaction as turning off your heat protection and blowing out your engine in order to suicide kill an enemy mech. Feeling the loud slam as Particle cannon tears off your left arm and you retaliate with your remaining right. Never before has any game but the Mechwarrior series made me feel like I'm actually driving something. You feel connected to your Atlas or Timber Wolf as you would your car or truck. They even made it to the point where you can hear your engine malfunctioning if you are on low health, and you can listen to the hissing of your failing heat sinks if they are destroyed.

Make no mistake. This game is in beta. It still has a long way to go before it is perfect. There's also a lot of skill involved, and it isn't the kind of game that you can learn in just a few hours. But once you do, it is great fun and it is also free!

So join me, and maybe I'll see you on the battlefield mechwarrior.

reviewText: A truly outstanding mech game. If you're looking for a simulation experience with tactical gameplay, solid cooperation in every match and a positive and friendly community then look no further. Given that there is very few mech/mecha type games out there of this calibre, luckily MWO really has nailed most of what you want. The maps are big and detailed. The mechs are very customisable. This is a simulation where skill is required - but forgiving enough for a novice. When you relay coordinates and see people actively respond it shows you the community understand teamwork. When you spend the time and effort tagging opponents and people thank you for it - it's worth it. You can play a ranged game, a stealth game or get amongst it and brawl. As a final bonus, there are paid elements but you can do everything in game and there is no pay to win - David can always beat Goliath!
